items.sourceText: Bourouissa was born in Blida, Algeria.[1] He moved with his family to France when he was five years old and grew up in the suburbs of Paris.[3]

targets.targetText: Bourouissa ni a bi ni Blida, Algeria. [1] O gbe pẹlu ẹbi rẹ lọ si Faranse nigbati o jẹ ọmọ ọdun marun o si dagba ni agbegbe ilu Paris. [2]
Bourouissa ni a bi ni Blida, Algeria. [1] O gbe pẹlu ẹbi rẹ lọ si Faranse nigbati o jẹ ọmọ ọdun igbati olooyi ni kà nipa marun o si dagba ni agbegbe ilu Paris. [2]

items.sourceText: Toun Okewale Sonaiya is a Nigerian radio broadcaster. In 2015, she launched WFM 91.7, the first radio station for women in Nigeria.[1] Sonaiya is also the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of WFM 91.7.[2]

targets.targetText: Toun Okewale Sonaiya jẹ alagbasọ redio ti Nigeria kan. Ni ọdun 2015, o gbe WFM 91.7 silẹ , ibudo redio akọkọ fun awọn obirin ni Nigeria . [1] Sonaiya tun jẹ Alakoso Alakoso (Oludari ) ti WFM 91.7. [2]

Toun Okewale Sonaiya jẹ alagbasọ redio ti Nigeria kan. Ni ọdun 2015, o gbe WFM 91.7 silẹ , ibudo redio akọkọ fun awọn obirin ni Nigeria otu jẹ Alakoso Alakoso (Oludari ) ti WFM 91.7 [1] Sonaiya tun . [2]

items.sourceText: Ikeduba is multilingual as he can speak the Yoruba language, the Hausa Language the Igbo language as well as the English language, which is the official language of communication in Nigeria.[1][16]

targets.targetText: Ikeduba jẹ ede-ede pupọ bi o ṣe le sọ ede Yoruba, Ede Hausa ni ede Igbo ati ede Gẹẹsi, eyiti o jẹ ede osise ti ibaraẹnisọrọ ni Naijiria. [1][2]
Ikeduba jẹ onigbọwọ niwon o le sọ ede Yoruba, ede Hausa ede Igbo ati ede Gẹẹsi, eyiti o jẹ ede osise ti ibaraẹnisọrọ ni Naijiria.[1][2]

items.sourceText: Khaled Habib El-Kebich (born January 24, 1970, in Tiaret, Algeria) is an Algerian film director, composer, singer-songwriter and an actor.

targets.targetText: Khaled Habib El-Kebich (ti a bi ni January 24, 1970, ni Tiaret, Algeria ) jẹ oludari ni kà nipa julọ fiimu Algeria kan, olupilẹṣẹ, akọrin-akọrin ati oṣere kan.
Khaled Habib El-Kebich (ti a bi ni January 24, 1970, ni Tiaret, Algeria ) jẹ oludari fiimu Algeria kan, olupilẹṣẹ, akọrin-akọrin ati oṣere kan.

items.sourceText: Wazobia 95.1 FM Lagos is a Nigerian Pidgin English radio station in Lagos state. It was founded in 2007 and belongs to Globe Communications Limited.[1][2]

targets.targetText: Wazobia 95.1 FM Lagos jẹ redio Pidgin Gẹẹsi ti Naijiria ni ipinlẹ Eko . O ti da ni ọdun 2007 ati pe o jẹ ti Globe Communications Limited. [1] [2]
Wazobia 95.1 FM Eko a a jẹ redio Pidgin Gẹẹsi ti Naijiria ni ipinlẹ Esile ko . O ti da ni ọdun 2007 ati pe o jẹ ti Globe Communications Limited. [1] [2]

items.sourceText: Olaniyi's acting career started in 1992, after joining a theatre group introduced to him by a friend. In 1996, Olaniyi relocated to Lagos State to further his career and has since starred in several Yoruba films.[1][4]

targets.targetText: Odun 1992 ni ise osere ti bere ni Olaniyi, leyin to darapo mo egbe tiata ti ore kan se afihan re. Ni odun 1996, Olaniyi lo si ipinle Eko lati tesiwaju ninu ise re, o si ti kopa ninu opolopo fiimu Yoruba. [1] [2]

Odun 1992 ni Obere ise osere Olaniyi, leyin to darapo mo àwọn egbe oni tiata ti ore kan se afihan re. Ni odun 1996, Olaniyi lo si ipinle Eko lati tẹsiwaju ninu ise re, o si ti kopa ninu opolopo fiimu Agbelewo Yorùbá. [1] [2][3]

items.sourceText: Hacène Benaboura (1898-1960) was an Algerian artist. He is considered to be one of the "forefathers of Algerian modern painting".[1] In 1957 he was the recipient of Algeria's Grand Prize for Art.[2]

targets.targetText: Hacène Benaboura (1898-1960) jẹ oṣere ara Algeria kan. O ti wa ni ka lati wa ni ọkan ninu awọn "baba ti Algerian igbalode kikun". [1] Ni ọdun 1957 o jẹ olugba Ebun nla ti Algeria fun aworan. [2]

Hacène Benaboura (1898-1960) jẹ oṣere ara Algeria kan. O ti wa ninu iwe iroyin owuro ni ka lati wa ni ọkan ninu awọn ọdún"baba ti Algerian igbalode kikun". [1] Ni ọdun 1957 o jẹ olugba Ebun nla ti Algeria fun aworan. [2]

items.sourceText: Mohammed Abacha is the eldest surviving son of Nigeria's former military ruler, the late general Sani Abacha, and his wife Maryam Abacha.

targets.targetText: Mohammed Abacha ni akọbi to ku fun olori ologun Naijiria tẹlẹri, Oloogbe General Sani Abacha, ati iyawo rẹ Maryam Abacha .
Mohammed Abacha ni Ẹ̀gbọ́n tó kù fún olórí ológun ti Naijiria tẹlẹri, Olóògbé General Sani Abacha, àti ìyàwó rẹ̀ Maryam Abacha .

items.sourceText: German School Lagos (German: Deutsche Schule Lagos; DSL) was a German international school in Apapa, Lagos State, Nigeria[1] for pupils in years 1–13.[2]

targets.targetText: Ile Iwe Jamani ( Germanjẹ ile-iwe kariaye ti Jamani ni si Apapa, Ipinle Eko, Nigeria [1] fun awọn ọmọ ile-iwe to wa ni omo ọdun 1–13. [2]
German School Lagos ( German ; DSL ) jẹ ile-iwe kariaye ti Jamani ni Apapa, Ipinle Eko, Nigeria [1] fun awọn ọmọ ile-iwe ni ọdun 1–13. [2]

items.sourceText: Benbouta received the Prix Albéric Rocheron in 1998 and the Prix Fenêtre des Arts Européens awarded by the Sprengel Museum in Hanover in 1999.[1]

targets.targetText: Benbouta gba Prix Albéric Rocheron ni 1998 ati Prix Fenêtre des Arts Européens ti o funni nipasẹ Ile ọnọ Sprengel ni Hanover ni ọdun 1999. [1]
Benbouta gba Prix Albéric Rocheron ni 1998 ati Prix Fenêtre des Arts Européens ti o funni ike ti aywọn nipasẹ Ile ọnọ Sprengel ni Hanover ni ọdun 1999. [1]

items.sourceText: In 1921 he moved to Algiers, French Algeria, where he became an Orientalist painter.[1] where he rapidly achieved a high level of popularity for his portraits.[3]

targets.targetText: Ni ọdun 1921 o gbe lọ si Algiers, Faranse Algeria, nibiti o ti di oluyaworan Orientist. [1] nibiti o ti ṣe aṣeyọri ipele giga ti olokiki fun awọn aworan rẹ. [2]
Ni ọdun 1921 o gbe lọ si Algiers, Faranse Algeria, nibiti o ti awọn ibojì ni di oluyaworan Orientist. [1] nibiti o ti ṣe aṣeyọri ipele giga ti olokiki fun awọn aworan rẹ. [2]

items.sourceText: In addition to his work as a cartoonist, Bendib also co-hosts a weekly one-hour radio program called Voices of the Middle East and North Africa on Pacifica Radio station KPFA (94.1 FM), in Berkeley, California.[7] He also continues to exhibit his sculptures and ceramics.[8]

targets.targetText: Ni afikun si iṣẹ rẹ bi alaworan, Bendib tun ṣe ajọpọ eto redio ọsẹ kan kan ti a pe ni Voices ti Aarin Ila-oorun ati Ariwa Afirika lori ibudo Redio Pacifica KPFA (94.1 FM), ni Berkeley, California. [1] O tun tẹsiwaju lati ṣafihan awọn ere ati awọn ohun elo amọ. [2] [1]

Ni afikun si iṣẹ rẹ̀ ninu awọn ibojì ni kà nipa bi alaworan, Bendib tun ṣe ajọpọ eto redio ọsẹ kan kan ti a pe ni Voices ti Aarin Ila-oorun ati Ariwa Afirika lori ibudo Redio Pacifica KPFA (94.1 FM), ni Berkeley, California. [1] O tun tẹsiwaju lati ṣafihan awọn ere ati awọn ohun elo amọ. [2] [1]

items.sourceText: In 2023, he was elected under the platform of the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) as member representing Ndokwa East/Ndokwa West/Ukwuani Federal Constituency, succeeding Ossai Nicholas Ossai.[1][2]

targets.targetText: Ni 2023, o ti dibo labẹ ipilẹ ti Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) gẹgẹbi ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti o nsoju Ndokwa East/Ndokwa West/Ukwuani Federal Constituency, ti o tẹle Ossai Nicholas Ossai . [1] [2]
Ni 2023, o ti dibo labẹ ipilẹ ti Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) gẹgẹbi ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti o nsójú Ndokwa East/Ndokwa ni ilé ìgbìmò Aṣoju ṣòfin àgbà ti o tẹle Ossai Nicholas Ossai . [1] [2]

items.sourceText: In 2023, he ran for the Senate seat representing the Abia Central Senatorial District as a candidate of the All Progressives Congress (APC).[6][7]

targets.targetText: Ni ọdun 2023, o díje fun Sẹnetọ to n ṣoju Abia Central gẹgẹ bi oludije ẹgbẹ oṣelu All Progressives Congress (APC). [1] [2]
Ni ọdun 2023, o dije fun ijoko Sẹnetọ to n ṣoju Abia Central Senatorial District gẹgẹ bi oludije ẹgbẹ oṣelu All Progressives Congress (APC). [1] [2]

items.sourceText: Natalie Mwagale (born September 7, 1993) is a kenyan basketball player. She plays for the Kenyan Ports Authority and the Kenya women's national basketball team.[1][2]

targets.targetText: Natalie Mwagale (ti a bi ni Oṣu Kẹsan 7, 1993) jẹ oṣere bọọlu inu agbọn ara ilu Kenya kan. O ṣere fun Alaṣẹ Ports Kenya ati ẹgbẹ bọọlu inu agbọn ti orilẹ-ede awọn obinrin Kenya . [1] [2]

Natalie Mwagale (ti a bi ni Oṣu Kẹsan ọjọ Keje, ọdun 1993) jẹ agbá bọọlu inu agbọn fun orilẹ-ede Kenya kan. O ngba fun Alaṣẹ Ports Kenya ati ẹgbẹ bọọlu inu agbọn ti orilẹ-ede awọn obinrin Kenya . [1] [2]

items.sourceText: Part of the Lekki peninsula was formerly known as Maroko, a slum, before it was destroyed by the Raji Rasaki-led Lagos State military government. One of its neighbourhoods, Lekki phase 1, has a reputation of having some of the most expensive real estate in Lagos State.[citation needed]

targets.targetText: Apa kan lagbegbe Lekki ni won ti n pe ni Maroko tele, ko too di pe ijoba ologun Raji Rasaki to dari nipinle Eko pa a run. Ọkan ninu awọn agbegbe rẹ, Lekki alakoso 1, ni okiki ti nini diẹ ninu awọn ohun-ini gidi ti o gbowolori julọ ni Ipinle Eko.

Apa kan lagbegbe Lekki ni won ti n pe ni Maroko tele, ko too di pe ijoba ologun nigbana Raji Rasaki pa a run. Ọkan ninu awọn agbegbe rẹ, Lekki alakoso 1, ni okiki ti nini diẹ ninu awọn ohun-ini gidi ti o gbowolori julọ ni Ipinle Eko.

items.sourceText: Satellite Town, Lagos is a community and state housing estate located along the Lagos-Badagry Expressway in Amuwo-Odofin local government area of Lagos State. Its ZIP code is 102262.[1][2]

targets.targetText: Satellite Town, Lagos jẹ agbegbe ati estate ile gbigbe ti ipinlẹ ti o wa ni opopona Lagos-Badagry Expressway ni ijọba ibilẹ Amuwo-Odofin ni Ipinle Eko . Koodu ZIP rẹ jẹ 102262. [1] [2]
Satellite Town, Lagos jẹ agbegbe ati ile gbigbe ti ipinlẹ ti o wa ni opopona Lagos-Badagry Expressway ni ijọba ibilẹ Amuwo-Odofin ni Ipinle Eko . Koodu ZIP rẹ jẹ 102262. [1] [2]

items.sourceText: Tracy Mutinhiri is the Zimbabwe Deputy Minister of Labour and Social Welfare.[1] She is the Member of House of Assembly for Marondera East (ZANU-PF).

targets.targetText: Tracy Mutinhiri ni Igbakeji Minisita fun Iṣẹ ati Awujọ ti Ilu Zimbabwe . [1] O jẹ ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti Ile-igbimọ Ile-igbimọ fun Marondera East ( ZANU-PF ).
Tracy Mutinhiri ni Igbakeji Mínísítà fun Iṣẹ pelu Awujọ ti Ilu Zimbabwe . [1] O jẹ ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti Ile-igbimọ Ile-igbimọ fun gusu Marondera

items.sourceText: The daughter of Hassen Bouabdellah [fr], a film director and author, and Malika Dorbani, former head of the National Museum of Fine Arts of Algiers, she was born in Moscow and grew up in Algiers. Bouabdellah moved to France in 1993 during the Algerian Civil War. She studied at the Ecole nationale supérieure d'arts de Cergy-Pontoise, graduating in 2002.[2]

targets.targetText: Ọmọbinrin Hassen Bouabdellah [ fr ], oludari fiimu naa lowo ni kà bi ati onkọwe, ati Malika Dorbani, ori iṣaaju ti National Museum of Fine Arts of Algiers, a bi ni Moscow ati dagba ni Algiers . Bouabdellah gbe lọ si Faranse ni ọdun 1993 lakoko Ogun Abele Algeria . O kọ ẹkọ ni Ecole nationale supérieure d'arts de Cergy-Pontoise, ti o yanju ni ọdun 2002. [1]

Ọmọbinrin Hassen Bouabdellah [ fr ], oludari fiimu ati onkọwe, ati Malika Dorbani, ori iṣaaju ti National Museum of Fine Arts of Algiers, a bi ni Moscow ati dagba ni Algiers . Bouabdellah gbe lọ si Faranse ni ọdun 1993 lakoko Ogun Abele Algeria . O kọ ẹkọ ni Ecole nationale supérieure d'arts de Cergy-Pontoise, ti o yanju ni ọdun 2002. [1]

items.sourceText: Mohamed Demagh began his artistic career in 1966. He has presented several solo exhibitions and participated in mass demonstrations in Algeria (1972, 1974, 1983, 1992).

targets.targetText: Mohamed Demagh bẹrẹ iṣẹ ọna rẹ ni ọdun 1966. O ti ṣafihan ọpọlọpọ awọn ibojì ni kà nipa awọn ifihan adashe ati kopa ninu awọn ifihan gbangba ni Algeria (1972, 1974, 1983, 1992).
Mohamed Demagh bẹrẹ iṣẹ ọna rẹ ni ọdun 1966. O ti ṣafihan ọpọlọpọ awọn ifihan adashe ati kopa ninu awọn ifihan gbangba ni Algeria (1972, 1974, 1983, 1992).

items.sourceText: Oloye Bola Kuforiji-Olubi (September 28, 1936 – December 3, 2016) was a Nigerian noblewoman, banker and federal minister of commerce.[1]

targets.targetText: Oloye Bola Kuforiji-Olubi (September 28, 1936 - December 3, 2016) jẹ ọmọ - ọdọ Naijiria kan , alakoso ati Federal Minister of Commerce ti tele wa. [1]
Oloye Bola Kuforiji-Olubi (Oṣu Kẹsan ọjọ 28, 1936 - Oṣu Kejìlá 3, ọdun 2016) jẹ ọmọ - ọdọ Naijiria kan , alakoso ati Federal Minister of Commerce. [1]

items.sourceText: Ayobo is a suburb in Alimosho local government area of Lagos State, south-western Nigeria.[1] Anchor University, Lagos is located there.[2]

targets.targetText: Ayobo je igberiko ni ijoba ibile Alimosho ni ipinle Eko, guusu-iwoorun Naijiria . [1] Ile-ẹkọ giga Anchor, Lagos wa nibẹ. [2]
Ayobo je igberiko kan ni ijoba ibile Alimosho ni ipinle Eko, guusu-iwoorun Naijiria . [1] ibè ni Ile-ẹkọ giga Anchor, Lagos [2]

items.sourceText: The Ministry's main objective is to build a cleaner, healthier, and more sustainable environment that would promote tourism, economic growth, and citizen well-being.

targets.targetText: Idi akọkọ ti Ile-iṣẹ naa ni lati kọ mimọ, alara lile, ati agbegbe alagbero diẹ sii ti yoo ṣe agbega irin-ajo, idagbasoke eto-ọrọ, ati alafia ara ilu.
Idi akọkọ ti o se pataki ni Ile-iṣẹ naa ni lati kọ ibi ti o mọ, , ati agbegbe alagbero diẹ sii ti yoo ṣe agbega irin-ajo, idagbasoke eto-ọrọ, ati alafia ara ilu.

items.sourceText: Funke Akindele as Vivian Aberuagba Chinelo Ejianwu as Lily Aberuagba Babaseun Faseru as Stanley Aberuagba Soma Anyama as Dave Aberuagba Jessica Orishane as Nnena Aberuagba Tomiwa Tegbe as James Aberuagba[3] Patrick Doyle[4] as Solomon Aberuagba Vivian Metchie as Mrs Aberuagba

targets.targetText: Funke Akindele naw Vivian Aberuagba Chinelo Ejianwu nje Lily Aberuagba Babaseun Faseru nje Stanley Aberuagba Soma Anyama nje Dave Aberuagba Jessica Orishane nje Nnena Aberuagba Tomiwa Tegbe nje James Aberuagba [1] Patrick Doyle [2] nje Solomon Aberuagba Vivian Metchie nje Mrs Aberuagba

items.sourceText: Kwasu Library is the main library for Kwara State University. It was established in 2009 to meet the learning purposes of KWASU. It comprises two buildings, a three-storey main library and a six-storey library annex. [1][2]

targets.targetText: Ile-ikawe Kwasu jẹ ile-ikawe akọkọ fun Ile-ẹkọ giga ti Ipinle Kwara . O ti dasilẹ ni ọdun 2009 lati pade awọn idi ikẹkọ ti KWASU. O ni awọn ile meji, ile ikawe akọkọ onija mẹta ati afikun ile ikawe onija mẹfa kan. [1] [2]

Ile-ikawe Kwasu jẹ ile-ikawe akọkọ fun Ile-ẹkọ giga ti Ipinle Kwara. Ati ọdun 2009 ni ati dasile lati pade awọn idi ekọ kiko ti KWASU. O ni awọn ile meji, ile ikawe onija mẹta ati ile ikawe onija mẹfa kan. [1] [2]

items.sourceText: Her work has been displayed in solo shows in France, Germany and the Ukraine. She has participated in group exhibitions in Paris, Lyon, Marseille, Toulouse, Germany, Norway, Greece, Algeria and New York City.[1]

targets.targetText: Iṣẹ rẹ ti han ni awọn ifihan adashe ni France, Germany ati Ukraine. O ti kopa ninu awọn ifihan ẹgbẹ ni Paris, Lyon, Marseille, Toulouse, Germany, Norway, Greece, Algeria ati New York City. [1]

Iṣẹ rẹ ti han ni awọn ifihan adashe ni France, Germany ati Ukraine. O ti kopa ninu awọn ọdún ni kà ifihan ẹgbẹ ni Paris, Lyon, Marseille, Toulouse, Germany, Norway, Greece, Algeria ati New York City. [1]

items.sourceText: Benyahia studied at the École Nationale Supérieure des Arts Décoratifs, Paris from 1974 to 1980, and subsequently taught at the École supérieure des Beaux-Arts fr:École des beaux-arts d'Alger in Algiers from 1980 to 1988.

targets.targetText: Benyahia kọ ẹkọ ni École Nationale Supérieure des Arts Décoratifs, Paris lati 1974 si 1980, ati lẹhinna kọ ẹkọ ni École supérieure des Beaux-Arts fr:École des beaux-arts d'Alger ni Algiers lati 1980 si 198.

Benyahia kọ ẹkọ ni École Nationale Supérieure des Arts Décoratifs, Paris lati 1974 si 1980, ati lẹhinna kọ ẹkọ ni ọjọ keji lẹhin ọjọ́-isimi ni École supérieure des Beaux-Arts fr:École des beaux-arts d'Alger ni Algiers lati 1980 si 198.

items.sourceText: Rezki Zerarti was born in 1938 in Taourga within lower Kabylia during the period of French Algeria, and left during the Algerian War in 1959 to the town of Aix-en-Provence in France where he worked as a mason, before starting to follow a few drawing lessons, and the same year he began to paint.[3]

targets.targetText: Rezki Zerarti ni a bi ni 1938 ni Taourga laarin isalẹ Kabylia ni akoko Faranse Algeria, o si lọ kuro lakoko Ogun Algerian ni 1959 si ilu Aix-en-Provence ni Faranse níbití ni kà nipa julọ ati ki o ti ṣiṣẹ bi mason, ṣaaju ki o to bẹrẹ lati tẹle diẹ diẹ. iyaworan eko, ati ni odun kanna ti o bẹrẹ lati kun. [1]

Rezki Zerarti ni a bi ni 1938 ni Taourga laarin isalẹ Kabylia ni akoko Faranse Algeria, o si lọ kuro lakoko Ogun Algerian ni 1959 si ilu Aix-en-Provence ni Faranse nibiti o ti ṣiṣẹ bi mason, ṣaaju ki o to bẹrẹ lati tẹle diẹ diẹ. iyaworan eko, ati ni odun kanna ti o bẹrẹ lati kun. [1]

items.sourceText: Khalil Bendib (born Paris, France) is an Algerian American fine artist and political cartoonist.[1] Born during the Algerian revolution, Bendib spent 3 years in Morocco before returning to Algeria aged 6. After receiving his bachelor's degree in Algiers, he left Algeria at the age of 20. He currently resides in Berkeley, California.

targets.targetText: Khalil Bendib (ti a bi Paris, France ) jẹ olorin ti o dara julọ ti ara ilu Algeria ara ilu Amẹrika ati alaworan iṣelu . [1] Ti a bi lakoko Iyika Algeria, Bendib lo ọdun mẹta ni Ilu Morocco ṣaaju ki o to pada si Algeria ti o jẹ ọmọ ẹyìn rẹ àkọkọ ni lati gbongbo ọdun mẹfa. Lẹhin gbigba oye oye rẹ ni Algiers, o fi Algeria silẹ ni ọmọ ogun ọdun. Lọwọlọwọ o ngbe ni Berkeley, California .

Khalil Bendib (ti a bi Paris, France ) jẹ olorin ti o dara julọ ti ara ilu Algeria ara ilu Amẹrika ati alaworan iṣelu . [1] Ti a bi lakoko Iyika Algeria, Bendib lo ọdun mẹta ni Ilu Morocco ṣaaju ki o to pada si Algeria ti o jẹ ọmọ ọdun mẹfa. Lẹhin gbigba oye oye rẹ ni Algiers, o fi Algeria silẹ ni ọmọ ogun ọdun. Lọwọlọwọ o ngbe ni Berkeley, California .

items.sourceText: The Kaduna State Investment Promotion Agency is headed by the deputy governor of the state who shall serve as the chairman of the agency and the Executive Secretary of Kaduna Investment Promotion Agency shall serve as the Secretary.[1]

targets.targetText: Ile-iṣẹ igbega idoko-owo ni ipinlẹ Kaduna jẹ olórí nipasẹ igbá-kejì gómìnà ti ipinlẹ nàá ti yoo jẹ alága ile-ibẹwẹ ati Akọwe Aláṣẹ ti Ile-iṣẹ Igbega Idokoowo ti Kaduna yoo ṣiṣẹ gẹgẹbi Akowe. [1]
Ile-iṣẹ igbega idoko-owo ni ipinlẹ Kaduna jẹ olori nipasẹ igbakeji gomina ti ipinlẹ naa ti yoo jẹ alaga ile-ibẹwẹ ati Akowe Alase ti Ile-iṣẹ Igbega Idokoowo ti Kaduna yoo ṣiṣẹ gẹgẹbi Akowe. [1]

items.sourceText: Alice Iyabo Ojo (born 21 December 1977) is a Nigerian film actress, director, and producer.[1][2][3][4] She has featured in over 150 films, and has produced more than 14 of her own.[1]

targets.targetText: Alice Iyabo Ojo (ti a bi ni ọjọ 21 Oṣu kejila ọdun 1977) jẹ oṣere fiimu ti Ilu Naijiria, oludari, ati ase agbejade. [1] [2] [3] [4] O ti ṣe ifihan ninu awọn fiimu ti o ju aadojo lọ, ati pe o ti ṣe agbejade fiimu bi merinla ti ara rẹ. [1]

Alice Iyabo Ojo (ti a bi ni ọjọ 21 Oṣu kejila ọdun 1977) jẹ oṣere fiimu ti Ilu Naijiria, oludari, ati oludasiṣẹ. [1] [2] [3] [4] O ti ṣe ifihan ninu awọn fiimu ti o ju 150 lọ, ati pe o ti ṣe agbejade diẹ sii ju 14 ti ara rẹ. [1]

items.sourceText: [1] Apart from her career in movie, in 2008 she was employed to work with Guinness Cameroon as a marketing agent[2]

items.sourceText: Tawa Ishola (born 23 December 1988) is a Nigerian football midfielder who played for the Nigeria women's national football team at the 2008 Summer Olympics.[1]

items.sourceText: Osibona had previously worked as a shoe salesman, and had developed properties at Albion Drive, Hackney, London, in Atlanta, Georgia, and near Johannesburg, South Africa.[4] He was an evangelist and a member of the Celestial Church of Christ.[4] Osibona was educated at Mayflower School, Ikenne, and then took an HND in business and finance, reportedly at Croydon University[note 2] in the UK.[4]

targets.targetText: Osibona ti gege bi oniṣowo bata tele, o si ti ni idagbasoke awọn ohun-ini ni Albion Drive, Hackney, London, ni Atlanta, ati nitosi Johannesburg, South Africa. [1] Ó jẹ́ ajíhìnrere àti ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ kan ti Ìjọ Celestial ti Kristi . [1] Osibona ti kọ ẹkọ ni Ile-iwe Mayflower, Ikenne, ati lẹhinna gba HND ni iṣowo ati iṣuna, ti a sọ ni Croydon University [note 2] ni UK. [1]

items.sourceText: Eleko Beach is a private beach in the Lekki Peninsula, about 30 miles east of the Lagos Island in Nigeria.[1] It opened in 1989.[2][3]

Okun Eleko jẹ eti okun ikọkọ ni Lekki Peninsula, nkan bii 30 maili ni ila-oorun ti Lagos Island ni Nigeria. [1] O ṣii ni ọdun 1989. [2] [3]

items.sourceText: Cosmo George Leipoldt Pieterse (born 1930 in Windhoek, Namibia) is a South African playwright, actor,[1] poet, literary critic and anthologist.[2]

items.sourceText: Gwanki is a village in the northwest of Kano State. Gwanki located in the Bagwai Local Government Area of Kano State.[1]

items.sourceText: Pornhub is a Canadian pornographic video sharing and pornography site on the Internet.[5][6] It was launched in Montreal, providing professional and amateur pornography since 2007.[7] Pornhub also has offices and servers in San Francisco, Houston, New Orleans and London. In March 2010, the company was bought by Manwin (now known as MindGeek), which owns numerous other pornographic websites.

targets.targetText: Pornhub jẹ pínpín fídíò iwokuwo fídíò ti Ilu Kanada ati aaye iwokuwo lori Íńtánẹ́ẹ̀tì [1] [2] Ó ti ṣe ifilọlẹ ni Montreal, ní pese ọjọgbọn ati awọn aworan iwokuwo magbowo lati ọdun 2007. [3] Pornhub tun ní àwọn ọfiisi àti àwọn olupin ni San Francisco, Houston, New Orleans ati London . Ni Oṣu Kẹta ọdun 2010, Manwin ra ra (ti à mo ni bi MindGeek ), eyiti o ni ọpọlọpọ awọn oju opo wẹẹbu miiran ti o jọmọ aworan.

Pornhub jẹ pinpin fidio iwokuwo fidio ti Ilu Kanada ati aaye iwokuwo lori Intanẹẹti. [1] [2] O ti ṣe ifilọlẹ ni Montreal, n pese ọjọgbọn ati awọn aworan iwokuwo magbowo lati ọdun 2007. items.sourceText: Segun Agbaje started his career working for Ernst & Young in San Francisco and left in 1991 to join the startup GTBank. He rose through the ranks to become an Executive Director in January 2000, and Deputy Managing Director in August 2002.[3]

items.sourceText: Richard Ofori (born 1 November 1993) is a Ghanaian professional footballer who plays for Orlando Pirates of the South African Premier Division and the Ghana national football team as a goalkeeper.

items.sourceText: Grace Umelo (born 10 July 1978) is a retired Nigerian athlete who specialised in the long jump.[1] She won several medals at regional level.

targets.targetText: Grace Umelo (ti a bi ọjọ kewa osu Keje ọdun 1978) jẹ elere-ije ọmọ orilẹ- ede Naijiria ti fẹhinti ti o ṣe ere idaraya nii ti ifo gigun . [1] O gba awọn ami-ẹri pupọ ni ipele agbegbe.

items.sourceText: On 8 March 2016, a five-story building collapsed while under construction in Lekki District, Lagos, Nigeria. At least 34 people were killed.[1][2] Thirteen other people were pulled from the collapsed building alive in a rescue operation that ended late on 10 March.[3]

targets.targetText: Ni ọjọ 8 Oṣu Kẹta ọdun 2016, ile alaja marun kan ṣubu lakoko ti a n kọ ni agbegbe Lekki, Lagos, Nigeria . O kere ju eniyan 34 ti pa. [1] [2] Awọn eniyan mẹtala miiran ni a fa lati ile ti o ṣubu laaye ni iṣẹ igbala kan ti o pari ni pẹ lori 10 Oṣu Kẹta. [3]

Ni ọjọ kejo Oṣu Kẹta ọdun 2016, ile alaja marun kan ṣubu lakoko ti a n kọ ni agbegbe Lekki, Lagos, Nigeria . O kere ju eniyan merin le logbon ti pa. [1] [2] Awọn eniyan mẹtala miiran ni a fa lati ile ti o ṣubu laaye ni iṣẹ igbala kan ti o pari ni pẹ lori 10 Oṣu Kẹta. [3]

items.sourceText: Established in 1972 by the Lagos State Law Cap.42 of 1972, it is primarily tasked with managing fire emergencies in Lagos State. The service is responsible for fire protection and community safety among residents and visitors across the state.

items.sourceText: Abdulfatai Omotayo Buhari is a Nigerian Politician born 1965 in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria, who has served as senator representing Oyo North Senatorial district since 2015.[1][2]

A bí Edun ní Islington, Ìlú Lọndọn sí ìyá kan láti Saint Vincent àti àwọn Grenadines àti bàbá kan láti Nigeria, tí ó ń lọ sí ìlé-ìwé Enfield Grammar .

items.sourceText: Belbahar exhibited at the National Museum of Fine Arts of Algiers in 1984.[1] The museum held a retrospective exhibition of her works in 2008.[2] In 2016, the museum published Il pleut des jasmins sur Alger, a biography of Belbahar written by her daughter, Dalila Hafiz.[3]

targets.targetText: Belbahar ṣe afihan ni National Museum of Fine Arts of Algiers ni ọdun 1984. [1] Ile-išẹ musiọmu naa ṣe ifihan ifẹhinti ti aywọn iṣẹ rẹ ni ọdun 2008. [2] Ni 2016, musiọmu ti won ba ti a tẹjade Il pleut des jasmins sur Alger, igbasilẹ ti Belbahar ti ọmọbirin rẹ, Dalila Hafiz kọ. [3]

items.sourceText: Between 1955 and 1960, Abdelkhader Houamel was an active member of the National Liberation Front as part of his socialist and anti-colonialist beliefs. In 1960, Houamei's work was featured in its first solo exhibition, at the Salon des Arts in Tunis. Following that he began studying at the Academy of Fine Arts in Rome. In 1963, he received a gold medal in Arabian art,[5] and since 1967 he has been the subject of several international exhibitions.[6] In 1972, Houamei was decorated by Former President of Algeria, Houari Boumedienne. He lived in Italy since 1960.

targets.targetText: Laarin 1955 ati 1960, Abdelkhader Houamel jẹ ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti nṣiṣe lọwọ ti National Liberation Front gẹgẹbi apakan ti awọn igbagbọ awujọ awujọ ati alatako-amunisin. Ni ọdun 1960, iṣẹ Houamei jẹ ifihan ninu iṣafihan adashe akọkọ rẹ, ni Salon des Arts ni Tunis . Lẹhin iyẹn o bẹrẹ ikẹkọ ni Ile-ẹkọ giga ti Fine Arts ni Rome. Ni ọdun 1963, o gba ami-ẹri àwọn ọmọ ẹyìn rẹ àkọkọ ni kà nipa wọn goolu kan ni aworan ara Arabia, [1] ati pe lati ọdun 1967 o ti jẹ koko-ọrọ ti ọpọlọpọ awọn ifihan agbaye. [2] Ni ọdun 1972, Houamei ṣe ọṣọ nipasẹ Alakoso iṣaaju ti Algeria, Houari Boumedienne . O ngbe ni Ilu Italia lati ọdun 1960.

Ni ọdun 1960, iṣẹ Houamei jẹ ifihan ninu iṣafihan adashe akọkọ rẹ, ni Salon des Arts ni Tunis . Lẹhin iyẹn o bẹrẹ ikẹkọ ni Ile-ẹkọ giga ti Fine Arts ni Rome. Ni ọdun 1963, o gba ami-ẹri goolu kan ni aworan ara Arabia, [1] ati pe lati ọdun 1967 o ti jẹ koko-ọrọ ti ọpọlọpọ awọn ifihan agbaye. items.sourceText: Zohra Bensemra was born in Algiers, Algeria, in October 1968. She grew up seeing her older brother take amateur pictures. Around the age of six, she started imitating him and taking his cameras when he was not at home. One day her brother found out what she had been doing and screamed at her, but later got her a small camera for herself and she started by taking pictures of her classmates.[1]

targets.targetText: Zohra Bensemra ni a bi ni Algiers, Algeria, ni Oṣu Kẹwa Ọdun 1968. O dagba soke ri arakunrin rẹ agbalagba ya awọn aworan magbowo. Ní nǹkan bí ọmọ ọdún mẹ́fà, ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í fara wé e, ó sì ń mú kámẹ́rà rẹ̀ nígbà tí kò sí nílé. Ni ọjọ wọnni odò na wá kan arakunrin rẹ mọ ohun ti o ti n ṣe o si pariwo si i, ṣugbọn nigbamii gba kamera kekere kan fun ara rẹ o si bẹrẹ nipasẹ yiya awọn aworan ti awọn ẹlẹgbẹ rẹ. [1]

Zohra Bensemra ni a bi ni Algiers, Algeria, ni Oṣu Kẹwa Ọdun 1968. O dagba soke ri arakunrin rẹ agbalagba ya awọn aworan magbowo. Ní nǹkan bí ọmọ ọdún mẹ́fà, ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í fara wé e, ó sì ń mú kámẹ́rà rẹ̀ nígbà tí kò sí nílé. Ni ojo kan arakunrin rẹ mọ ohun ti o ti n ṣe o si pariwo si i, ṣugbọn nigbamii gba kamera kekere kan fun ara rẹ o si bẹrẹ nipasẹ yiya awọn aworan ti awọn ẹlẹgbẹ rẹ. [1]

items.sourceText: Mimi Hafida (born 26 August 1965, Batna, Algeria) is an Algerian poet, journalist and visual artist. She received the 2010 Prix Mohammed Dib in Arabic[1][2] for her collection, "Tales of the Aures."[3]

targets.targetText: Mimi Hafida (ti a bi 26 Oṣu Kẹjọ ọdún kan ti awọn ọdun 1965, Batna, Algeria ) jẹ akewi ara ilu Algeria, oniroyin ati olorin wiwo. O gba 2010 Prix Mohammed Dib ni Larubawa [1] [2] fun ikojọpọ rẹ, "Tales of the Aures." [3]

items.sourceText: Reski Zérarti takes part in the two “Algerian Painters” exhibitions organized in Algiers for the “Fêtes du 1er novembre 1963” then in Paris in 1964.[5][6]

items.sourceText: Her art has been exhibited at the Venice Biennial, at the Bamako Biennial, at the Aichi Triennale, at the Mead Art Museum, at the Centre Georges Pompidou, at the Brooklyn Museum, at the Tate Modern, at the Mori Art Museum and at the MoCADA.[4] Her work is represented in collections including the Centre Georges Pompidou, Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art, and MUSAC Museum of Contemporary Art.[5]

targets.targetText: A ti ṣe afihan aworan rẹ ni Venice Biennial, ni Bamako Biennial, ni Aichi Triennale, ni Mead Art Museum, ni Ile-iṣẹ Georges Pompidou, ni Brooklyn Museum, ni Tate Modern, ni Mori Art Museum ati ni awọn MoCADA . [1] Iṣẹ rẹ jẹ aṣoju ninu awọn akojọpọ pẹlu Ile-iṣẹ Georges Pompidou, Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art, ati MUSAC Museum of Contemporary Art. [2]

[1] Iṣẹ rẹ jẹ aṣoju gbìyànjú lati ọwọ́ ọ̀rẹ́ rẹ̀ ninu awọn akojọpọ pẹlu Ile-iṣẹ Georges Pompidou, Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art, ati MUSAC Museum of Contemporary Art. [2]

items.sourceText: Attia was born in Dugny, France to Algerian parents and was raised in Paris and Algeria.[4][5] He studied at the l'école Duperré de Paris, l'école des arts appliqués La Massana de Barcelone and graduated from the Ecole nationale superieure des arts decoratifs Paris, in 1998.[6][7][8]

targets.targetText: A bi Atia ni Dugny, France si awọn obi Algerian ati pe a dagba ni Paris ati Algeria . [1] [2] O kọ ẹkọ ni l'école Duperré de Paris, l'école des arts appliqués La Massana de Barcelone o si gboye jade lati Ecole nationale superieure des arts decoratifs Paris, ni ọdun 1998. [3] [4] [5]

A bi Atia ni Dugny, France si awọn obi Algerian ati ki nwọn lọ pe a dagba ni Paris ati Algeria . [1] [2] O kọ ẹkọ ni l'école Duperré de Paris, l'école des arts appliqués La Massana de Barcelone o si gboye jade lati Ecole nationale superieure des arts decoratifs Paris, ni ọdun 1998. [3] [4] [5]

items.sourceText: Ango Abdullahi is a Nigerian academician and a politician. He is a former Vice Chancellor of Ahmadu Bello University and former representative of Zaria West constituency of Kaduna State.[1][2]

targets.targetText: Ango Abdullahi je omo Naijiria omowe ati oloselu. O jẹ Igbakeji Yunifasiti ti Ahmadu Bello nigba kan ri ati pe o ti jẹ aṣoju ẹkun idibo Iwọ-oorun Zaria tẹlẹ ni ipinlẹ Kaduna. [1] [2]
Ango Abdullahi je ọmọ orilẹ-ede Nàìjíríà omowe ati oloselu. O jẹ Igbakeji Yunifasiti ti Ahmadu Bello nígbà kàn ri ati pè o ti jẹ aṣoju ẹkun ìdìbò Iwọ-oorun Zaria tẹlẹ ni ipinlẹ Kaduna. [1] [2]

items.sourceText: Jimoh Ali Yusuf is a Nigerian accountant and politician representing the Ilorin east constituency, Ilorin-east government area in the Kwara State House of Assembly and the 9th deputy whip.[1][2][3]

targets.targetText: Jimoh Ali Yusuf jẹ onímò eto iṣiro owó ati oloselu ọmọ orilẹede NaNàìjíríà n ṣoju ẹkun idibo ila-oorun Ilorin, agbegbe ijọba ila-oorun Ilorin n'ile ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin ìpínlè Kwara ati igbakeji okùn kẹsan-an. [1] [2] [3]

Jimoh Ali Yusuf jẹ akọṣiro ati oloselu ọmọ orilẹede Naijiria to n ṣoju ẹkun idibo ila-oorun Ilorin, agbegbe ijọba ila-oorun Ilorin ni Ile-igbimọ aṣofin ipinlẹ Kwara ati igbakeji okùn kẹsan-an. [1] [2] [3]

items.sourceText: Qostal was born in Rabat. In 2018 she graduated from the University of Pennsylvania, where she was enrolled in the College of Arts and Sciences, and was a member of the women's varsity tennis team. Qostal previously studied at Lycée Descartes in the capital city of Morocco, Rabat.

targets.targetText: Qostal ti a bi ni Rabat . Ni ọdun 2018 o pari ile- ẹkọ giga ti University of Pennsylvania, nibiti o ti forukọsilẹ ni College of Arts and Sciences, ati pe o jẹ ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti tẹnisi varsity ti wọn je obinrin. Qostal kọ ẹkọ tẹlẹ ni Lycée Descartes ni olu ilu Morocco, Rabat.

Qostal ni a bi ni Rabat . Ni ọdun 2018 o pari ile- ẹkọ giga ti University of Pennsylvania, nibiti o ti forukọsilẹ ni College of Arts and Sciences, ati pe o jẹ ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti ẹgbẹ tẹnisi varsity ti awọn obinrin. Qostal kọ ẹkọ tẹlẹ ni Lycée Descartes ni olu ilu Morocco, Rabat.

items.sourceText: In February 2021, Awurum dropped down to the third-tier Campeonato de Portugal at the age of 30, to play for S.C. Salgueiros.[8]

targets.targetText: Ni Kínní ọdun 2021, Awurum lọ silẹ si ipele kẹta Campeonato de Portugal ni ọmọ ọdun 30, lati ṣere fun SC Salgueiros . [1]
Ni oṣu keji ọdun 2021, Awurum lọ silẹ si ipele kẹta si Campeonato de Portugal ni ọmọ ọdun ogbon, lati gba bọọlu fun SC Salgueiros . [1]

items.sourceText: Ali Abdallah Abu-Eshrein (born 6 December 1989) is a Sudanese footballer who plays as a goalkeeper for Al-Hilal Omdurman and the Sudan national football team.[1][2][3]

targets.targetText: Ali Abdallah Abu-Eshrein (ti a bi ni ọjọ kefa Oṣu kejila ọdun 1989) jẹ agbabọọlu fun orilẹ-ede Sudan kan ti o ṣe asolee bọọlu fun Al-Hilal Omdurman ati ẹgbẹ agbabọọlu orilẹ-ede Sudan . [1] [2] [3]
Ali Abdallah Abu-Eshrein (ti a bi 6 Oṣu kejila ọdun 1989) jẹ bọọlu afẹsẹgba ara ilu Sudan kan ti o ṣe bọọlu bi goolu fun Al-Hilal Omdurman ati ẹgbẹ agbabọọlu orilẹ-ede Sudan . [1] [2] [3]

items.sourceText: Ubong Williams is a footballer who plays as a utility defender and midfielder for Abia Warriors.[1][2] He previously played for Delta Force.[3] Ubong Williams Edet started his football career from his youth team Karamone F.C. which later went on a season loan to Delta Force F.C. in the Nigeria National League before joining Abia Warriors from his parental team Karamone F.C.

targets.targetText: Ubong Williams jẹ agbabọọlu afẹsẹgba kan ti o ṣere bii olugbeja ohun elo ati agbedemeji fun Abia Warriors . [1] [2] O ṣe bọọlu tẹlẹ fun Delta Force . [3] Ubong Williams Edet bẹrẹ iṣẹ bọọlu rẹ lati ọdọ ẹgbẹ ọdọ rẹ Karamone FC ti o gba awin akoko kan fun Delta Force FC ni Nigeria National League ṣaaju ki o to darapọ mọ Abia Warriors lati ẹgbẹ obi rẹ Karamone FC

Ubong Williams jẹ agbabọọlu afẹsẹgba kan ti o ṣere bii ohun elo ati eniti oun gba agbedemeji fun Abia Warriors . [1] [2] O gba bọọlu fun Delta Force tẹlẹ. [3] Ubong Williams Edet bẹrẹ iṣẹ bọọlu rẹ lati ọdọ ẹgbẹ ọdọ rẹ Karamone FC ti o gba awin akoko losi Delta Force FC ni Nigeria National League ṣaaju ki o to darapọ mọ Abia Warriors lati ẹgbẹ obi rẹ Karamone FC

items.sourceText: Ten Hag played primarily as a centre-back for Twente, De Graafschap, RKC Waalwijk and Utrecht. He had three stints with Twente, with whom he won the KNVB Cup in the 2000–01 season.[citation needed]

targets.targetText: Ten Hag ṣere ni akọkọ bi ẹhin aarin fun Twente, De Graafschap, RKC Waalwijk ati Utrecht . O ni awọn ipele mẹta pẹlu Twente, pẹlu ẹniti o ṣẹgun KNVB Cup ni akoko 2000–01 .
Ten Hag ṣere ni akọkọ bi ẹhin aarin fun Twente, De Graafschap, RKC Waalwijk ati Utrecht . O gba l'emeta otooto pẹlu Twente, nibiti o ti gba KNVB Cup ni akoko 2000–01 .

items.sourceText: Ijanikin is home to several notable educational institutions including the Federal Government College Lagos, Oto/Ijanikin and also the Lagos state government secondary school, Oto/ijanikin[4]

targets.targetText: Ijanikin jẹ ile si ọpọlọpọ awọn ile-ẹkọ ẹkọ olokiki pẹlu College obirin ti ijoba apapo ti ilu Eko, Oto/Ijanikin ati tun ile-iwe girama ijọba ipinlẹ Eko, Oto/ijanikin [1]
Ijanikin jẹ ile si ọpọlọpọ awọn ile-ẹkọ ẹkọ olokiki pẹlu Federal Government College Lagos, Oto/Ijanikin ati tun ile-iwe girama ijọba ipinlẹ Eko, Oto/ijanikin [1]

items.sourceText: Frank Edwards (nicknamed Frankrichboy) is a member of Christ Embassy Church in Nigeria and LoveWorld Music Ministry alongside other gospel musicians including Moses Bliss, Ada Ehi (gospel musician), Sinach, Eben, Joe Praize.[1]

targets.targetText: Frank Edwards (ti a npè ni Frankrichboy) jẹ ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti Christ Embassy Church ni Nigeria ati LoveWorld Ijoba Orinpapọ pẹlu awọn akọrin ihinrere miiran pẹlu Moses Bliss, Ada Ehi (orinrin ihinrere), Sinach, Eben, Joe Praize . [1]

Frank Edwards (ti a npè ni Frankrichboy) jẹ ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti Christ Embassy Church ni Nigeria ati LoveWorld Music Ministry papọ pẹlu awọn akọrin ihinrere miiran pẹlu Moses Bliss, Ada Ehi (orinrin ihinrere), Sinach, Eben, Joe Praize . [1]

items.sourceText: Obadare was born in Ilesa, now part of Osun State, southwestern Nigeria, to David and Felicia Obadare, a pastor and petty trader, respectively.[1] The majority of documents date Obadare's birth to 1930.[3]

targets.targetText: Ọbadare ni a bi ni Ileṣa, báyìí apakan ti Ipinle Osun, guusu iwọ-oorun ￼￼ Nàìjíríà David ati Felicia Ọbadare, olùsọ agutan ati oniṣowo kekere, lẹsẹsẹ. [1] Pupọ julọ awọn iwe aṣẹ ni ọjọ ibi Ọbadare si ọdun 1930. [1]

Obadare ni a bi ni Ilesa, bayi apakan ti Ipinle Osun, guusu iwọ-oorun Naijiria, David ati Felicia Obadare, olusoagutan ati oniṣowo kekere, lẹsẹsẹ. [1] Pupọ julọ awọn iwe aṣẹ ni ọjọ ibi Ọbadare si ọdun 1930. [1]

items.sourceText: Chineze Anyaene was born and raised in Abuja, Nigeria, West Africa. She obtained her B. A in Theatre Art from the prestigious University of Abuja, Nigeria. In 2005, she moved to the United States where she obtained a master's degree in Directing at the New York Film Academy (NYFA). She married Mr. Chibuzor Abonyi in 2017.[1]

targets.targetText: Chineze Anyaene ni won bi ati dagba ni Abuja, Nigeria, West Africa. O gba B. A ni Iṣẹ iṣe tiata ni Fasiti olokiki ti Abuja, Nigeria. Ni ọdun 2005, o gbe lọ si Amẹrika nibiti o ti gba oye titunto si ni Itọsọna ni New York Film Academy (NYFA). Ó fẹ́ ọ̀gbẹ́ni Chibuzor Abonyi ní ọdún 2017. [1]

Chineze Anyaene ni won bi ati dagba ni Abuja, Nigeria, West Africa. O gba B. A ni Iṣẹ iṣe tiata ni Fasiti olokiki ti Abuja, Nigeria. Ni ọdun 2005, o gbe lọ si Amẹrika nibiti o ti gba oye titunto si ni Itọsọna ni 2017.[1] (NYFA). Ó fẹ́ ọ̀gbẹ́ni Chibuzor Abonyi ní ọdún 2017. [2][3]

items.sourceText: Looking for Oum Kulthum is a 2017 internationally co-produced drama film about the Egyptian diva Umm Kulthum, directed by Shirin Neshat in collaboration with Shoja Azari. It was screened in the Contemporary World Cinema section at the 2017 Toronto International Film Festival.[1]

targets.targetText: Wiwa fun Oum Kulthum jẹ fiimu ere-idaraya ti kariaye 2017 ti o ṣe agbejade agbaye nipa diva Egypt Umm Kulthum, ti a ṣe itọsọna nipasẹ Shirin Neshat ni ifowosowopo pẹlu Shoja Azari. O ti ṣe ayẹwo ni apakan Cinema World Contemporary ni 2017 Toronto International Film Festival . [1]

Wiwa fun Oum Kulthum jẹ fiimu ere-idaraya ti kariaye ti kariaye 2017 nipa diva Egypt Umm Kulthum, ti a ṣe itọsọna nipasẹ Shirin Neshat ni ifowosowopo pẹlu Shoja Azari. O ti ṣe ayẹwo ni apakan Cinema World Contemporary ni 2017 Toronto International Film Festival.

items.sourceText: The film was shot in the Free State with an international crew hailing from South Africa, Greece, Poland and France.[7]

targets.targetText: A ya fiimu naa ni Ipinle Ọfẹ pẹlu awọn atukọ agbaye ti o wa lati South Africa, Greece, Polandii ati France. [1]
A ya fiimu naa ni Ipinle Ọfẹ pẹlu awọn alabase agbaye ti o wa lati South Africa, Greece, Polandii ati France.[1]

items.sourceText: She is a member of professional bodies such as the Nigerian Library Association, International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions and International Association of School Libraries among others.[11]

targets.targetText: O Je omo egbe alamọdaju tii egbẹ Ile-ikawe Naijiria, International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions ati International Association of School Libraries laarin awọn miiran. [1]

O jẹ ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti awọn ẹgbẹ alamọdaju bii Ẹgbẹ Ile-ikawe Naijiria, International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions ati International Association of School Libraries laarin awọn miiran. [1]

items.sourceText: Ouadahi's works are included in the publication collections of Barjeel Art Foundation (Sharjah, UAE), FRAC Centre (Orléans, France), Herbert-Weisenburger-Stiftung (Rastatt, Germany), Kamel Lazaar Foundation (Geneva, Switzerland), Kunstmuseum Düsseldorf (Germany), Nadour Collection (Germany), Stadtsparkasses Baden-Baden (Germany)[citation needed]

items.sourceText: Mohammed Racim (Arabic: محمد راسم, 24 June 1896 – 30 March 1975) was an Algerian artist who founded the Algerian School for Miniature Painting with his brother, Omar. It still exists to this day.[1]

targets.targetText: Mohammed Racim ( Arabic </link> Ọdun 24, Ọdun 1896 – 30 Oṣu Kẹta Ọdun 1975) jẹ oṣere ara ilu Algeria kan ti o da Ile-iwe Algerian fun Kikun Kekere pẹlu arakunrin rẹ, Omar . O tun wa titi di oni. [1]

Mohammed Racim ( Arabic </link> Ọdun 24, Ọdun 1896 – 30 Oṣu Kẹta Ọdun 1975) jẹ oṣere ara ilu Algeria kan ti oruko idile da Ile-iwe Algerian fun Kikun Kekere pẹlu arakunrin rẹ, Omar . O tun wa titi di oni. [1]

items.sourceText: Yellès was born in Tlemcen on 12 September 1921.[1] He studied at the School of Fine Arts in Algiers, then the Ecole de Beaux-Arts in Paris. He served as a director of the École supérieur des Beaux Arts d'Alger of Algiers,[2] between the years 1960 and 1980.[3] In his works, he continued using local themes but also experimented with Cubism, Expressionism, and Fauvism.[1] Yellès turned 100 in September 2021.[4] He died in Algiers on 16 August 2022.[5]

targets.targetText: Yellès ni a bi ni Tlemcen ni ọjọ 12 Oṣu Kẹsan ọdun 1921. [1] O kọ ẹkọ ni Ile-iwe ti Fine Arts ni Algiers, lẹhinna Ecole de Beaux-Arts ni Ilu Paris. O ṣiṣẹ bi oludari ti École supérieur des Beaux Arts d'Alger ti Algiers, [2] laarin awọn ọdun 1960 ati 1980. [3] Ninu awọn iṣẹ rẹ, o tẹsiwaju lilo awọn akori agbegbe ṣugbọn tun ṣe idanwo pẹlu Cubism, Expressionism, ati Fauvism . [1] Yellès di ẹni 100 ni Oṣu Kẹsan ọdun 2021. [4] O ku ni Algiers ni ọjọ 16 Oṣu Kẹjọ ọdun 2022. [5]

Yellès ni a bi ni Tlemcen ni ọjọ 12 Oṣu Kẹsan ọdun 1921. [1] O kọ ẹkọ ni Ile-iwe ti Fine Arts ni Algiers, lẹhinna Ecole de Beaux-Arts ni Ilu Paris. O ṣiṣẹ bi oludari ti École supérieur des Beaux Arts d'Alger ti Algiers, [2] láàrin àwon orílè-èdè pèlú awọn ọdun 1960 ati 1980. [3] Ninu awọn iṣẹ rẹ, o tẹsiwaju lilo awọn akori àwọn é agbegbe ṣugbọn tun ṣe idanwo pẹlu Cubism, Expressionism, ati Fauvism . [1] Yellès di ẹni 100 ni Oṣu Kẹsan ọdun 2021. [4] O ku ni Algiers ni ọjọ 16 Oṣu Kẹjọ ọdun 2022. [5]

items.sourceText: Belbahar was born in Blida, Algeria, in 1934.[2][1][3] A self-taught artist,[2] she held her first exhibition in 1971, at the age of 37.[3] Since that time, she has participated in numerous solo and group exhibitions in Algiers.[2] The Algerian Cultural Centre in Paris hosted a solo exhibition of Belbahar's works in 1986.[4]

targets.targetText: Belbahar ni a bi ni Blida, Algeria, ni ọdun 1934. [1] [2] [3] Oṣere ti o kọ ara rẹ, [1] o ṣe ifihan akọkọ rẹ ni ọdun 1971, ni ọmọ ọdun 37. [3] Lati akoko yẹn, o ti kopa ninu ọpọlọpọ adashe ati awọn ifihan ẹgbẹ ni Algiers . [1] Ile-iṣẹ Asa Ilu Algeria ni Ilu Paris gbalejo iṣafihan adashe ti awọn iṣẹ Belbahar ni ọdun 1986. [4]

Belbahar ni a bi ni Blida, Algeria, ni ọdun 1934. [1] [2] [3] Oṣere ti o kọ ara rẹ, [1] o ṣe ifihan akọkọ rẹ ni ọdun 1971, ni ọmọ ọdun 37. [3] Lati akoko yẹn, o ti kopa ninu idije enimeji pelu àwọn ọpọlọpọ adashe ati awọn ifihan ẹgbẹ ni Algiers . [1] Ile-iṣẹ Asa Ilu Algeria ni Ilu Paris gbalejo iṣafihan adashe ti awọn iṣẹ Belbahar ni ọdun 1986. [4]

items.sourceText: Rabah Driassa (19 August 1934 – 8 October 2021[2]) was an Algerian painter[3] and singer interpreting folk music. He was mostly active between the 1950s through 1980s where a number of his songs ("Hizia", "Nejma Qotbia", "El Goumri") became national hits in Algeria.[4]

targets.targetText: Rabah Driassa (19 Oṣu Kẹjọ 1934 - 8 Oṣu Kẹwa Ọdun 2021 [1] ) jẹ oluyaworan ara ilu Algeria [2] ati akọrin ti n tumọ orin eniyan. O ṣe pupọ julọ laarin awọn ọdun 1950 si awọn ọdun 1980 nibiti nọmba awọn orin rẹ ("Hizia", "Nejma Qotbia", "El Goumri") ti di olokiki orilẹ-ede ni Algeria. [3]

Rabah Driassa (19 Oṣu Kẹjọ 1934 - 8 Oṣu Kẹwa Ọdun 2021 [1] ) jẹ oluyaworan ara ilu Algeria [2] ati akọrin ti n tumọ orin eniyan. O ṣe pupọ julọ laarin awọn ọdun 1950 si awọn ọdun 1980 nibiti nọmba laini ọmọ ẹyìn awọn orin rẹ ("Hizia", "Nejma Qotbia", "El Goumri") ti di olokiki orilẹ-ede ni Algeria. [3]

items.sourceText: He returned to Algeria after Independence[clarification needed] in August 1962, and settled in the district of Pointe-Pescade (Raïs Hamidou) in Algiers, and opened his painting studio in the vicinity of the accommodation of the poet Jean Sénac who met him in 1963.[4]

targets.targetText: O pada si Algeria lẹhin Ominira  ni Oṣu Kẹjọ ọdun 1962, o si gbe ni agbegbe Pointe-Pescade ( Raïs Hamidou ) ni Algiers, o si ṣii ile òṣèré Obìnrin tódárajùlọ ni aworan rẹ ni agbegbe ibugbe ti Akewi Jean Sénac ti o pade rẹ ni ọdun 1963. [1]

O pada si Algeria lẹhin Ominira  ni Oṣu Kẹjọ ọdun 1962, o si gbe ni agbegbe Pointe-Pescade ( Raïs Hamidou ) ni Algiers, o si ṣii ile iṣere aworan rẹ ni agbegbe ibugbe ti Akewi Jean Sénac ti o pade rẹ ni ọdun 1963. [1]

items.sourceText: Adamu was born in Adamawa. In 1987, he graduated from Government Secondary School, Yola, Adamawa state, with a West African School Certificate. He graduated with a B.Tech in Geology in 1992 from Federal University Of Technology Yola.[4]

targets.targetText: Ilu Adamawa ni won bi Adamu. Ni 1987, o pari ile-iwe giga ti ijọba, Yola, ipinle Adamawa, pẹlu iwe-ẹri ile-iwe Iwọ-oorun Afirika. O gboye gboye pelu B.Tech ni Geology ni 1992 lati Federal University Of Technology Yola. [1]

Ìlú Adamawa ni wón bi Adamu si Ni ọdun 1987, o pari ile-iwe gíga ti ijọba, Yola, ipinlẹ Adamawa, pẹlu iwe-ẹri ile-iwe Iwọ-oorun Afirika. O gboye gboyè pelu B.Tech ni Geology ni ọdún 1992 lati Federal University Of Technology Yola. [1]

items.sourceText: Ihedioha is also known for embarking on widespread infrastructural projects, proactive lawmaking, and proposing and enacting/signing 17 laws, within his short period as Governor.[25]

targets.targetText: Ihedioha tun jẹ olókìkí fun gbigbe awọn iṣẹ akanṣe ti o gbòòrò, ṣiṣe ofin imuduro, ati igbero ati ṣiṣe / fowo si awọn ofin 17, láàrin akoko kúkúrú rẹ bi Gomina. [1]
Ihedioha tun jẹ olokiki fun gbigbe awọn iṣẹ akanṣe ti o gbooro, ṣiṣe ofin imuduro, ati igbero ati ṣiṣe / fowo si awọn ofin 17, laarin akoko kukuru rẹ bi Gomina. [1]

items.sourceText: Balarabe was born into the family of Alhaji Abubakar Balarabe in Sanga local government area of Kaduna state. She attended Girls College Soba for her secondary education and obtain her General Certificate of Education (GCE) in 1982,[1] She then got admission into the prestigious University of Maiduguri to study medicine and graduated with MBBS in 1986.[11]

targets.targetText: A bi Balarabe ninu ìdílé Alhaji Abubakar Balarabe ni ìjọba ìbílè Sanga ni ìpínlè Kaduna . O lọ si Girls College Soba fun eto ẹkọ gírámà rẹ o si gba Iwe-ẹri Gbogbogboo ti Ẹkọ (GCE) ni ọdun 1982, [1] Lẹhinna o gba wọle si Ile-ẹkọ giga olokiki ti Maiduguri lati kàwé nípa oògùn o pari pẹlu gbà iwe-ẹri MBBS ni ọdun 1986. [2]

A bi Balarabe ninu idile Alhaji Abubakar Balarabe ni ijoba ibile Sanga ni ipinle Kaduna . O lọ si Girls College Soba fun eto ẹkọ girama rẹ o si gba Iwe-ẹri Gbogbogbo ti Ẹkọ (GCE) ni ọdun 1982, [1] Lẹhinna o gba wọle si Ile-ẹkọ giga olokiki ti Maiduguri lati kawe oogun ati pari pẹlu MBBS ni ọdun 1986. [2]

items.sourceText: Gay is a term that primarily refers to a homosexual person or the trait of being homosexual. The term was originally used to mean "carefree", "cheerful", or "bright and showy".[1]

targets.targetText: Onibaje jẹ ọrọ kan ti o ni akọkọ ntokasi si ọkunrin kan ti o ni ipalara tabi awọn iwa ti jijọpọ. Oro naa ti a lo lati tumọ si "ailewu", "cheerful", tabi "imọlẹ ati showy". [1]
Gay jẹ ọrọ kan ti o ni akọkọ ntokasi si ọkunrin kan ti o ni ipalara tabi awọn iwa ti jijọpọ. Oro naa ti a lo lati tumọ si "ailewu", tabi "imọlẹ. [1]

items.sourceText: Islam Bibi (Pashto: د اسلام چاچی‎; 1974 – 4 July 2013) was a female police officer in Afghanistan in the Helmand province Headquarters and also a pioneer in the fight for feminism[1].

targets.targetText: Islam Bibi ( Pashto ; Ni ọdun 1974 - 4 Oṣu Karun ọdun 2013) jẹ ọlọpa obinrin kan ni Afiganisitani ni ati pe o tun jẹ aṣáájú-ọnà ninu ija fun abo [1] .
Islam Bibi ( Pashto ; Ni ọdun 1974 - 4 Oṣu Karun ọdun 2013) jẹ ọlọpa obinrin ọlọpa kan ni Afiganisitani ni olu-ilu ti Helmand ati pe o tun jẹ aṣáájú-ọnà ninu ija fun abo [1] .

items.sourceText: Mercy Aigbe (born 1 January 1978) is a Nigerian actress, director and businesswoman. She is best known for her Yoruba indigenous movies.[1][2]

targets.targetText: Mercy Aigbe (ojo akoko osu kinni odun 1978) je oserebirin ara Nigeria, oludari ati obinrin onitowo . Oje gbajumo fun awọn fiimu abinibi abinibi rẹ . [1] [2]
Mercy Aigbe (ojoibi 1 osu kinni odun 1978) je oserebirin ara Nigeria, oludari ati obinrin onitowo . O mọ julọ fun awọn fiimu abinibi abinibi rẹ . [1] [2]

items.sourceText: AGSOBA is an association of old students (boys and girls) of Abeokuta Grammar School and is the oldest students association in Nigeria. Headed by a national body known as the Central Executive Committee with its headquarters in Abeokuta, the association operates through branches all over Nigeria and the world.

targets.targetText: AGSOBA jẹ ajọṣepọ ti awọn ọmọ ile-iwe arugbo (ọmọkunrin ati ọmọdebinrin) ti Ile-iwe Girama Abeokuta ati pe o jẹ ẹgbẹ awọn ọmọ ile-iwe ti o dagba julọ ni Nigeria. Ti o jẹ olori nipasẹ ẹgbẹ ti orilẹ-ede ti a mọ ni Igbimọ Alakoso Central pẹlu olu-ilu rẹ ni Abeokuta, ajọṣepọ naa n ṣiṣẹ nipasẹ awọn ẹka ni gbogbo orilẹ-ede Naijiria ati ni agbaye.

AGSOBA jẹ ajọṣepọ ti awọn ọmọ ile-eko arugbo (ọmọkunrin ati ọmọdebinrin) ti Ile-iwe Girama Abeokuta ati pe o jẹ ẹgbẹ awọn ọmọ ile-iwe ti o dagba julọ ni Nàìjíríà Ti o jẹ olori nipasẹ ẹgbẹ ti orilẹ-ede ti a mọ ni Igbimọ Alakos gbogbogboo pẹlu olu-ilu rẹ ni Abeokuta, ajọṣepọ naa n ṣiṣẹ nipasẹ awọn ẹka ni gbogbo orilẹ-ede Naijiria ati ni agbaye.

items.sourceText: The Owa of Otan Ayegbaju is the title given to the ruler or king. The Owa of Otan Ayegbaju was the 26th child of Oduduwa. The town's government wasn't destroyed by inter-tribal wars. The current Owa is Lukman Adesola Ojo Fadipe Arenibiowo and Owa Olatanka III. They started ruling in June 2009.[citation needed]

targets.targetText: Owa ti Otan Ayegbaju ni oye Oba. Owa ti Otan Ayegbaju ni omo odun merindinlogbon ti Oduduwa. Ijọba ilu naa ko parun nipasẹ awọn ogun laarin ẹya. Owa lọwọlọwọ ni Lukman Adesola Ojo Fadipe Arenibiowo ati Owa Olatanka III. Wọn bẹrẹ ijọba ni oṣu kẹfa ọdun 2009.

Owa ti Otan Ayegbaju ni akole ti a fun olori tabi oba. Owa ti Otan Ayegbaju ni omo odun merindinlogbon ti Oduduwa. Ijọba ilu naa ko parun nipasẹ awọn ogun laarin ẹya. Owa lọwọlọwọ ni Lukman Adesola Ojo Fadipe Arenibiowo ati Owa Olatanka III. Wọn bẹrẹ ijọba ni oṣu kẹfa ọdun 2009.

items.sourceText: Muyei played from 2001 to 2003 for Sekondi Hasaacas F.C., in the past he played also for Kelantan FA (01.07.2003-01.01.2005) and later for Stade Malien (Bamako, Mali).[1]

targets.targetText: Muyei ṣere lati 2001 si 2003 fun Sekondi Hasaacas FC, ni iṣaaju o tun ṣe bọọlu fun Kelantan FA (01.07.2003-01.01.2005) ati nigbamii fun Stade Malien ( Bamako, Mali ). [1]
Muyei gba bọọlu lati ọdun 2001 si ọdun 2003 fun Sekondi Hasaacas FC, ni iṣaaju o tun gba bọọlu fun Kelantan FA (01.07.2003-01.01.2005) ati ni ọjọ iwaju fun Stade Malien ( Bamako, Mali ). [1]

items.sourceText: Adebayor Zakari Adje (born 12 November 1996) is a Nigerien professional footballer who plays for Niger Premier League club USGN, on loan from Danish 1st Division club HB Køge.

targets.targetText: Adebayor Zakari Adje (ti a bi ni ọjọ kejila Oṣu kọkanla ọdun 1996) jẹ agbabọọlu ọmọ orilẹ-ede Niger ti o gba fun ẹgbẹ agbabọọlu Niger Premier League USGN, ti o wa la'win lati ọdọ Danish 1st Division club HB Køge .

Adebayor Zakari Adje (ti a bi 12 Oṣu kọkanla ọdun 1996) jẹ agbabọọlu alamọdaju ọmọ orilẹ-ede Niger ti o ṣere fun ẹgbẹ agbabọọlu Niger Premier League USGN, ni awin lati ọdọ Danish 1st Division club HB Køge .

items.sourceText: On 7 August 2017, after helping Virtus Francavilla Calcio reach the Lega Pro promotion play-offs, Nzola signed a four-year deal with Carpi F.C. 1909.[4]

targets.targetText: Ni ọjọ keje oṣu kejo odun 2017, lẹhin ti o ṣe iranlọwọ fun Virtus Francavilla Calcio de Lega Pro igbega play-offs, Nzola fowo si adehun ọdun mẹrin pẹlu Carpi FC 1909 . [1]
Lori 7 August 2017, lẹhin ti o ṣe iranlọwọ fun Virtus Francavilla Calcio de Lega Pro igbega play-offs, Nzola fowo si adehun ọdun mẹrin pẹlu Carpi FC 1909 . [1]

items.sourceText: Ikorodu Road is a major expressway connecting the Mainland of Lagos to Ikorodu. The road is designated as the A1 highway for its entire 24.5 kilometer length. For most of the Lagos portion, it is a four-lane expressway with two frontage roads parallel to the expressway. The expressway crosses other major expressways such as Apapa Oworonshoki Expressway and Lagos-Ibadan Expressway. The expressway also hosts many of the Lagos Metropolitan Area Transport Authority's bus rapid transit (BRT) stops all the way to Ikorodu

targets.targetText: Opopona Ikorodu jẹ ọna opopona pataki kan ti o so Ilu Mainland ti Ilu Eko si Ikorodu . Ọna naa jẹ apẹrẹ bi opopona A1 fun gbogbo ipari gigun kilomita 24.5 rẹ. Fun pupọ julọ apakan Eko, o jẹ ọna opopona mẹrin ti o ni awọn ọna iwaju meji ti o jọra si ọna kiakia. Opopona kiakia naa kọja awọn ọna nla miiran bii Apapa Oworonshoki Expressway ati Lagos-Ibadan Expressway . Opopona kiakia tun gba ọpọlọpọ awọn ti Lagos Metropolitan Area Transport Authority 's akero kiakia irekọja (BRT) duro titi di Ikorodu.

Opopona Ikorodu jẹ ọna opopona pataki kan ti o so Ilu Mainland ti Ilu Eko si Ikorodu . Ọna naa jẹ apẹrẹ bi opopona A1 fun gbogbo ipari gigun kilomita 24.5 . Fun pupọ julọ apakan Eko, o jẹ ọna opopona mẹrin ti o ni awọn ọna iwaju meji ti o jọra si ọna kiakia. Opopona kiakia naa kọja awọn ọna nla miiran bii Apapa Oworonshoki Expressway ati Lagos-Ibadan Expressway . Opopona kiakia tun gba ọpọlọpọ awọn ti Lagos Metropolitan Area Transport Authority 's akero kiakia irekọja (BRT) fi ipin si gbo gbo opopona to ja si Ikorodu.

items.sourceText: The Lagos Stadium is home to Nigeria Women Premier League club DreamStar F.C. Ladies, and Nigeria Premier League Club MFM, who represented the country at the 2017 CAF Champion League, along with Plateau United.[3]

targets.targetText: Papa papa iṣere Lagos jẹ ile fun ẹgbẹ agbabọọlu DreamStar FC Ladies Nigeria Women Premier League, ati Nigeria Premier League Club MFM, ti o ṣoju orilẹ-ede naa ni 2017 CAF Champion League, pẹlu Plateau United. [1]

Papa papa iṣere Lagos jẹ ile fun ẹgbẹ agbabọọlu DreamStar FC Ladies Nigeria Premier League ti obirin, ati egbe Nigeria Premier League MFM, ti o ṣoju orilẹ-ede naa ni 2017 CAF Champion League, pẹlu Plateau United. [1]

items.sourceText: Badagry Heritage Museum is a museum in Badagry, Nigeria that is housed in the District Officer's Office built in 1863 by the British colonial government.[1][2][3][4]

items.sourceText: The Lagos State university of Science and Technology ( formerly known as Lagos State Polytechnic) was established with the promulgation of Lagos State Edict No. 1 of 1978 with retroactive effect from June 1, 1977. The Institution commenced classes in January, 1978 at a temporary site (now the Isolo Campus) with five Departments namely, [[Accounting|Accountancy],Business administration,Banking and finance,Marketing and Insurance.

targets.targetText: Ile-ẹkọ giga ti Imọ ati Imọ-ẹrọ ti Ipinle Eko (eyiti a mọ si Lagos State Polytechnic tẹlẹ) jẹ idasile pẹlu ikede ofin Ipinle Eko No. Ile-ẹkọ naa bẹrẹ awọn kilasi ni Oṣu Kini, ọdun 1978 ni aaye igba diẹ (bayi Isolo Campus) pẹlu Ẹka marun ti o jẹ, [[Iṣiro|Aṣiro], Isakoso Iṣowo, Ile-ifowopamọ ati Isuna, Iṣowo ati Iṣeduro.

Ile-ẹkọ giga ti Imọ ati Imọ-ẹrọ ti Ipinle Eko (eyiti a mọ si Lagos State Polytechnic tẹlẹ) jẹ idasile pẹlu ikede ofin Ipinle Eko No. Ile-ẹkọ naa bẹrẹ awọn si ni keko ni Oṣu Kini, ọdun 1978 ni aaye igba diẹ (bayi Isolo Campus) pẹlu Ẹka marun ti o jẹ, [[Iṣiro|Aṣiro], Isakoso Iṣowo, Ile-ifowopamọ ati Isuna, Iṣowo ati Iṣeduro.

items.sourceText: Radio Continental started under the name Link FM with its first transmission in 102.3 FM in Lagos. After ten months it was rebranded Unity 102.3 FM, with focus on general entertainment, news and sports.[1]

items.sourceText: Nigeria Info is a network of talk radio stations in Nigeria, broadcasting on 99.3 MHz in Lagos, 95.1 MHz in Abuja, and 92.3 MHz in Port Harcourt. Owned by Info FM Nigeria Limited, the stations broadcast local and international news with a blend of talk and sports shows, while addressing current affairs and topical issues in Nigeria.

targets.targetText: Alaye Naijiria jẹ nẹtiwọọki ti awọn ile-iṣẹ radio igbe ohun safefe ni Nigeria, ti n tan kaakiri lori 99.3 MHz ni Eko, 95.1 MHz ni Abuja, ati 92.3 MHz ni Port Harcourt . Ohun ini nipasẹ Info FM Nigeria Limited, awọn ibudo naa ṣe ikede awọn iroyin agbegbe ati ti kariaye pẹlu idapọpọ ọrọ ati awọn ere idaraya, lakoko ti o n sọrọ awọn ọran lọwọlọwọ ati awọn ọran agbegbe ni Nigeria.

items.sourceText: In January 2012, journalist Enenche Akogwu, who worked as a correspondent in Kano for Channels Television, was shot and killed while reporting on coordinated attacks there claimed by the radical Islamist sect known as Boko Haram. According to his colleagues, Akogwu had shown up after a bombing and began filming a crowd gathered there without knowing they were armed sect members.[8]

targets.targetText: Ni osu sere ti o je osu kini ni odun 2012, onise iroyin Enenche Akogwu, ti o ṣiṣẹ gẹgẹbi oniroyin ni Kano fun Channels Television, ni a yinbọn ati pa lakoko ti o n ṣe iroyin lori awọn ikọlu iṣọpọ nibe ti ẹgbẹ Islamist ti o ni agbara ti a mọ si Boko Haram sọ. Gege bi oro awon akegbe re, Akogwu ti farahan leyin ti bombu kan se, o si bere si ni ya aworan fawon eeyan ti won pejo sibe lai mo pe omo egbe eleto ni won ni ihamọra. [1]

items.sourceText: In 2013, about 21 million people consisting of indigenes and non-indigenes attended the festival. items.sourceText: The Lagos State Fire Service was established on August 31, 1972, with an Expatriate Chief Fire Officer, Sir Allan Flemming, as the first Chief Fire Officer with a three-man crew.

items.sourceText: David Adedeji Adeleke was born on 21 November 1992, in Atlanta, Georgia. His father Adedeji Adeleke is a business magnate and his mother Vero Adeleke was a university lecturer.[1] Davido is the youngest of five siblings and his father's second-born son.[2][3] He attended the British International School in Lagos, Nigeria, and at the age of 16, he moved back to the United States to study business administration at Oakwood University in Alabama.[2][4]

targets.targetText: David Adedeji Adeleke ni a bi ni 21 Oṣu kọkanla ọdun 1992, ni Atlanta, Georgia . Baba rẹ Adedeji Adeleke jẹ oga iṣowo ati iya rẹ Vero Adeleke jẹ olukọni yunifasiti . [1] Davido jẹ abikẹhin ninu awọn aburo marun ati ọmọ keji ti baba rẹ. [2] [3] O lọ si ile -iwe International International British ni Lagos, Nigeria, ati ni ọmọ ọdun 16, o tun pada si Amẹrika lati kọ ẹkọ iṣakoso iṣowo ni Oakwood University ni Alabama . [2] [4]

items.sourceText: The pearls are known as sābudānā in the Indian subcontinent; they are used for sweet and savory dishes, such as sabudana khichri. In Brazil, the pearls are cooked with wine or other liquid to add flavor and are called sagu.

targets.targetText: Awọn pearl ni a mọ si sābudānā ni agbegbe India ; wọn lo fun awọn ounjẹ ti o dun ati ti o dun, gẹgẹbi sabudana khichri . Ni Ilu Brazil, awọn okuta iyebiye ti wa ni jinna pẹlu ọti-waini tabi omi miiran lati ṣafikun adun ati pe wọn pe ni sagu .

Àwọn òkúta Iyebiye ni a mọ̀ sí sābudānā ní agbegbe India ; wọn lo fún àwọn oúnjẹ tí o dun àti tí o dun, gẹgẹ bí sabudana khichri . Ní Ilu Brazil, àwọn òkúta iyebiye tí wà ní jìnnà pẹlu ọti-waini tabi omi miiran lati ṣafikun adun ati pe wọn pe ni sagu .

items.sourceText: Getaneh Kebede Gebeto (Amharic: ጌታነህ ከበደ; born 2 April 1992) is an Ethiopian professional footballer who plays as a striker for Ethiopian Premier League club Wolkite City.

items.sourceText: George Edozie was born on 11 May 1972. He attended the University Primary School, Nsukka, Washington Memorial School, Onitsha. Edozie studied Fine & Applied Arts at the University of Benin in Benin City where he majored in painting and graduated with a BA degree in 1996.[1]

items.sourceText: Sayyid Mumtaz Ali was born on 27 September 1860 in Deoband, British India.[2] He was a fellow and contemporary of Mahmud Hasan Deobandi and studied at Darul Uloom Deoband with Muhammad Yaqub Nanautawi and Muhammad Qasim Nanautawi.[3]

targets.targetText: Sayyid Mumtaz Ali ni a bi ni ọjọ 27 Oṣu Kẹsan ọdun 1860 ni Deoband, Ilu Gẹẹsi India . [1] O jẹ ẹlẹgbẹ ati asiko ti Mahmud Hasan Deobandi o si kọ ẹkọ ni Darul Uloom Deoband pẹlu Muhammad Yaqub Nanautawi ati Muhammad Qasim Nanautawi . [2]

Wọ́n bí Sayyid Mumtaz Ali bi ni ọjọ ketadinlogbon Oṣu Kẹsan, ọdun 1860 ni Deoband, Ilu Gẹẹsi India . [1] O jẹ ẹlẹgbẹ ati asiko ti Mahmud Hasan Deobandi o si kọ ẹkọ ni Darul Uloom Deoband pẹlu Muhammad Yaqub Nanautawi ati Muhammad Qasim Nanautawi . [2]

items.sourceText: Guido Borelli da Caluso is an Italian painter. He was born in Caluso in 1952. He comes from an artistic background, and his family always encouraged him to develop his talent, as early as childhood. He won a contest at 13 and held his first exhibition at the age of 17 at Ars Plauda Gallery in Turin. After high school, he received his artistic training at the Accademia Albertina in Turin. Today, he has permanent exhibitions in art galleries, in Italy, France, the United Kingdom and in the U.S.

targets.targetText: Guido Borelli da Caluso jẹ oluyaworan Ilu Italia. A bi ni Caliso ni ọdun 1952. O wa lati ipilẹṣẹ iṣẹ ọna, ati pe ẹbi rẹ nigbagbogbo gba ọ niyanju lati ṣe idagbasoke talenti rẹ, ni kutukutu bi igba ewe. O ṣẹgun idije kan ni ọdun metala o si ṣe ifihan akọkọ rẹ ni ọjọ-ori ọdun metadinlogun ni Ars Plauda Galleri ni Turin . Lẹhin ile-iwe giga, o gba ikẹkọ iṣẹ ọna rẹ ni Accademia Albertina ni Turini. Loni, o ni awọn ifihan ti o yẹ ni awọn ibi aworan aworan, ni Ilu Italia, Faranse, Papọ Ijọba Gẹẹsi ati ni AMẸRIKA.

O ṣẹgun idije kan ni ọdun 13 o si ṣe ifihan akọkọ rẹ ni ọjọ-ori ọdun 17 ni Ars Plauda Gallery ni Turin . Lẹhin ile-iwe giga, o gba ikẹkọ iṣẹ ọna rẹ ni Accademia Albertina ni Turin. Loni, o ni awọn ifihan ti o yẹ ni awọn ibi aworan aworan, ni Ilu Italia, Faranse, United Kingdom ati ni AMẸRIKA

items.sourceText: Nkalagu is a town in Ishielu Local Government Area of Ebonyi State, Nigeria. It is notable for having a large deposit of limestone which provided the raw material for the large cement plant of the Nigerian Cement Company (Nigercem).[1] Nkalagu is the first town you will enter, when you are going into Ebonyi State through Enugu-Abakaliki express road. It is the headquarters of Ishielu West Development Centre[2] and has five major villages: Ishiagu, Uwule, Imeoha, Amanvu and Akiyi. The village head in Nkalagu is also known as Onyishi. Each village has its own Onyishi which must be the most eldest son of the town. The major market is Nkwo Nkalagu which is located along Enugu-Abakaliki Express road.

targets.targetText: Nkalagu je ilu ni ijoba ibile Ishielu ni ipinle Ebonyi ni orile-ede Naijiria . O jẹ ohun akiyesi fun nini ohun idogo nla ti limestone eyiti o pese ohun elo aise fun ile-iṣẹ simenti nla ti Ile-iṣẹ Simenti Naijiria (Nigercem). [1] Nkalagu ni ilu akọkọ ti iwọ yoo wọ, nigbati o ba lọ si Ipinle Ebonyi nipasẹ ọna opopona Enugu-Abakaliki. O jẹ olu ile-iṣẹ Ishielu West Development Centre [2] o si ni awọn abule pataki marun: Ishiagu, Uwule, Imeoha, Amanvu ati Akiyi. Olori abule ni Nkalagu tun mo si Onyishi . Abule kọọkan ni Onyishi tirẹ ti o gbọdọ jẹ akọbi julọ ni ilu naa. Ọja pataki ni Nkwo Nkalagu ti o wa ni ọna Enugu-Abakaliki Express.

Nkalagu se ilu niijoba ibile Ishielu ni ipinle Ebonyi ni orile-ede ￼￼Naijiria￼￼.O jẹohun akiyesi fun nini ohun idogo nlati limestone eyiti o pese ohun eloaise fun ile-iṣẹ simenti nla ti Ile-iṣẹ Simenti Naijiria (Nigercem). [1] Nkalagu ni ilu akọkọ ti iwọ yoowọ, nigbati o ba lọ si Ipinle Ebonyi nipasẹ ọna opopona Enugu-Abakaliki. O jẹ olu ile-iṣẹ Ishielu West Development Centre [2] o si ni awọn abule pataki marun: Ishiagu, Uwule, Imeoha, Amanvu ati Akiyi. Olori abule ni Nkalagu tun mo si Onyishi . Abule kọọkan ni Onyishi tirẹ ti o gbọdọ jẹ akọbi julọ ni ilu naa. Ọja pataki ni Nkwo Nkalagu ti o wa ni ọna Enugu-Abakaliki Express.

items.sourceText: Arisekola-Alao was married to and had children with multiple women.[1] His first wife, who was born in 1945, died in 2013.[4] Two weeks after Arisekola-Alao's death, another wife, Jelilat, died in early July 2014 following a car accident.[5][6]

targets.targetText: Arisekola-Alao ti ni iyawo ti o si bi ọmọ pẹlu ọpọlọpọ awọn obirin. Iyawo akọkọ, ti a bi ni 1945, ku ni 2013. Ni ọsẹ meji lẹhin iku Arisekola-Alao, iyawo miiran, Jelilat, ku ni ibẹrẹ Keje 2014 lẹhin ijamba ọkọ ayọkẹlẹ kan.

Arisekola-Alao ti ni iyawo o si bi ọmọ pẹlu ọpọlọpọ awọn obirin. [1] Iyawo akọkọ rẹ, ti a bi ni 1945, ku ni ọdun 2013. [2] Ni ọsẹ meji lẹhin iku Arisekola-Alao, iyawo miiran, Jelilat, ku ni ibẹrẹ Oṣu Keje ọdun 2014 lẹhin ijamba ọkọ ayọkẹlẹ kan. [3] [4]

items.sourceText: Chimezie Ikeazor was educated at Dennis Memorial Grammar School, Onitsha, Anambra State, proceeding subsequently to the University of London, where he obtained a Degree in Theology and subsequently read law at King's College London. He was called to the Bar at Lincoln's Inn London in 1960.

targets.targetText: Chimezie Ikeazor ti kọ ẹ̀kọ́ ni Dennis Memorial Grammar School, Onitsha, Ipinle Anambra, ti o tẹ̀lé lẹhìn náà sí University of London, níbití o ti gbà ìwé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga ni Theology ati lẹhinna ká òfin ní King's College London . O pẹ si Pẹpẹ nì Lincoln's Inn London ni ọdún 1960.

Chimezie Ikeazor ti kọ ẹkọ ni Dennis Memorial Grammar School, Onitsha, Ipinle Anambra, ti o tẹle lẹhin naa si University of London, nibiti o ti gba Iwe-ẹkọ giga ni Theology ati lẹhinna ka ofin ni King's College London . O pe si Pẹpẹ ni Lincoln's Inn London ni ọdun 1960.

items.sourceText: Bedrick was raised in a secular Jewish home in Windham, New Hampshire, and he became religiously observant over the course of many years. He attended Bishop Guertin High School in Nashua, New Hampshire, where he received the Religious Studies Award for "the student who best understands the Christian message presented in the classroom."[6]

targets.targetText: Bedrick ni a dagba ni ile Juu alailesin ni Windham, New Hampshire, o si di alakiyesi ẹsin ni ọpọlọpọ ọdun. O lọ si Ile-iwe giga Bishop Guertin ni Nashua, New Hampshire, nibi ti o ti gba Aami Eye Awọn Ẹkọ Ẹsin fun "ọmọ-iwe ti o ni oye ti o dara julọ ifiranṣẹ Kristiẹni ti a gbekalẹ ni ile-iwe." [1]

Bedrick ni a da lágbà ní ilé Juu alailesin ni Windham, New Hampshire, o si di alakiyesi ẹsin ni ọpọlọpọ ọdun. O lọ si Ile-iwe giga Bishop Guertin ni Nashua, New Hampshire, nibi ti o ti gba Aami Eye Awọn Ẹkọ Ẹsin fun "ọmọ-iwe ti o ni oye ti o dara julọ ifiranṣẹ Kristiẹni ti a gbé kalè̩ ni yàrá ìkàwé." [1]

items.sourceText: Zaphaniah Bitrus Jisalo was born on 3 April 1970 in Abuja. He hails from Garki Village in Suleja/Abuja Municipal Council.[1][2]

targets.targetText: Ojo keta osu kerin odun 1970 ni won bi Zaphaniah Bitrus Jisalo ni ilu Abuja. O wa lati Abule Garki ni Suleja/Abuja Municipal Council. [1] [2]
