items.sourceText: In 2019, he was elected as a member representing Ohaukwu/Ebonyi Federal Constituency.[1] Ahead of the 2023 gubernatorial elections, Chukwuma picked the party form alongside his older brother, Dr. Augustine Nwazunku, both under the platform of the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP).[2] He served as Speaker, Ebonyi State House of Assembly, and faced impeachment twice.[1][3]

targets.targetText: Ni ọdun 2019, o jẹ ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti o nsoju agbegbe Ohaukwu/Ebonyi Federal Constituency. [1] Ṣaaju idibo gomina ni ọdun 2023, Chukwuma yan fọọmu ẹgbẹ pẹlu ẹgbọn rẹ, Dokita Augustine Nwazunku, awọn mejeeji labẹ ipilẹ ti Peoples Democratic Party (PDP). [2] O ṣiṣẹ gẹgẹbi Agbọrọsọ, Ile-igbimọ Aṣofin Ipinle Ebonyi, o si koju ikọsilẹ lẹẹmeji. [1] [3]

Ni ọdun 2019, o jẹ ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti o nsoju agbegbe Ohaukwu/Ebonyi [1] Ṣaaju ìdìbò gómìnà ni ọdun 2023, Chukwuma yan fọọmu ẹgbẹ pẹlu ẹgbọn rẹ, Dokita Augustine Nwazunku, awọn mejeeji labẹ ipilẹ ti Peoples Democratic Party (PDP). [2] O ṣiṣẹ gẹgẹbi Agbọrọsọ, Ile-igbimọ Aṣofin Ipinle Ebonyi, o si koju ikọsilẹ lẹẹmeji. [1] [3]

items.sourceText: Edward studied law at the University of Jos and later completed his studies at the Nigerian Law School in Lagos.[3] He served as Plateau State’s Attorney General and Commissioner for Justice from 2007 to 2011.[4][5]

targets.targetText: Edward kọ ẹkọ nipa ofin ni Yunifasiti ti Jos o si pari ẹkọ rẹ ni ile-ẹkọ ofin ti Naijiria ni Lagos. [1] O ṣiṣẹ bi Attorney General ti Ipinle Plateau ati Komisona fun Idajọ lati 2007 si 2011. [2] [3]

Edward kọ ẹkọ nípa ofin ni Yunifasiti ti Jos o si pari ẹkọ rẹ ni ile-ẹkọ ofin ti Naijiria ni Lagos. [1] O ṣiṣẹ bi adájọ́ àgbà ti Ipinle Plateau ati Komisona fún ètò Idajọ lati ọdún 2007 si ọdun 2011. [2] [3]

items.sourceText: Abdulganiyu Saka Cook Olododo (born 25 December 1960) is a Nigerian politician who serves as a member of the House of Representatives representing Ilorin East/Ilorin South federal constituency under the platform of the All Progressives Congress (APC) from 2019 to 2023.[1][2]

targets.targetText: Abdulganiyu Saka Cook Olododo (ojoibi 25 December 1960) je oloselu omo orile- ede Naijiria to n sise gege bi omo ile igbimo asoju-sofin to n soju ipinle Ilorin East / Ilori South South labe egbe oselu All Progressives Congress (APC) lati 2019 si 2023. [1] [2]

Abdulganiyu Saka Cook Olododo (ojoibi 25 December 1960) je olóṣèlú ọmọ orilẹ-ede Nàìjíríà to n ṣiṣẹ gẹgẹbi ọmọ ile ìgbìmọ̀ asoju-sofin to n sójú ìpínlè Ilorin East / Ilori South South labẹ ẹgbẹ́ òsèlú All Progressives Congress (APC) lati 2019 si 2023. [1] [2]

items.sourceText: Olododo is an entrepreneur, community leader, and politician. His father, Alhaji Sakariyah Cook, belonged to the prominent Amode family in the Okelele region of Ilorin.[1]

targets.targetText: Olododo is jẹ oníṣòwò olori agàgbègbèati olóṣèlú. Baba rẹ, Alhaji Sakariyah Cook, jẹ ti idile Amode ti o jẹ olokiki ni agbegbe Okelele ni Ilorin. [1]
Olododo is an entrepreneur, olori agbegbe, ati oloselu. Baba rẹ, Alhaji Sakariyah Cook, jẹ ti idile Amode ti o jẹ olokiki ni agbegbe Okelele ni Ilorin. [1]

items.sourceText: Babatunde was born on 12 August 1961 in Ilorin, Ilorin West Local Government area of Kwara State Nigeria she attended Oyun Baptist High School, Ijagbo in Oyun Local Government Area of Kwara State Nigeria and earned her West African School Certificate in 1981.[1]

targets.targetText: Won bi Babatunde ni ojo kejila osu kẹjọ ọdún 1961 ni ìlú Ilorin, ni ijoba ibile Ilorin West ni ipinle Kwara Nigeria o lo si ile iwe giga Oyun Baptist High School, Ijagbo ni ijoba ibile Oyun ni ipinle Kwara Nigeria o si gba iwe eri ile iwe West African School ni odun 1981. [1]

Won bi Babatunde ni ojo kejila osu kejo odun 1961 ni ilu Ilorin, ni ijoba ibile Ilorin West ni ipinle Kwara Nigeria o lo si ile iwe giga Oyun Baptist High School, Ijagbo ni ijoba ibile Oyun ni ipinle Kwara Nigeria o si gba iwe eri ile iwe West African School ni odun 1981. [1]

items.sourceText: Yusuf was born on 13 June 1982 in Offa, Offa Local Government area of Kwara State Nigeria. He studied Mechanical Engineering Technology (Automotive) at Kwara State Polytechnic where he earned his Higher National Diploma in 2005.[1]

targets.targetText: A bi Yusuf ni ojo 13 osu kefa odun 1982 ni Offa, agbegbe ijoba ibile Offa ni Ipinle Kwara Nigeria . O ka Mechanical Engineering Technology (Automotive) ni Kwara State Polytechnic nibi ti o ti gba Diploma Higher National ni 2005. [1]

A bi Yusuf ni ojo 13 osu kẹfà ọdún 1982 ni Offa, àgbègbè ìjọba ìbílè Offa ni Ìpínlè Kwara Nigeria . O ka Mechanical Engineering Technology (Automotive) ni Kwara State Polytechnic nibi ti o ti gba Diploma Higher National ni ọdun 2005. [1]

items.sourceText: Odetundun is an experienced Project Manager and expert in Tourism and Events Management. Before joining politics in 2015, he was an aspirant for the Kwara State House of Assembly member under the People's Democratic Party (Nigeria). He later joined the All Progressives Congress and won his seat at the state assembly in the 2023 general elections.[1][3]

targets.targetText: Odetundun jẹ oluṣakoso Iṣẹ ti o ni iriri ati alamọja ni Irin-ajo ati Iṣakoso Awọn iṣẹlẹ. Ṣaaju ki o to darapọ mọ oselu ni ọdun 2015, o jẹ oludije fun ọmọ ilé ìgbìmò aṣòfin ìpínlè Kwara labẹ egbe People's Democratic Party (Nigeria) . Lẹhinna o darapọ mọ All Progressive Congress o si gba ijoko rẹ ni apejọ ipinlẹ ni awọn idibo gbogbogbo 2023. [1] [2]

Odetundun jẹ oluṣakoso Iṣẹ ti o ni iriri ati alamọja ni Irin-ajo ati Isakoso Awọn iṣẹlẹ. Ṣaaju ki o to darapọ mọ oselu ni ọdun 2015, o jẹ oludije fun ọmọ ile-igbimọ aṣofin ipinle Kwara labẹ egbe People's Democratic Party (Nigeria) . Lẹhinna o darapọ mọ All Progressive Congress o si gba ijoko rẹ ni apejọ ipinlẹ ni awọn idibo gbogbogbo 2023. [1] [2]

items.sourceText: Olufemi Lanlehin was born into the Lanlehin family of Ibadan land. He had his secondary education at Ibadan Grammar School, Ibadan and Igbobi College, Yaba, Lagos.[5]

targets.targetText: Olufemi Lanlehin ni won bi si idile Lanlehin ti ilu Ibadan. O ti gba eko girama ni Ibadan Grammar School, Ibadan ati Igbobi College, Yaba, Lagos. [1]
Olufemi Lanlehin ni won bi si ìdílé Lanlehin ti ìlù Ìbàdàn. O ti gba eko gírámà ni Ibadan Grammar School, Ìbàdàn ati Igbobi College, Yaba, Lagos. [1]

items.sourceText: in the 1992 Nigerian parliamentary election, he was elected to the House of Representatives representing Ikeja constituency on the platform of the SDP in the Third Nigerian Republic.

targets.targetText: ninu idibo ile igbimo asofin Naijiria odun 1992, won dibo yan si ile igbimo asofin to n soju agbegbe Ikeja lori egbe SDP ni Orile-ede Naijiria Kẹta .
ninu ìdìbò ile ìgbìmọ̀ asofin Naijiria odun 1992, won dibo yan si ile igbimo asofin to n soju agbegbe Ikeja lori egbe SDP ni Orile-ede Nàìjíríà Kẹta .

items.sourceText: Mustapha won the PDP primary election with 257 votes, which makes him the official PDP candidate in the 2023 Nigerian general election.[4]

targets.targetText: Mustapha jawe olubori ninu idibo alaabẹrẹ ti PDP pẹlu ibo 257, eyi ti o mu ki o di oludije fun ẹgbẹ oṣelu PDP ninu idibo gbogboogbo Naijiria lọdun 2023. [1]
Mustapha jawe olubori ninú ìdìbò alaabẹrẹ ti PDP pẹlu ibo 257, eyi ti o mu ki o di oludije fun ẹgbẹ oṣelu PDP ninu idibo gbogbogbòò Nàìjíríà lọdun 2023.[1] [2]

items.sourceText: In 2015, she was elected to the Nigerian Senate to represent Anambra North Senatorial District.[5][6] She was one of the only seven women elected to the 8th. The others were Rose Okoji Oko, Uche Ekwunife, Fatimat Raji Rasaki, Oluremi Tinubu, Abiodun Olujimi and Binta Garba.[7] Oduah was re-elected to a second term in the Senate in 2019.[8][9] In 2022, she ran again under APC but lost to the incumbent Senator Tony Nwoye.

targets.targetText: Ni ọdun 2015, o ti dibo si Ile-igbimọ Alagba Naijiria lati ṣoju Anambra North. [1] [2] O jẹ ọkannínú àwọn obìnrin méje nìkan ti a yan si 8th. Awon to ku ni Rose Okoji Oko, Uche Ekwunife, Fatimat Raji Rasaki, Oluremi Tinubu, Abiodun Olujimi ati Binta Garba . [3] Oduah tun yan si saa keji ni Sẹnetọ ni ọdun 2019. [4] [5] Ni 2022, o tun dije labẹ APC ṣugbọn opàdánù lọwọ Sẹnetọ Tony Nwoye ti o wa ni ipo.

Ni ọdun 2015, o ti dibo si Ile-igbimọ Alagba Naijiria lati ṣoju Anambra North Senatorial District . [1] [2] O jẹ ọkan ninu awọn obinrin meje nikan ti a yan si 8th. Awon to ku ni Rose Okoji Oko, Uche Ekwunife, Fatimat Raji Rasaki, Oluremi Tinubu, Abiodun Olujimi ati Binta Garba . [3] Oduah tun yan si saa keji ni Sẹnetọ ni ọdun 2019. [4] [5] Ni 2022, o tun dije labẹ APC ṣugbọn o padanu lọwọ Sẹnetọ Tony Nwoye ti o wa ni ipo.

items.sourceText: On February 9, The Economic and Financial Crime Commission (EFCC) indicted Stella Oduah, and the Nigerian Subsidiary of Chinese Construction Giant, CCECC, in allege fraudulent cash transaction of about N5billion over five months in 2014.[13]

targets.targetText: Ni Oṣu Keji ọjọ 9, Igbimọ Ẹṣẹ Iṣowo ati Iṣowo (EFCC) fi ẹsun kan Stella Oduah, ati Ẹka Ilu Naijiria ti Giant Construction Giant, CCECC, ni ẹsun jibiti iṣowo owo ti o to N5billion ni oṣu márùn-ún ni ọdun 2014.

Ni Oṣu Keji ọjọ 9, Igbimọ Ẹṣẹ Iṣowo ati Iṣowo (EFCC) fi ẹsun kan Stella Oduah, ati Ẹka Ilu Naijiria ti Giant Construction Giant, CCECC, ni ẹsun jibiti iṣowo owo ti o to N5billion ni oṣu marun ni ọdun 2014. [1]

items.sourceText: Abiola Peter Makinde born (16 August 1973) is a financial management expert and politician. He is a member of Nigeria Federal House of Representatives holding assignment for  Ondo East/Ondo West federal constituency  of  Nigeria's western state of Ondo.[1]  In 2014, President Goodluck Jonathan appointed Makinde National Board Member of Nigeria Literacy Commission and was on the assignment until 2015 when President Jonathan and People's Democratic Party, PDP lost federal power to then opposition All Progressives Congress, APC.[2]

targets.targetText: Abiola Peter Makinde ti a bi (16 August 1973) jẹ amoye iṣakoso owo ati oloselu. Ó jẹ́ ọmọ ilé ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin ìjọba àpapọ̀ Nàìjíríà tí ó ń ṣe iṣẹ́ àyànfúnni fún ẹkùn ìdìbò àpapọ̀ ìpínlẹ̀ Ìlà Oòrùn Ìlà Oòrùn Ondo ní ìpínlẹ̀ ìwọ̀ oòrùn Nàìjíríà ti Ondo . [1] Ni ọdun 2014, Aare Goodluck Jonathan yan Makinde National Board Member of Nigeria Literacy Commission ati pe o wa lori iṣẹ naa titi di ọdun 2015 nigba ti Aare Jonathan ati People's Democratic Party, PDP padanu agbara ijọba apapo si alatako All Progressive Congress, APC. [2]

Abiola Peter Makinde ti a bi ni (16 August 1973) jẹ amoye ìṣàkóso òwò ati olóṣèlú. Ó jẹ́ ọmọ ilé ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin ìjọba àpapọ̀ Nàìjíríà tí ó ń ṣe iṣẹ́ àyànfúnni fún ẹkùn ìdìbò àpapọ̀ ìpínlẹ̀ Ìlà Oòrùn Ondo ní ìpínlẹ̀ ìwọ̀ oòrùn Nàìjíríà ti Ondo . [1] Ni ọdun 2014, Aare Goodluck Jonathan yan Makinde National Board Member of Nigeria Literacy Commission ati pe o wa lori iṣẹ naa titi di ọdun 2015 nígbà ti Ààrẹ Jonathan ati People's Democratic Party, PDP padanu àgbàrá ijọba àpapọ̀ si alatako All Progressive Congress, APC. [2]

items.sourceText: Mohammed Tahir Monguno was born on 12 February 1966. He had his primary education in Monguno Central Primary School and later attended Government Secondary School (GSS) Ngala, Borno State where he obtained his Senior School Certificate.[4] He studied law at the University of Maiduguri where he graduated in 1989. He attended Nigerian Law School and was called to the Nigerian Bar in 1990.

targets.targetText: A bi Mohammed Tahir Monguno ni ojo kejìlá osu keji ọdun 1966. O ti kọ ẹkọ alakọbẹrẹ rẹ ni Monguno Central Primary School ati lẹhinna lọ si Ile-iwe Atẹle Ijọba (GSS) Ngala, Ipinle Borno nibiti o ti gba iwe-ẹri Ile-iwe giga rẹ. [1] O kọ ẹkọ nipa ofin ni Yunifasiti ti Maiduguri nibiti o ti pari ni ọdun 1989. Ó lọ sí ilé ẹ̀kọ́ òfin ní Nàìjíríà, wọ́n sì pè é sí ilé-igbó Nàìjíríà ní ọdún 1990.[2]

A bi Mohammed Tahir Monguno ni ojo kejila osu keji odun 1966. O ti kọ ẹkọ alakọbẹrẹ rẹ ni Monguno Central Primary School ati lẹhinna lọ si Ile-iwe Atẹle Ijọba (GSS) Ngala, Ipinle Borno nibiti o ti gba iwe-ẹri Ile-iwe giga rẹ. [1] O kọ ẹkọ nipa ofin ni Yunifasiti ti Maiduguri nibiti o ti pari ni ọdun 1989. Ó lọ sí ilé ẹ̀kọ́ òfin ní Nàìjíríà, wọ́n sì pè é sí ilé-igbó Nàìjíríà ní ọdún 1990.

items.sourceText: Hon. TeeJay attended the popular St. Augustine's College Kabba, where he obtained his West African School Certificate/GCE in 1987. In 1997, he graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in economics from the University of Jos, Plateau State.[6]

targets.targetText: Hon. TeeJay lọ si ile-ẹkọ giga St Augustine's College Kabba, nibiti o ti gba Iwe-ẹri Ile-iwe Iwọ-oorun Afirika/GCE ni ọdun 1987. Ni odun 1997, o gboye gboye nipa imo eto oro aje lati Fasiti ti Jos, ipinle Plateau. [1]

Hon. TeeJay lọ si ile-ẹkọ giga St Augustine's College Kabba, nibiti o ti gba Iwe-ẹri Ilé-ìwé Iwọ-oorun Afirika/GCE ni ọdun 1987. Ni odun 1997, o gboye nípa ìmò eto oro ajé lati Fasiti ti Jos, Ìpínlẹ̀ Plateau. [1]

items.sourceText: Aniekan Uko is a Nigerian Politician and member of the 7th Akwa Ibom State House of Assembly, representing Ibesikpo Asutan State Constituency. He is a member of the Peoples Democratic Party.[1][2][3] He is also known as Iboroakam.[4]

targets.targetText: Aniekan Uko je oloselu omo orile-ede Naijiria ati omo egbe ile igbimo asofin ipinle Akwa Ibom 7th, ti o nsoju agbegbe Ibesikpo Asutan State Constituency. O je omo egbe Peoples Democratic Party . [1] [2] [3] O tun mo si Iboroakam. [4]

Aniekan Uko je olóṣèlú ọmọ orílè-èdè Nàìjíríà ati ọmọ ẹgbẹ ile ìgbìmọ̀ asofin ìpínlè Akwa Ibom 7th, ti o nsójú agbegbe Ibesikpo Asutan State Constituency. O je omo egbe Peoples Democratic Party . [1] [2] [3] O tun mo si Iboroakam. [4]

items.sourceText: His tenure was cut short in December 2015 when the Court of Appeal nullified his election, leading to his removal from the position. Onofiok Luke was elected as the new Speaker of the Akwa Ibom State House of Assembly .[10][11][12]

targets.targetText: Akoko rẹ ti ge kuru ni Oṣu Keji ọdun 2015 nigbati Ile-ẹjọ Apetunpe fagile idibo rẹ, eyiti o yori si yiyọ kuro ni ipo naa. Onofiok Luke ni won yan gege bi olori ile igbimo asofin ipinle Akwa Ibom. [1] [2] [3]

Akoko rẹ ti ge kuru ni Oṣu Keji ọdun 2015 nigbati Ile-ẹjọ Apetunpe fagile ìdìbò rẹ, eyiti o yori si yiyọ kuro ni ipo naa. Onofiok Luke ni won yan gẹgẹ bi olórí ile ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin ìpínlẹ̀ Akwa Ibom. [1] [2] [3]

items.sourceText: Enoh was born and raised in Agbokim Waterfall community of Cross River State.[3] He graduated from the University of Calabar in 1988 with a bachelor’s degree in Sociology, and was the best-graduating student of his set. He attended several courses at home and abroad on capacity building in aid of his legislative work.

targets.targetText: A bi Enoh ati dagba ni agbegbe Agbokim Waterfall ti Ipinle Cross River . [1] O pari ile-ẹkọ giga ti Ilu Calabar ni ọdun 1988 pẹlu oye oye ni Sociology, ati pe o jẹ ọmọ ile-iwe ayẹyẹ ti o dara julọ ti eto rẹ. O lọ si ọpọlọpọ awọn iṣẹ ikẹkọ ni ile ati ni okeere lori kikọ agbara ni iranlọwọ ti iṣẹ isofin rẹ.

A bi Enoh ati dagba ni agbègbè Agbokim Waterfall ti Ìpínlẹ̀ Cross River . [1] O pari ile-ẹkọ giga ti Ilu Calabar ni ọdun 1988 pẹlu oye oye ni Sociology, ati pe o jẹ ọmọ ile-iwe ayẹyẹ ti o dara julọ ti eto rẹ. O lọ si ọpọlọpọ awọn iṣẹ ikẹkọ ni ile ati ni okeere lori kikọ àgbàrá ni iranlọwọ ti iṣẹ isofin rẹ.[2]

items.sourceText: In 2019, Chima was falsely alleged to have raped a woman. Upon further investigation, it was debunked by the Nigerian Police, Imo State, stating that it was a blackmail and conspiracy scheme.[6]

targets.targetText: Ni ọdun 2019, Chima jẹ ẹsun eke pe o ti fipa ba obìnrin kàn lo. Nigba ìwádìí siwaju, ileeṣẹ ọlọpaa lorilẹede Naijiria, ni ìpínlè Imo ni wọn tako rẹ, ti wọn si sọ wi pe ibani lórúkọ je ati ete agbebọn ni. [1]
Ni ọdun 2019, Chima jẹ ẹsun eke pe o ti fipa ba obinrin kan lo. Nigba iwadii siwaju, ileeṣẹ ọlọpaa lorilẹede Naijiria, nipinlẹ Imo ni wọn tako rẹ, ti wọn si sọ wi pe okunkun ati ete agbebọn ni. [1]

items.sourceText: Ihedioha's business interests span real estate development, industrialised farming, hospitality, power and petroleum sectors. He is married to Ebere Ihedioha and has four children (three sons and a daughter). Ihedioha is an avid supporter of the Arsenal football club and enjoys travelling and table tennis. He is a philanthropist, particularly within his native Imo state.

targets.targetText: Awọn iwulo iṣowo Ihedioha ni idagbasoke ohun-ini gidi, iṣẹ-ogbin ti iṣelọpọ, alejò, agbara ati awọn apa epo. O ti ni iyawo si Ebere Ihedioha, o si bi ọmọ mẹrin (ọkunrin mẹta ati ọmọbirin kan). Ihedioha jẹ alatilẹyin oninuure fun ẹgbẹ agbabọọlu Arsenal ati gbadun irin-ajo ati tẹnisi tabili. O jẹ onínúrere, paapaa laarin ìpínlè Imo abinibi rẹ.

Awọn iwulo iṣowo Ihedioha ni idagbasoke ohun-ini gidi, iṣẹ-ogbin ti iṣelọpọ, alejò, agbara ati awọn apa epo. O ti ni iyawo si Ebere Ihedioha, o si bi ọmọ mẹrin (ọkunrin mẹta ati ọmọbirin kan). Ihedioha jẹ alatilẹyin oninuure fun ẹgbẹ agbabọọlu Arsenal ati gbadun irin-ajo ati tẹnisi tabili. O jẹ oninuure, paapaa laarin ipinlẹ Imo abinibi rẹ.

items.sourceText: Isau was a member of the People's Democratic Party and contested for the party's governorship ticket in the 2019 general election, alongside Bolaji Abdullahi.[4][5] He served as the 14th chairman of Nigerian Bar Association Ilorin branch between 2000 - 2001.[6]

targets.targetText: Isau je omo egbe People's Democratic Party, o si dije fun tikeeti gomina egbe naa ninu idibo gbogboogbo odun 2019, pelu Bolaji Abdullahi . [1] [2] O ṣiṣẹ gẹgẹbi alaga 14th ti Nigerian Bar Association ti eka Ilorin laarin 2000 - 2001. [3]

Isau je ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ People's Democratic Party, o si dije fun tikeeti gomina egbe naa ninu idibo gbogbogbòò odun 2019, pelu Bolaji Abdullahi . [1] [2] O ṣiṣẹ gẹgẹbi alága 14th ti Nigerian Bar Association ti eka Ilorin láàrin ọdún 2000 - 2001. [3]

items.sourceText: Abayomi Sheba is a Nigerian politician born on 2 May 1961 in Ode Irele, Irele Local Government, Ondo State, Nigeria. He completed his primary and secondary education in Ode Irele. He then attended the University of Ilorin, where he obtained a Bachelor's degree in Public Administration. He furthered his education at Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife, earning a Master's degree in Public Administration from 1995 to 1997.[1][2]

targets.targetText: Abayomi Sheba je olóṣèlú omo orile- ede Naijiria ti a bi ni ojo keji osu karùn-ún ọdún 1961 ni Ode Irele, ijoba ìbílè Irele, Ìpínlẹ̀ Ondo, Naijiria . O pari eko alakọbẹrẹ ati gírámà ni Ode Irele. Lẹhinna o lọ si ile-ẹkọ giga ti Ilorin, nibiti o ti gba oye oye ni Ìṣàkóso Ijọba. O tẹsiwaju ninu eko re ni Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife, nibi ti o ti gba oye gíga ninu Ìṣàkóso ìjọba lati 1995 si 1997. [1] [2]

Abayomi Sheba je oloselu omo orile- ede Naijiria ti a bi ni ojo keji osu karun-un odun 1961 ni Ode Irele, ijoba ibile Irele, ipinle Ondo, Naijiria . O pari eko alakoobere ati girama ni Ode Irele. Lẹhinna o lọ si ile-ẹkọ giga ti Ilorin, nibiti o ti gba oye oye ni Isakoso Ijọba. O tesiwaju ninu eko re ni Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife, nibi ti o ti gba oye oye giga ninu isakoso ijoba lati 1995 si 1997. [1] [2]

items.sourceText: Yusuf Ahmad Badau has served in the Federal House of Representatives, representing the Shanono/Bagwai constituency in both the 9th and 10th parliaments of the Kano State House of Assembly.[1][2]

targets.targetText: Yusuf Ahmad Badau ti ṣiṣẹ ni ile igbimọ aṣofin apapọ ìjọba gẹẹsi, ti o n ṣoju ẹkun idibo Shanono / Bagwai ni awọn ile igbimọ aṣofin kẹsàn-án ati kẹwàá ti Ile-igbimọ Asofin Ìpínlè Kano . [1] [2]
Yusuf Ahmad Badau ti ṣiṣẹ ni ile igbimọ aṣofin apapọ ijọba gẹẹsi, ti o n ṣoju ẹkun idibo Shanono / Bagwai ni awọn ile igbimọ aṣofin 9th ati 10th ti Ile-igbimọ Asofin Ipinle Kano . [1] [2]

items.sourceText: Odebunmi completed his primary education at Baptist Day School, Oko, Oyo State (1974–1980), and his secondary education at Baptist Secondary Grammar School, Oko. He then earned an Ordinary Diploma in Secretarial Administration from the Federal Polytechnic, Ede, Osun State, and a Bachelor of Science degree in Business Education from the University of Ado-Ekiti.[3]

targets.targetText: Odebunmi parí ẹ̀kọ́ alakọbẹrẹ ni Baptist Day School, Oko, Ìpínlẹ̀ Oyo (1974–1980), ati eko gírámà re ni Baptist Secondary Grammar School, Oko. Lẹhinna o gba iwe-ẹkọ diploma deede ni ìpín fúnni Secretarial lati Federal Polytechnic, Ede, Ìpínlẹ̀ Osun, ati oye ni Ẹkọ Iṣowo lati Fasiti ti Ado-Ekiti . [1]

Odebunmi pari eko alakoobere ni Baptist Day School, Oko, Ipinle Oyo (1974–1980), ati eko girama re ni Baptist Secondary Grammar School, Oko. Lẹhinna o gba iwe-ẹkọ diploma deede ni ipinfunni Secretarial lati Federal Polytechnic, Ede, Ipinle Osun, ati oye oye oye ni Ẹkọ Iṣowo lati Fasiti ti Ado-Ekiti . [1]

items.sourceText: Cornelius Nnaji was born in 1973 and hails from Enugu State. In 2019, he succeeded Kingsley Ebenyi to be elected into the Federal House of Assembly under the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP).[1][2]

targets.targetText: Ọdun 1973 ni wọn bi Cornelius Nnaji, o si wa lati ipinlẹ Enugu . Ni ọdun 2019, o rọpo Kingsley Ebenyi lati dibo si ile igbimọ aṣofin apapọ labẹ ẹgbẹ Peoples Democratic Party (PDP). [1] [2]
Ọdun 1973 ni wọn bi Cornelius Nnaji, o si wa lati ìpínlè Enugu . Ni ọdun 2019, o rọpo Kingsley Ebenyi lati dibo si ile igbimọ aṣofin apapọ labẹ ẹgbẹ òṣèlú Peoples Democratic Party (PDP). [1] [2]

items.sourceText: Dennis Oguerinwa Amadi was born in 1968 and hails from Enugu State. He started his elementary education at Christ High School, Abor and completed in 1986 at Boy's High School, Uzalla. In 1991, he graduated from the University of Benin with a bachelor’s degree in Computer Science, and later bagged an MBA degree from the same university.[1][2]

targets.targetText: Dennis Oguerinwa Amadi ni a bi ni ọdun 1968 ati pe o wa láti Ìpínlẹ̀ Enugu . O bere ẹ̀kọ́ alakọbẹrẹ rẹ ni Christ High School, Abor o si pari ni 1986 ni Boy's High School, Uzalla. Ni 1991, o pari ile-ẹkọ giga ti Benin pẹlu oye ni imọ-ẹrọ Kọmputa, lẹhinna o gba oye MBA lati ile-ẹkọ giga kanna. [1] [2]

Dennis Oguerinwa Amadi ni a bi ni ọdun 1968 ati pe o wa lati Ipinle Enugu . O bere eko alakọbẹrẹ rẹ ni Christ High School, Abor o si pari ni 1986 ni Boy's High School, Uzalla. Ni 1991, o pari ile-ẹkọ giga ti Benin pẹlu oye oye ni imọ-ẹrọ Kọmputa, lẹhinna o gba oye MBA lati ile-ẹkọ giga kanna. [1] [2]

items.sourceText: Foingha was elected to the House of Representatives in 2011 and was reelected in 2015, representing the Brass/Nembe Federal Constituency, Bayelsa State, Nigeria.[1][4]

targets.targetText: Foingha ni a dibo si Ile Awọn Aṣoju ni ọdun 2011 ati pe o tun yan ni ọdun 2015, ti o nsoju àgbègbè Brass/Nembe ni Ìpínlẹ̀ Bayelsa, Nàìjíríà [1] [2]
Foingha ni a dibo si Ile Awọn Aṣoju ni ọdun 2011 ati pe o tun yan ni ọdun 2015, ti o nsoju agbegbe Brass/Nembe Federal Constituency, Ipinle Bayelsa, Nigeria. [1] [2]

items.sourceText: The four common ingredients used in making aadun include corn flour, chilli pepper, palm oil and salt. There are two types of the snack and they are: the pure cornflour and the moulded one rich in palm oil. The okun people from kogi state also add grinded beans to their corn flour before moulding with banana leaves to give it a unique taste.[3][4]

targets.targetText: Awọn eroja mẹrin ti o wọpọ ti a lo fun ṣiṣe adun ni iyẹfun agbado, ata chilli, epo ọpẹ ati iyo. Orisi ipanu meji lo wa ti won si je: iyẹfun agbado ti a mọn sínu epo ọpẹ. Awon ara okun lati ipinle kogi tun fi ewa ti a yan sinu iyẹfun agbado wọn ki wọn to di ewe ogede lati fun ni itọwo otooto. [1] [2]

Awọn eroja mẹrin ti o wọpọ ti a lo fun ṣiṣe adun ni iyẹfun agbado, ata chilli, epo ọpẹ ati iyo. Orisi ipanu meji lo wa ti won si je: iyẹfun agbado ti ko dara ati eyi ti o jẹ ti epo ọpẹ. Awon ara okun lati ipinle kogi tun fi ewa ti a yan sinu iyẹfun agbado wọn ki wọn to di ewe ogede lati fun ni itọwo otooto. [1] [2]

items.sourceText: The Myanmar New Year Thingyan is announced by the traditional calendar of Myanmar Team and normally falls around 13 April. Cambodia celebrates the Cambodian New Year from 14 to 16 April (ចូលឆ្នាំខ្មែរ or សង្ក្រាន្ត). The Lao New Year, called Songkan (ສົງກຣານ) in the Lao language, is celebrated every year from 13 to 15 April. The Thai New Year or Songkran (สงกรานต์) is fixed every year from 13 to 15 April.

targets.targetText: Ọdun Tuntun Mianma Thingyan jẹ ikede nipasẹ kalẹnda ibile ti Ẹgbẹ Mianma ati deede ṣubu ni ayika 13 Oṣu Kẹrin. Cambodia ṣe ayẹyẹ Ọdun Tuntun Cambodia lati ọjọ 14 si 16 Oṣu Kẹrin (eyi) Ọdun Tuntun Lao, ti a pe ni Songkan (ສົງກຣານ) ni ede Lao, ni a ṣe ayẹyẹ ni gbogbo ọdun lati 13 si 15 Kẹrin. Ọdun Tuntun Thai tabi Songkran (สงกรานต์) ti wa ni ipilẹ ni gbogbo ọdun lati 13 si 15 Oṣu Kẹrin.

Ọdun Tuntun Mianma Thingyan jẹ ikede nipasẹ kalẹnda ibile ti Ẹgbẹ Mianma ni dédé ọjọ́ 13 Oṣu Kẹrin. Cambodia ṣe ayẹyẹ Ọdun Tuntun Cambodia lati ọjọ 14 si 16 Oṣu Kẹrin (eyi) Ọdun Tuntun Lao, ti a pe ni Songkan (ສົງກຣານ) ni ede Lao, ni a ṣe ayẹyẹ ni gbogbo ọdun lati 13 si 15 Kẹrin. Ọdun Tuntun Thai tabi Songkran (สงกรานต์) ti wa ni ipilẹ ni gbogbo ọdun lati 13 si 15 Oṣu Kẹrin.

items.sourceText: Eltahawy was born in Port Said, Egypt.[7] Her family moved to the UK when she was 7 and then to Saudi Arabia when she was 15. She graduated from the American University in Cairo[7] in 1990 with a bachelor's degree and in 1992 she earned a master's degree in mass communication with a concentration in journalism.[8]

targets.targetText: A bi Eltahawy ni Port Said, Egipti . [1] Idile rẹ gbe lọ si UK nigbati o jẹ omo odun meje ati lẹhinna si Saudi Arabia nigbati o jẹ ọdun marundinlogun. O gboye jade ni Ile-ẹkọ giga Amẹrika ni Cairo [1] ni ọdun 1990 pẹlu oye oye ati ni ọdun 1992 o gba alefa titunto si ni ibaraẹnisọrọ pupọ pẹlu ifọkansi ninu iṣẹ iroyin . [2]

A bi Eltahawy ni Port Said, Egipti . [1] Idile rẹ gbe lọ si UK nigbati o jẹ ọdun 7 ati lẹhinna si Saudi Arabia nigbati o jẹ ọdun 15. O gboye jade ni Ile-ẹkọ giga Amẹrika ni Cairo [1] ni ọdun 1990 pẹlu oye oye ati ni ọdun 1992 o gba alefa titunto si ni ibaraẹnisọrọ pupọ pẹlu ifọkansi ninu iṣẹ iroyin . [2]

items.sourceText: Nasir Ahmad El-Rufai was born on 16 February 1960 to a Fulani family in Daudawa. His father died while he was eight years old, and he was sponsored through his early schooling by an uncle.[6]

targets.targetText: Nasir Ahmad El-Rufai ni wọn bi ni ọjọ kẹrin dínlógún oṣù kejì ọdún 1960 si idile Fulani kan ni Daudawa . Bàbá rẹ ku nígbà ti o jẹ ọmọ ọdun mẹjọ, ati pe o ni atilẹyin nipasẹ ile-iwe akọkọ rẹ nipasẹ aburo kan. [1]

Nasir Ahmad El-Rufai ni won bi ni ojo kerindinlogun osu keji odun 1960 si idile Fulani kan ni Daudawa . Baba rẹ ku nigba ti o jẹ ọmọ ọdun mẹjọ, ati pe o ni atilẹyin nipasẹ ile-iwe akọkọ rẹ nipasẹ aburo kan. [1]

items.sourceText: Adewale Oke Adekola FIStructE FICE CON (26 March 1932 – March 1999) was a Nigerian engineer, academic, author, and administrator. He was the first Nigerian dean of engineering and head of civil engineering[1][2][page needed] at the University of Lagos. He was the founding vice chancellor[3] of the Abubakar Tafawa Balewa University Bauchi and emeritus professor of the University of Lagos. He was a pioneer of engineering education[4][page needed] in Nigeria and reputed as a great teacher. He became one of the first Nigerians to be awarded the degree of Doctor of Science (DSc) in 1976 - awarded by London University in engineering (structural mechanics).[5]

targets.targetText: Adewale Oke Adekola FISTructE FICE CON (26 Oṣu Kẹta 1932 - Oṣu Karun 1999) jẹ onilẹ- ede Naijiria kan, ẹkọ, onkowe, ati alakoso. Oun ni oṣiṣẹ akọkọ ti Naijiria ti ẹrọ-ṣiṣe ati ori ti imọ-ilu [1] [2]   ni Yunifasiti ti Lagos . Oun ni Igbakeji Igbimọ Alakoso [3] ti Ile-ẹkọ giga Yunifasiti Abubakar Tafawa Balewa ati olukọ-ọjọ giga ti Yunifasiti ti Lagos. O jẹ aṣáájú-ọnà ti ẹkọ imọ-ẹrọ [4]   ni orile-ede Naijiria ati pe o jẹ alakọni nla. O di ọkan ninu awọn orilẹ-ede Naijiria akọkọ lati fun ni oye ti Dokita Doctor of Science (DSc) ni ọdun 1976 - Oriṣẹ ile-ẹkọ Yunifasiti ti London fun ni imọ-ẹrọ (awọn ẹrọ imọ-ilana). [5]

Adewale Oke Adekola FISTructE FICE CON (26 Oṣu Kẹta 1932 - Oṣu Karun 1999) jẹ onilẹ- ede Naijiria kan, ẹkọ, onkowe, ati alakoso. Oun ni oṣiṣẹ akọkọ ti Naijiria ti ẹrọ-ṣiṣe ati ori ti imọ-ilu [1] [2] ni Yunifasiti ti Eko. Oun ni Igbakeji Igbimọ Alakoso [3] ti Ile-ẹkọ giga Yunifasiti Abubakar Tafawa Balewa ati olukọ-ọjọ giga ti Yunifasiti ti Eko. O jẹ aṣáájú-ọnà ti ẹkọ imọ-ẹrọ [4]   ni orile-ede Naijiria ati pe o jẹ alakọni nla. O di ọkan ninu awọn orilẹ-ede Naijiria akọkọ lati fun ni oye ti Dokita Doctor of Science (DSc) ni ọdun 1976 - Oriṣẹ ile-ẹkọ Yunifasiti ti London fun ni imọ-ẹrọ (awọn ẹrọ imọ-ilana). [5]

items.sourceText: Anthony Olufunsho Williams (May 9, 1948 – July 27, 2006) was an influential politician from Lagos State and former Commissioner under Colonel Olagunsoye Oyinlola's Military Administration in Lagos.

targets.targetText: Anthony Olufunsho Williams (Oṣu Karun ojo kesan, 1948 - Oṣu Keje 27, 2006) je oloselu lati Ipinle Eko ati Oludari Alakoso labẹ Isakoso Ologun ti ile-igbimọ Colonel Olagunsoye Oyinlola ni Lagos.
Anthony Olufunsho Williams (Oṣu Keje 9, 1948 - Oṣu Keje 27, 2006) je oloselu oloselu lati Ipinle Eko ati Oludari Alakoso labẹ Isakoso Ologun ti ile-igbimọ Colonel Olagunsoye Oyinlola ni Lagos.

items.sourceText: Segun Agbaje (born 1964) is the Managing Director of Guaranty Trust Bank.[1] He is also a Director on MasterCard Advisory Board Middle East and Africa.

targets.targetText: Segun Agbaje (bi 1964) ni Alakoso Alakoso Guaranty Trust Bank . [1] O tun jẹ Oludari lori Alakoso Advisory Board Aarin Ila-oorun ati Afirika.
Segun Agbaje (bi 1964) ni Alakoso Guaranty Trust Bank . [1] O tun jẹ Oludari lori Alakoso Advisory Board Aarin Ila-oorun ati Afirika.

items.sourceText: Beatriz Gimeno Reinoso (born 9 May 1962, Madrid)[1] is a Spanish politician and LGBT rights activist. Since June 2015, she has been a representative for Podemos in the tenth legislative term of the Assembly of Madrid[2] and is responsible for the area of policy of Podemos concerning equality in Madrid.[3] She was the President of the FELGTB (National Federation of Lesbians, Gays, Transsexuals and Bisexuals) between 2003 and 2007, during the period in which same-sex marriage was approved in Spain and Madrid was chosen as the holder of Europride 2007.[4]

targets.targetText: Beatriz Gimeno Reinoso (a bi 9 May 1962, Madrid ) [1] jẹ oloselu Spani kan ati olugboja ẹtọ ẹtọ LGBT . Niwon June 2015, o ti jẹ aṣoju fun Podemos ni ofin mẹwa ti Apejọ ti Madrid [2] ati pe o ni ẹtọ fun agbegbe ti Podemos nipa isọgba ni Madrid. [3] O jẹ Aare ti FELGTB (National Federation of Lesbians, Gays, Transsexuals and Bisexuals) laarin ọdun 2003 ati 2007, lakoko ti akoko ti a ti ṣe adehun igbeyawo igbeyawo kanna ni Spain ati Madrid ni a yàn gẹgẹbi oluwo Europride 2007 . [4]

Beatriz Gimeno Reinoso (a bi 9 May 1962, Madrid ) [1] jẹ oloselu Orile ede Spain kan ati olugboja ẹtọ LGBT . Lati June 2015, o ti jẹ aṣoju fun Podemos ni ole gbimo ofin ti Madrid [2] ati pe o ni ẹtọ fun agbegbe ti Podemos nipa isọgba ni Madrid. [3] O jẹ Aare ti FELGTB (National Federation of Lesbians, Gays, Transsexuals and Bisexuals) laarin ọdun 2003 ati 2007, lakoko ti akoko ti a ti ṣe adehun igbeyawo igbeyawo kanna ni Spain ati Madrid ni a yàn gẹgẹbi oluwo Europride 2007 . [4]

items.sourceText: The symbolism of the cross which is today one of the most widely recognized Christian symbols was used from the earliest Christian times and Justin Martyr who died in 165 describes it in a way that already implies its use as a symbol, although the crucifix appeared later.[231][232] Masters such as Caravaggio, Rubens and Titian have all depicted the Crucifixion scene in their works.

targets.targetText: Awọn aami ti àgbélébù ti o jẹ loni ọkan ninu awọn aami Kristiẹni ti a gbajumo julọ ni a lo lati igba akọkọ Kristiani ati Justin Martyr ti o kú ni 165 ṣe apejuwe rẹ ni ọna ti o ti tẹlẹ tumọ si lilo rẹ gẹgẹbi aami, biotilejepe àgbélébù han nigbamii. [1] [2] Awọn oluko bii Caravaggio, Rubens ati Titian ti ṣe afihan ipo àgbélébù ninu iṣẹ wọn.

Awọn aami ti agbelebu ti o jẹ loni ọkan ninu awọn aami Kristiẹni ti a gbajumo julọ ni a lo lati igba akọkọ Kristiani ati Justin Martyr ti o kú ni 165 ṣe apejuwe rẹ ni ọna ti o ti tẹlẹ tumọ si lilo rẹ gẹgẹbi aami, biotilejepe agbelebu han nigbamii. [1] [2] Awọn oluko bii Caravaggio, Rubens ati Titian ti ṣe afihan ipo Agbelebu ninu iṣẹ wọn.

items.sourceText: Ita Egbe is a village located in Ipokia Local Government Area of Ogun State, it is recognized by its huge agricultural activities around the area and by being one of the largest oil palm producer in Ipokia Local Government of Ogun state.

targets.targetText: Ita Egbe jẹ abule kan ti o wa ni Ijoba Ibile ti Ipokia ti Ipinle Ogun, a mọ̀ọ́ nipasẹ awọn iṣẹ-ogbin ti o tobi julọ ni ayika agbegbe ati nipa jije ọkan ninu awọn ti o tobi julọ ti ọpẹ ni Ipinle Ijọba ti Ogun.

Ita Egbe jẹ abule kan ti o wa ni Ipinle Ijoba Ibile ti Ipokia ti Ipinle Ogun, o mọ nipasẹ awọn iṣẹ-ogbin ti o tobi julọ ni ayika agbegbe ati nipa jije ọkan ninu awọn ti o tobi julọ ti ọpẹ ni Ipinle Ijọba ti Ogun.

items.sourceText: Babaeko attended the Federal School of Arts and Science in Suleja, Niger State for his A-levels, and Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria for his first degree in Theatre Arts[1] though he said he had always wanted to be in advertising. He did his mandatory National Youth Service (NYSC) at NTA Kaduna.[9]

targets.targetText: Babaeko lọ si Ile-ẹkọ Federal Arts of Arts and Science ni Suleja, Ipinle Niger fun awọn ipele A-rẹ, ati Ile-iwe Ahmadu Bello, Zaria fun oye akọkọ rẹ ni Arts Theatre [1] botilẹjẹpe o sọ pe nigbagbogbo fẹ lati wa ni ipolowo. O ṣe dandan ti Iṣẹ Iṣẹ Ọdọmọde ti Orilẹ-ede (NYSC) ni NTA Kaduna. [2]

Babaeko lọ si Ile-ẹkọ Federal Arts of Arts and Science ni Suleja, ni Ipinle Niger fun A-level rẹ, ati Ile-iwe Ahmadu Bello, Zaria fun oye akọkọ rẹ ni Theatre Arts[1] sugbon o sọ pe nigbagbogbo fẹ lati wa ni ipolowo. O ṣe dandan ti Iṣẹ Iṣẹ Ọdọmọde ti Orilẹ-ede (NYSC) ni NTA Kaduna. [2]

items.sourceText: On 12 January 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed that a novel coronavirus was the cause of a respiratory illness in a cluster of people in Wuhan City, Hubei Province, China, which was reported to the WHO on 31 December 2019.[3][4]

targets.targetText: Ni ọjọ 12 Oṣu Kini ọjọ 2020, Ajo Agbaye fun Ilera (WHO) fidi rẹ mulẹ pe coronavirus aramada ni fa ti aisan atẹgun ninu akopọ ti eniyan ni Wuhan City, Agbegbe Hubei, China, eyiti o royin fun WHO ni Oṣu Kẹjọ Ọjọ 31 Oṣu keji ọdun 2019. [ 1] [2]

Ni ọjọ 12 Oṣu Kini ọjọ 2020, Ajo Agbaye fun Ilera (WHO) fidi rẹ mulẹ pe coronavirus aramada ni fa ti aisan ìmín ninu akopọ àwọn ènìyàn ni Wuhan City, Agbegbe Hubei, China, eyiti o royin fun WHO ni Oṣu Kẹjọ Ọjọ 31 Oṣu keji ọdun 2019. [ 1] [2]

items.sourceText: Augie-Kuta became an Associate for the Nigeria Leadership Initiative (NLI) in May 2011. She is also the vice-president of Women in Film and Television in Nigeria (WIFTIN) the West African chapter of the US-based network. She co-founded the Photowagon, a Nigerian photography collective, in 2009.[4]

targets.targetText: Augie-Kuta di alabaṣẹpọ fun Nigeria Leadership Initiative (NLI) ni oṣu Karun ọdun 2011. O tun jẹ igbakeji aare ti Awọn Obirin oni Fiimu ati Telifisonu ni Nigeria, ipin ti Iwọ-oorun Afirika ti nẹtiwọọki ti o da lori AMẸRIKA. O ṣe agbekalẹ Photowagon, apapọ fọtoyiya ti Naijiria, ni ọdun 2009. [1]

Augie-Kuta di alabaṣiṣẹpọ fun Initiative Leadership Initiative (NLI) ni oṣu Karun ọdun 2011. O tun jẹ igbakeji aare ti Awọn Obirin ni Fiimu ati Telifisonu ni Nigeria (WIFTIN) ipin ti Iwọ-oorun Afirika ti nẹtiwọọki ti o da lori AMẸRIKA. O ṣe agbekalẹ Photowagon, apapọ fọtoyiya ti Naijiria, ni ọdun 2009. [1]

items.sourceText: The Battle of Gurin took place on 29 April 1915 during the Kamerun Campaign of World War I in Gurin, British Nigeria near the border with German Kamerun. The battle was one of the largest of the German forays into the British colony. It ended in a successful British repulsion of the German force.

targets.targetText: Ogun ti Gurin waye ni ọjọ 29 Kẹrin ọdun 1915 lakoko Kam Kam Campaign ti Ogun Agbaye 1 ni Gurin, British Nigeria nitosi aala pẹlu German Kamerun . Ija naa jẹ ọkan ninu awọn ti o tobi julọ ti awọn ọmọ ilu Jamani si ileto Ilu Gẹẹsi. O pari ni ifasilẹ Ijọba Gẹẹsi ti aṣeyọri ti ipa ara ilu Jamani.

Ogun ti Gurin waye ni ọjọ 29 Kẹrin ọdun 1915 lakoko Kam Kam Campaign ti Ogun Agbaye 1 ni Gurin, British Nigeria nitosi aala pẹlu German Kamerun . Ija naa jẹ ọkan ninu awọn ti o tobi julọ ti awọn ọmọ ilu Jamani si ileto Ilu Gẹẹsi. O pari ni ifasilẹ Ijọba Gẹẹsi ti aṣeyọri ti ipa ara ilu Jamani. Leyin ti won saseyori ogun ti Germany

items.sourceText: Abdul Latiff Abdul Majeed (15 November 1933 – 13 November 1987) was a Sri Lankan politician and Member of Parliament.[1]

targets.targetText: Abdul Latiff Abdul Majeed (15 Oṣu kọkanla 1933 – 13 Kọkànlá Oṣù 1987) jẹ oloselu Sri Lankan ati Ọmọ Igbimọ Aṣoju. [1]
Abdul Latiff Abdul Majeed (15 Oṣù Kọkànlá odun1933 – 13 Kọkànlá Oṣù 1987) jẹ oloselu Sri Lankan ati Ọmọ Igbimọ Aṣoju. [1]

items.sourceText: Abdul Majeed was born on 15 November 1933.[2] He was educated at Sivananda Vidyalayam, Batticaloa and Trincomalee Hindu College.[3] He later studied at Wadia College, Bombay and Presidency College, Madras.[3]

targets.targetText: Abdul Majeed bi ni 15 Kọkànlá Oṣù 1933. [1] O kọ ẹkọ ni Sivananda Vidyalayam, Batticaloa ati Trincomalee Hindu College . [2] Lẹhinna o kọ ẹkọ ni Ile-ẹkọ giga Wadia, Bombay ati Alakoso Alakoso, Madras . [2]

Won bi Abdul Majeed ni ojo karun-dinlogun Oṣù Kọkànlá odun 1933. [1] O kọ ẹkọ ni Sivananda Vidyalayam, Batticaloa ati Trincomalee Hindu College . [2] Lẹhinna o kọ ẹkọ ni Ile-ẹkọ giga Wadia, Bombay ati Alakoso Alakoso, Madras . [2]

items.sourceText: Abdul Majeed stood as a candidate in Mutur at the March 1960 parliamentary election but failed to get elected.[5] He stood as the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) candidate in Mutur at the July 1960 parliamentary election. He won the election and entered Parliament.[6] He was appointed Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Public Works in 1964.[3]

targets.targetText: Abdul Majeed gbegba idibo ni Mutur ni idibo ile igbimọ aṣofin ni Oṣu Kẹta Ọjọ 1960 ṣugbọn won ko yan-an wole. [1] O duro gege bi oludije fun Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) ni Mutur ni idibo ile-igbimọ aṣofin ti July 1960 . O bori ninu idibo naa o si wọ ile igbimọ aṣofin . [2] Won yan gege Akowe Ile-igbimọ aṣofin si Minisita fun Iṣẹ Gbogbogbo ni ọdun 1964. [3]

Abdul Majeed duro bi oludibo ni Mutur ni idibo ile igbimọ aṣofin ni Oṣu Kẹta Ọjọ 1960 ṣugbọn o kuna lati dibo. [1] O duro gege bi oludije Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) ni Mutur ni idibo ile-igbimọ aṣofin ti July 1960 . O bori ninu idibo naa o si wọ ile igbimọ aṣofin . [2] O ti yan Akowe Ile-igbimọ aṣofin si Minisita fun Iṣẹ Gbogbogbo ni ọdun 1964. [3]

items.sourceText: Tijani Babatunde Folawiyo (also known as Tunde Folawiyo) is a Nigerian businessman. He is the managing director of Yinka Folawiyo Group.[1] According to Forbes, he has an estimated net worth of $650 million.[2]

targets.targetText: Tijani Babatunde Folawiyo (ti a tun mọ ni Tunde Folawiyo ) jẹ onisowo omo ori elede Nigiria. Oun ni oludari iṣakoso ẹgbẹ Yinka Folawiyo. [1]Gẹgẹbi Forbes, o ni iye ti o ni ifoju ti $ 650 milionu. [2]
Tijani Babatunde Folawiyo (ti a tun mọ ni Tunde Folawiyo ) jẹ oniṣowo ọmọ-ede Naijiria kan. Oun ni oludari iṣakoso ẹgbẹ Yinka Folawiyo. [1] Gẹgẹbi Forbes, o ni iye ti o ni ifoju ti $ 650 milionu. [2]

items.sourceText: Honorary titles Preceded by Flora Azikiwe First Lady of Nigeria 16 January 1966 – 29 July 1966 Succeeded by Victoria Gowon

targets.targetText: Awọn akọle ọlá Ti ṣaju nipasẹ </br> Flora Azikiwe Iyaafin Akọkọ ti Nigeria </br> 16 Oṣu Kini 1966 - 29 Oṣu Keje 1966 Ṣe aṣeyọri nipasẹ </br> Victoria Gowon
Awọn akọle ọlá Ti ṣaju nipasẹ Flora Azikiwe Iyaafin Akọkọ ti Nigeria 16 Oṣu Kini 1966 - 29 Oṣu Keje 1966 Ṣe aṣeyọri nipasẹ Victoria Gowon

items.sourceText: Catherine Chikwakwa (born 24 July 1985 in Blantyre) is a Malawian long-distance runner. She has represented her country at both the 2000 Sydney Olympics and the 2004 Athens Olympics, as well as several Commonwealth Games. She was the 5000 metres silver medallist at the 2004 World Junior Championships in Athletics, held in Grosseto, Italy.

targets.targetText: Catherine Chikwakwa (ti a bi 24 Keje 1985 ni Blantyre ) jẹ asare-jinna jijin ara Malawi kan . O ti ṣe aṣoju orilẹ-ede rẹ ni mejeeji Olimpiiki Sydney 2000 ati Olimpiiki Athens 2004, bakanna pẹlu awọn ere Agbaye lọpọlọpọ . Arabinrin naa jẹ ami-eye fadaka 5000 mita ni 2004 World Junior Championships ni Awọn elere idaraya, ti o waye ni Grosseto, Italy.

Catherine Chikwakwa (ti a bi ni 24 osu Keje 1985 ni Blantyre ) jẹ asare-jinna jijin ara Malawi kan . O ti ṣe aṣoju orilẹ-ede rẹ ni ona meji ni Olimpiiki Sydney 2000 ati Olimpiiki Athens 2004, bakanna pẹlu awọn ere Agbaye lọpọlọpọ . Arabinrin naa jẹ ami-eye fadaka 5000 mita ni 2004 World Junior Championships ni elere idaraya, ti o waye ni Grosseto, Italy.

items.sourceText: Kenza Tazi was born on 6 February 1996 in Boston, Massachusetts to Moroccan parents. Tazi began to ski at the age of three, joining her first ski club when she turned 12. She later explained that "every year my family took me skiing for one week in winter and my love of the sport grew from there"[citation needed].

targets.targetText: Kenza Tazi ni a bi ni ọjọ 6 Kínní 1996 ni Boston, Massachusetts si awọn obi Ilu Morocco. Tazi bẹrẹ siki ni ọmọ ọdun mẹta, o darapọ mọ ẹgbẹ ski akọkọ rẹ nigbati o di ọdun 12. Lẹhinna o ṣalaye pe “ni gbogbo ọdun idile mi mu mi ni ski fun ọsẹ kan ni igba otutu ati pe ifẹ mi fun ere idaraya dagba lati ibẹ”  .

Kenza Tazi ni a bi ni ọjọ 6 Kínní 1996 ni Boston, Massachusetts si awọn obi Ilu Morocco. Tazi bẹrẹ siki ni ọmọ ọdun mẹta, o darapọ mọ ẹgbẹ ski akọkọ rẹ nigbati o di ọdun 12. Lẹhinna o ṣalaye pe “ni gbogbo ọdun ni idile re ma nmu oun jade ski fun ọsẹ kan ni igba otutu ati pe ifẹ mi fun ere idaraya dagba lati ibẹ”  .

items.sourceText: She was part of the Nigeria national team at the 2015 FIFA Women's World Cup and the winning squad at the 2014 African Women's Championship.[9]

targets.targetText: O jẹ okan laara ẹgbẹ orilẹ-ede Naijiria ni 2015 FIFA Women's World Cup ati ẹgbẹ ti o bori ni 2014 African Women's Championship . [1]
O jẹ apakan ti ẹgbẹ orilẹ-ede Naijiria ni 2015 FIFA Women's World Cup ati ẹgbẹ ti o bori ni 2014 African Women's Championship . [1]

items.sourceText: At the 1987 Central African Games he won the gold medal in the triple jump and the silver medal in the long jump.[1] At the 1988 African Championships he won the gold medal in the triple jump.[2]

targets.targetText: Ni ìdíje ere 1987 Central African o gba ami-eye goolu ni fo olopometa ati ami ẹyẹ fadaka ni ti ifo gigun. [1] Ni ipari idije naa ni 1988 ti Afirika o gba ami-eye goolu ni fo olopometa. [2]
Ni awọn ere 1987 Central African o gba ami-eye goolu ni fo meteta ati ami ẹyẹ fadaka ni fo gigun. [1] Ni idije 1988 ti Afirika o gba ami-eye goolu ni fo meteta. [2]

items.sourceText: Igor Alberto Secundino Silva (born 22 October 1984) is an Angolan road racing cyclist, who currently rides for UCI Continental team BAI–Sicasal–Petro de Luanda.[1]

targets.targetText: Igor Alberto Secundino Silva (ti a bi ni ọjọ kejilelogun Oṣu Kẹwa Ọdun 1984) jẹ ẹlẹṣin-ije ni opopona ni orilẹ-ede Angola, ti o gun lọwọlọwọ fun ẹgbẹ UCI Continental BAI–Sicasal–Petro de Luanda . [1]
Igor Alberto Secundino Silva (ti a bi 22 Oṣu Kẹwa Ọdun 1984) jẹ ẹlẹṣin-ije ni opopona Angolan kan, ti o gun lọwọlọwọ fun ẹgbẹ UCI Continental BAI–Sicasal–Petro de Luanda . [1]

items.sourceText: At the 1996 African Championships he won the silver medals in the 100 metres.[1] He also competed at the World Championships in 1995 and 1997, as well as in 4 x 100 m relay at the 1996 and 2000 Summer Olympics without reaching the final.

targets.targetText: Ni idije 1996 Afirika o gba ami-ẹri fadaka ni mita 100 . [1] O tun dije ni Awọn ere-idije Agbaye ni ọdun 1995 ati 1997, ati ni 4 x 100 m relay ni idije ti ọdun 1996 ati 2000 Olimpiiki Igba ooru laisi de ipari.

Ni idije 1996 Afirika o gba awọn ami-ẹri fadaka ni awọn mita 100 . [1] O tun dije ni Awọn ere-idije Agbaye ni ọdun 1995 ati 1997, ati ni 4 x 100 m relay ni 1996 ati 2000 Olimpiiki Igba ooru laisi de ipari.

items.sourceText: His personal best times are 10.11 seconds in the 100 m and 20.58 seconds in the 200 m, both achieved in the summer of 2002.

targets.targetText: Awọn akoko ti o dara julọ ti ara ẹni jẹ awọn aaya 10.11 ni 100 m ati 20.58 awọn aaya ni 200 m, mejeeji ṣaṣeyọri ni igba ooru ti ọdun 2002.
Awọn akoko ti o dara julọ ti ara re jẹ awọn aaya 10.11 ni 100 m ati 20.58 aaya ni 200 m, mejeeji ṣaṣeyọri ni igba ooru ti ọdun 2002.

items.sourceText: For Chad he finished ninth at the 1964 Olympic Games. It is still Chad's best position ever at the Olympic Games. On the Track and Field News annual world rankings Idriss placed ninth in 1961, tenth in 1964 and eighth in 1966.[3]

targets.targetText: Fun Chad o pari ni ipo kẹsan ni ere Olimpiiki 1964 . O tun jẹ ipo ti o dara julọ ti orilẹ-ede Chad lailai ni ere ìdíje Olympic. Lori Track and Field News ni ipo agbaye lododun Idriss gbe ipo kẹsan ni ọdun 1961, kẹwa ni ọdun 1964 ati kẹjọ ni ọdun 1966. [1]

Fun Chad o pari ipo kẹsan ni Awọn ere Olimpiiki 1964 . O tun jẹ ipo ti o dara julọ ti Chad lailai ni Awọn ere Olympic. Lori Track and Field News awọn ipo agbaye lododun Idriss gbe ipo kẹsan ni ọdun 1961, kẹwa ni ọdun 1964 ati kẹjọ ni ọdun 1966. [1]

items.sourceText: Anozie lived in Benin, Edo State, Nigeria[1] before moving to the United States in 2014. She originally planned to visit Chicago for training tour for 2014 Commonwealth Games but ended up living in Shreveport, Louisiana after a conflict with her trainer.[2]

targets.targetText: Anozie ngbe ni Benin, Edo State, ni orilẹ-ede Nigeria [1] ṣaaju ki o to lọ si orile edè Amẹrika ni ọdun 2014. Ni akọkọ oun gbero lati ṣabẹwo si Chicago fun irin-ajo ikẹkọ fun Awọn ere Agbaye 2014 ṣugbọn o bere si n gbe ni Shreveport, Louisiana lẹhin ija kan pẹlu olukọni rẹ. [2]

Anozie ngbe ni Benin, Edo State, Nigeria [1] ṣaaju ki o to lọ si Amẹrika ni ọdun 2014. Ni akọkọ o gbero lati ṣabẹwo si Chicago fun irin-ajo ikẹkọ fun Awọn ere Agbaye 2014 ṣugbọn pari gbigbe ni Shreveport, Louisiana lẹhin ija kan pẹlu olukọni rẹ. [2]

items.sourceText: Shina Abiola Peller (born 14 May 1976) is a Nigerian entrepreneur, politician, Industrialist, and a Member of the 9th National Assembly. He is the chairman and chief executive officer of Aquila Group of Companies and Club Quilox.[1] Shina Peller holds both the chieftaincies titles of Ayedero of Yoruba land and Akinrogun of Epe land, Lagos Nigeria.[2]

targets.targetText: Shina Abiola Peller (ojoibi 14 May 1976) je omo orile-ede Naijiria otaja, oloselu, onise ile ise, ati asòfin ni ilé ìgbìmọ̀ asòfin 9th . items.sourceText: The Musical Society of Nigeria (MUSON) was established in 1983 in the site of the former "Love Garden" (prior to the unveiling the Centre's facilities by Prince Charles in 1995). MUSON was founded as a result of the efforts of some distinguished Nigerians and expatriates to provide facilities for classical music performances in Nigeria, especially in Lagos.

targets.targetText: Awujọ orin ti ile Nigeria (MUSON) ti dasilẹ ni ọdun 1983 ni aaye ti “Ọgbà Ifẹ” ti tẹlẹ (ṣaaju iṣafihan awọn ohun elo Centre nipasẹ Prince Charles ni ọdun 1995). MUSON ni a da sile latari akitiyan awon omo orile-ede Naijiria olokiki ati awon ti o wa ni ilu okeere lati pese ohun elo fun ere orin aladun ni Naijiria, paapaa ni ilu Eko.

items.sourceText: The Lagos State Ministry of Health (Nigeria) is the state government ministry, charged with the responsibility to plan, devise and implement the state policies on health.[1][2]The State Ministry of Health in conjunction with the Lagos State House of Assembly created the Lagos State Health Scheme law which established the Lagos State Health Management Agency, Lagos State Health Scheme and the Lagos State Health Fund.[3][4]

items.sourceText: Ikosi, the administrative headquarters of the seven villages that make up Kosofe, was founded in the 15th century, by Aina Ejo, the seventh son of Akanbiogun, an Ile-Ife prince and warrior who previously domiciled in Iwaye Quarters in Ota (Ogun State). He later left Ota to settle for a virgin land.

targets.targetText: Ikosi, olu ile ise isakoso ti awon abule meje ti o je Kosofe, ni won da sile ni orundun marundin logun, lati owo Aina Ejo, omo keje ti Akanbiogun, ijoye ati jagunjagun Ile-Ife ti o tele ni Iwaye Quarters ni Ota (Ogun State). . Lẹ́yìn náà ó kúrò ní Ota láti lọ gbé ilẹ̀ wúńdíá.

items.sourceText: According to Lagos State gouvernour Sanwo-Olu, full production of the facility will drastically reduce prices of rice and pressure to purchase the commodity.[6] At this moment (early 2022) Nigeria produces husk rice, yet imports hulled/polished rice at a higher price.[7] Processing the national staple food rice in its own country therefore should improve Nigeria's trade balance.

targets.targetText: Gege bi gomina ipinle Eko Sanwo-Olu se so, isejade ni kikun ti ohun elo naa yoo dinku iye owo iresi ati lati ra ọja naa. [1] Ni akoko yii (ni kutukutu 2022) Naijiria nmu iresi husk jade, sibẹ o n gbe iresi ti o dan wọle ni idiyele ti o ga julọ. [2] Sise ilana iresi ounjẹ ti orilẹ-ede ni orilẹ-ede tirẹ nitori naa o yẹ ki o mu iwọntunwọnsi iṣowo Naijiria dara si.

items.sourceText: Broad Street on Lagos Island, Lagos, Nigeria, is a commercial hub in one of the city's central business districts.[1][2] Among the tenants: Bagatelle restaurant,[3] Christ Church Cathedral Primary School,[4] Eko Boys High School, Newswatch (Nigeria), and St. Mary's Private School.[5] The "Secretariat" building was constructed in 1906.[6]

items.sourceText: The yearly festival is a cultural and historical feast aiming at showcasing the richness and diversity of African heritage, as well as celebrating African creativity through a variety of performances including traditional and modern dance, drama, music, and expositions. The combination of traditional and modern performing techniques is intended to present guests with a one-of-a-kind cultural experience in Lagos.

items.sourceText: Abubeker Nassir Ahmed (Amharic: አቡበከር ናስር; born 23 February 2000) is an Ethiopian professional footballer who plays as a forward for Mamelodi Sundowns in the Premier Soccer League and the Ethiopia national team. He previously played for Ethiopian Coffee in the Ethiopian Premier League.[1][2]

items.sourceText: The use of education as a tool of colonization was widespread throughout the French Colonial Empire. Hubert Lyautey, the first Resident-General of French Morocco, advocated for the facilitation of ruling and conquest through cooperation with native elites. To facilitate the relationship with this "bourgeois" class of francophone Africans, selective educational institutions were established across the French Empire.

targets.targetText: Lilo eto-ẹkọ bi ohun elo ti imunisin jẹ ibigbogbo jakejado Ijọba Faranse . Hubert Lyautey, Olugbe akọkọ-Gbogbogbo ti Ilu Faranse Morocco, ṣeduro fun irọrun ti iṣakoso ati iṣẹgun nipasẹ ifowosowopo pẹlu awọn alamọdaju abinibi. Lati dẹrọ ibatan pẹlu kilaasi “bourgeois” ti awọn ọmọ Afirika francophone, awọn ile-ẹkọ eto yiyan ti ṣeto ni gbogbo Ijọba Faranse.

items.sourceText: In 2000, the United Nations adopted the Millennium Development Goals, a set of development goals for the year 2015, more specifically, "to ensure that by 2015, children everywhere, boys and girls alike will be able to complete a full course of primary schooling."[18] That same year, the World Education Forum met in Dakar, Senegal, and adopted the Dakar Framework for Action reaffirming the commitment to achieving Education for All by the year 2015.[19]

targets.targetText: Ni ọdun 2000, Ajo Agbaye gba Awọn ibi-afẹde Idagbasoke Ẹgbẹrun Ọdun, eto awọn ibi-afẹde idagbasoke fun ọdun 2015, diẹ sii ni pataki, “lati rii daju pe nipasẹ 2015, awọn ọmọde nibi gbogbo, awọn ọmọkunrin ati awọn ọmọbirin yoo ni anfani lati pari ikẹkọ kikun ti ile-iwe alakọbẹrẹ ." items.sourceText: Joel Marangella is an American oboist who has performed in concert with many of the world's leading orchestras. A founding member of the Speculum Musicae, he was the principal oboist for the West Australian Symphony Orchestra, and a founding member of the New Music Ensemble.

items.sourceText: Auta Balefi is a fast developing district in central Nigeria. This town is located in Karu Local Government Area of Nasarawa State. It lies close to Abuja, the capital city of Nigeria in the Federal Capital Territory of Nigeria. Popular institutions located in this town include, Birgham University Campus (ECWA); Living Faith Church, Goshen City; The Redeemed Christian Church of God, Redemption Camp, Auta gurgu; and some developing estates. This district is rapidly growing due to its closeness to the Federal Capital Territory, Abuja.[1]

targets.targetText: Auta Balefi jẹ agbegbe to sese ndagbasoke ni agbedemeji Naijiria . Ilu yii wa ni ijoba ibile Karu ni Ipinle Nasarawa . O wa nitosi Abuja, olu ilu Naijiria ni Federal Capital Territory ti Nigeria. Awọn ile-iṣẹ olokiki ti o wa ni ilu yii pẹlu, Ile-ẹkọ giga Birgham University (ECWA); Ile-ijọsin Igbagbọ Alaaye, Ilu Goṣeni; Ile ijọsin Kristiẹni ti a rà pada, Ibudo irapada, Auta gurgu; ati diẹ ninu awọn ohun-ini idagbasoke. Agbegbe yii n dagba ni kiakia nitori isunmọ rẹ si Federal Capital Territory, Abuja. [1]

items.sourceText: Azaraegbelu is a village in southeastern Nigeria located near the city of Owerri.[1] The name has its origin in Emekuku. Azaraegbelu was the first son of Emekuku and was regarded as the most powerful.[2]

targets.targetText: Azaraegbelu jẹ abule kan ni guusu ila-oorun Naijiria ti o wa nitosi ilu Owerri . [1] Orukọ naa ni ipilẹṣẹ ni Emekuku . Azaraegbelu ni omo Emekuku akoko ti won si n gba gege bi alagbara julo. [2]

items.sourceText: Mahmoud Abdel-Aty is an Egyptian professor of mathematics and information science at Sohag University and the Mathematics Department at Zewail City of Science, Technology and Innovation. He is an elected fellow and the former North Africa Vice President of the African Academy of Sciences, the President of the Egyptian National Committee for the International Mathematical Union, and the Director of the Center for International Relations at Sohag University.[1][2][3]

targets.targetText: Mahmoud Abdel-Aty jẹ olukọ ọjọgbọn ara Egipti ti mathimatiki ati imọ-jinlẹ alaye ni Ile-ẹkọ giga Sohag ati Ẹka Iṣiro ni Ilu Zewail ti Imọ, Imọ-ẹrọ ati Innovation . O jẹ ẹlẹgbẹ ti a yan ati Igbakeji Alakoso Ariwa Afirika tẹlẹ ti Ile-ẹkọ giga ti Imọ-jinlẹ ti Afirika, Alakoso Igbimọ Orilẹ-ede Egypt fun International Mathematical Union, ati Oludari Ile-iṣẹ fun Ibatan Kariaye ni Ile-ẹkọ giga Sohag . [1] [2] [3]

items.sourceText: After his PhD, Salih returned to Sudan in 1973 and joined the Faculty of Engineering of the University of Khartoum as a Lecturer before becoming an associate professor in 1977, a head of the department of Civil Engineering in 1979, and a full professor in 1982. He became the University of Khartoum's Deputy Vice-Chancellor between 1990 and 1991. As of November 2022, he is a professor at the Department of Civil Engineering, University of Khartoum, and a member of the Governing Councils of the University of Khartoum and Sudan University of Science and Technology. He was also a professor at the College of Engineering, King Saud University, from 1982 until.[1][2][6]

targets.targetText: Lẹhin PhD rẹ, Salih pada si Sudan ni ọdun 1973 o si darapọ mọ Oluko ti Imọ-ẹrọ ti Ile-ẹkọ giga ti Khartoum gẹgẹbi Olukọni ṣaaju ki o to di alamọdaju ẹlẹgbẹ ni ọdun 1977, ori ti ẹka ti Imọ-iṣe Ilu ni 1979, ati olukọ ni kikun ni ọdun 1982. O di Igbakeji Alakoso Yunifasiti ti Khartoum laarin 1990 ati 1991. Ni Oṣu kọkanla ọdun 2022, o jẹ olukọ ọjọgbọn ni Ẹka ti Imọ-iṣe Ilu, Ile-ẹkọ giga ti Khartoum, ati ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti Awọn Igbimọ Alakoso ti Ile-ẹkọ giga ti Khartoum ati Ile-ẹkọ giga Sudan ti Imọ ati Imọ-ẹrọ. O tun jẹ olukọ ọjọgbọn ni College of Engineering, King Saud University, lati 1982 titi di.[5][4][6]

Lẹhin PhD rẹ, Salih pada si Sudan ni ọdun 1973 o si darapọ mọ Oluko ti Imọ-ẹrọ ti Ile-ẹkọ giga ti Khartoum gẹgẹbi Olukọni ṣaaju ki o to di alamọdaju ẹlẹgbẹ ni ọdun 1977, ori ti ẹka ti Imọ-iṣe Ilu ni 1979, ati olukọ ni kikun ni ọdun 1982. O di Igbakeji Igbakeji Yunifasiti ti Khartoum laarin 1990 ati 1991. O tun jẹ olukọ ọjọgbọn ni College of Engineering, King Saud University, lati 1982 titi di. [1] [2] [3]

items.sourceText: The organization is considered the highest academic institution in Sudan and works to support and promote scientific research and innovation in the country.[7] The main objectives of the Academy are to raise the standard of and further develop theoretical and applied research in Sudan, as well as to establish a national observatory for science, technology, and innovation.[19]

targets.targetText: A ṣe akiyesi ajo naa ni ile-ẹkọ giga ti o ga julọ ni Sudan ati pe o ṣiṣẹ lati ṣe atilẹyin ati igbega iwadii imọ-jinlẹ ati isọdọtun ni orilẹ-ede naa.[2] Awọn ibi-afẹde akọkọ ti Ile-ẹkọ giga ni lati gbe iwọnwọn soke ati idagbasoke imọ-jinlẹ ati iwadi ti a lo ni Sudan, ati lati fi idi akiyesi orilẹ-ede kan fun imọ-jinlẹ, imọ-ẹrọ, ati isọdọtun.[14]

items.sourceText: He obtained his first degree, B.Sc. in Engineering in Computer Science and Automatic Control from the Alexandria University, Egypt in 1988. He obtained his M.Sc and Ph.D. in Computer and Information Science from University of Pennsylvania in 1989 and 1991.[1][2][6][7]

targets.targetText: O gba oye akọkọ rẹ, B.Sc. ni Imọ-ẹrọ ni Imọ-ẹrọ Kọmputa ati Iṣakoso Aifọwọyi lati Ile-ẹkọ giga Alexandria, Egypt ni ọdun 1988. O gba M.Sc ati Ph.D. ni Kọmputa ati Imọ-ẹrọ Alaye lati University of Pennsylvania ni ọdun 1989 ati 1991. [1] [2] [3] [4]

O gba oye akọkọ rẹ, B.Sc. ni Imọ-ẹrọ ni Imọ-ẹrọ Kọmputa ati Iṣakoso Aifọwọyi lati Ile-ẹkọ giga Alexandria, Egypt ni ọdun 1988. O gba M.Sc ati Ph.D. ni Kọmputa ati Imọ-jinlẹ Alaye lati Ile-ẹkọ giga ti Pennsylvania ni ọdun 1989 ati 1991.[3][4][6][7]

items.sourceText: Toure has been a member of the International Centre for Pure and Applied Mathematics (CIMPA), and he has attended conferences and given lectures in various countries, including Japan, India, and France.[1] He is also a permanent secretary of the National Academy of Sciences of Burkina Faso.[8]

targets.targetText: Toure ti jẹ ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti Ile-iṣẹ International fun Pure ati Mathematics Applied (CIMPA), ati pe o ti lọ si awọn apejọ ati fun awọn ikowe ni ọpọlọpọ awọn orilẹ-ede, pẹlu Japan, India, ati France.[7] O tun jẹ akọwe titilai ti National Academy of Sciences of Burkina Faso.[8]

items.sourceText: Bankole went to New York City in September 1971 and enrolled in January 1972 at Fordham University. He graduated in June 1974 with a Bachelor of Science Degree in Accounting. He received his Master of Business Administration (MBA) in Finance and Investment from Baruch College in February 1976.

targets.targetText: Bankole lọ si Ilu New York ni Oṣu Kẹsan ọdun 1971 o si forukọsilẹ ni Oṣu Kini ọdun 1972 ni Ile-ẹkọ giga Fordham . O pari ile-iwe giga ni Oṣu Karun ọdun 1974 pẹlu Apon ti Imọ-jinlẹ ni Iṣiro . O gba Master of Business Administration (MBA) ni Isuna ati Idoko-owo lati Baruch College ni Kínní 1976.

items.sourceText: Ogbonna was appointed as the Director of the National Centre for Energy Research and Development from 2004 to 2009. In 2011, he was appointed the Head of Department of Electronic Engineering.[1][2]

targets.targetText: Ogbonna ni a yan gẹgẹbi Oludari Ile-iṣẹ ti Orilẹ-ede fun Iwadi Agbara ati Idagbasoke lati 2004 si 2009. Ni ọdun 2011, o jẹ olori ti Ẹka ti Imọ-ẹrọ Itanna.[2][5]

items.sourceText: Tsega was married in 1972 to Frances Lester, a distinguished doctor herself.[1][2] Together they had four children, Aida, Naomi, Yohannes and Yodit.[17] His daughter Aida Edemariam, editor and writer at The Guardian,[18] published The Wife's Tale: A Personal History in 2018,[19] which is the story of Tsega's mother, Yètèmegnu.[20]

targets.targetText: Tsega ti ṣe igbeyawo ni ọdun 1972 si Frances Lester, dokita olokiki kan funrararẹ.[6][16] Papọ wọn ni ọmọ mẹrin, Aida, Naomi, Yohannes ati Yodit.[17] Ọmọbinrin rẹ Aida Edemariam, olootu ati onkọwe ni The Guardian,[18] ṣe atẹjade Itan Iyawo: Itan Ti ara ẹni ni ọdun 2018,[19] eyiti o jẹ itan ti iya Tsega, Yètèmegnu.[20]

items.sourceText: Tsega was elected a Fellow of the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada in 1971,[1] a Fellow of The World Academy of Sciences in 1987,[24] and a Fellow of the African Academy of Sciences in 1988.[5]

targets.targetText: Tsega jẹ ẹlẹgbẹ ti Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada ni ọdun 1971,[5] Ẹlẹgbẹ kan ti Ile-ẹkọ giga ti Imọ-jinlẹ Agbaye ni 1987,[24] ati Ẹlẹgbẹ ti Ile-ẹkọ giga ti Imọ-jinlẹ Afirika ni ọdun 1988.[5]

items.sourceText: He obtained a Bachelor of Science in Mathematics and Physics with honours from McGill University in Montreal, Canada, in 1959, and a Master of Science in Meteorology with distinction from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in 1960. He went on to obtain a Doctor of Science in Meteorology from MIT in 1963.[4][2] He received the Carl-Gustaf Rossby Award for his thesis.[6]

targets.targetText: O gba ẹkọ ti imọ jinlẹ ni Iṣiro ati Fisiksi pẹlu ọlá lati Ile-ẹkọ giga McGill ni Montreal, Canada, ni ọdun 1959, ati Titunto si ti Imọ-jinlẹ ni Meteorology pẹlu iyatọ lati Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) ni 1960. O tẹsiwaju lati gba Dokita ti Imọ ni Meteorology lati MIT ni ọdun 1963. [1] [2] O gba aami eye Carl-Gustaf Rossby fun iwe afọwọkọ rẹ. [3]

O gba Apon ti Imọ-jinlẹ ni Iṣiro ati Fisiksi pẹlu awọn ọlá lati Ile-ẹkọ giga McGill ni Montreal, Canada, ni ọdun 1959, ati Titunto si ti Imọ-jinlẹ ni Meteorology pẹlu iyatọ lati Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) ni 1960. O tẹsiwaju lati gba Dokita ti Imọ ni Meteorology lati MIT ni ọdun 1963. [1] [2] O gba Aami Eye Carl-Gustaf Rossby fun iwe afọwọkọ rẹ. [3]

items.sourceText: Mokope Modjadji V (27 April 1937 – 28 June 2001) was the fifth Rain Queen of the Balobedu tribe in the Limpopo Province of South Africa from 1981 until her death in 2001.

targets.targetText: Mokope Modjadji V (27 Kẹrin 1937 – 28 Okudu 2001) jẹ ayaba Ojo karun ti ẹya Balobedu ni Limpopo Province ti South Africa lati ọdun 1981 titi o fi ku ni ọdun 2001.
Mokope Modjadji V (27 Kẹrin 1937 – 28 Okudu 2001) jẹ karun ti ẹya Balobeedu ni Limpopo Province ti South Africa lati ọdun 1981 titi o fi ku ni ọdun 2001.

items.sourceText: Jiří Oberfalzer (17 January 1954) is a Czech Republic Politician and the vice-president of the senate of Czech Republic he is a member of Member of the Senate of the Parliament of the Czech Republic and serves as a member of a Czech municipal council.[1][2]

targets.targetText: Jiří Oberfalzer (17 Oṣu Kini ọdun 1954) jẹ Oloṣelu Ilu Czech Republic ati igbakeji Aare ile igbimọ aṣofin ti Czech Republic o jẹ ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti Igbimọ Alagba ti Ile-igbimọ ti Czech Republic ati pe o ṣiṣẹ bi ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti igbimọ ilu Czech kan. [1] [2]

items.sourceText: We Don't Live Here Anymore is a 2018 Nigerian film directed by Tope Oshin and produced by Olumide Makanjuola, Bose Oshin and Tope Oshin. The drama is based on the story of two LGBT high school students Chidi Egwuonwu (Temidayo Akinboro) and Tolu Bajulaye (Francis Sule).[1] The boys are in love with each other and have to deal with discrimination regarding their relationship.[2][3]

targets.targetText: A Ko gbe Nihin mọ jẹ fiimu Naijiria 2018 ti Tope Oshin dari ti Olumide Makanjuola, Bose Oshin ati Tope Oshin ṣe. Ere naa da lori itan awọn ọmọ ile-iwe giga LGBT meji Chidi Egwuonwu (Temidayo Akinboro) ati Tolu Bajulaye (Francis Sule). Awọn ọmọkunrin wa ni ife pẹlu ara wọn ati ki o ni lati wo pẹlu iyasoto nipa wọn ibasepọ.

items.sourceText: Set in a remote village in North Africa, the story focuses on women who go on a sex strike against having to fetch water from a distant well. The story is an adaptation of the ancient greek comedy Lysistrata.

targets.targetText: Ṣeto ni abule ti o jina ni Ariwa Afirika, itan naa da lori awọn obinrin ti pinu pe awon yan ibalopo loodi ote won looru laati lo pon omi lati kanga ti o jina. Itan naa jẹ aṣamubadọgba ti awada Greek atijọ Lysistrata.

items.sourceText: Elliot was born to a Yoruba father from Olowogbowo in Lagos Island, Lagos and a mother from Illah in Oshimili North, Delta State .[4] He received his primary education at Air Force Primary School and later attended St John's College, both in Jos. He studied economics at Lagos State University and graduated in 2003.[5]

targets.targetText: Baba Elliot je Yoruba lati Olowogbowo ni Lagos Island, Eko, iya re wa lati Illah ni Oshimili North, Ipinle Delta . [1] O gba eko alakọbẹrẹ rẹ ni Air Force Primary School ati lẹhinna lọ si St John's College, mejeeji ni Jos . Ó kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ nípa ètò ọrọ̀ ajé ní Lagos State University, ó sì jáde ní ọdún 2003. [2]
