items.sourceText: Susan Diane Wojcicki (/wʊˈtʃɪtski/ wuu-CHITS-kee;[1] born July 5, 1968) is a Polish-American business executive who has been the CEO of YouTube since 2014. Her net worth was estimated at $765 million in 2022.[2]

targets.targetText: Susan Diane Wojcicki / / w ʊˈtʃɪtski / wuu- CHITS - wuu- ; [1] ti a bi ni Oṣu Keje ọjọ 5, ọdun 1968) jẹ oludari iṣowo ara ilu Polandii-Amẹrika ti o ti jẹ Alakoso YouTube lati ọdun 2014. Iye iye rẹ jẹ $ 765 million ni ọdun 2022. [2]

Susan Diane Wojcicki / / w ʊˈtʃɪtski / wuu- CHITS - wuu- ; [1] tí a bi ní Oṣu Keje ọjọ 5, ọ̀dun 1968) jẹ́ olùdarí i iṣowo ara ìlú Polandii-Amẹrika tí o ti jẹ́ Alakoso YouTube láti ọdún 2014. Gbogbo akojopo rẹ jẹ́ $ 765 million ni ọdún 2022. [2]

items.sourceText: In London, he founded the Hull Shakespeare Society, of which Sir Henry Irving was the first President. Representing his political interests and considerable British interest in the Orient, he founded the Anglo-Ottoman Society, London. Its members included Lords Newton, Lamington, Stourton and Mowbray.

targets.targetText: Ni Ilu Lọndọnu, o da Hull Shakespeare Society silẹ, eyiti Sir Henry Irving jẹ Alakoso akọkọ. Ni aṣoju awọn anfani iṣelu rẹ ati iwulo Ilu Gẹẹsi nla ni Ila-oorun, o da Anglo-Ottoman Society silẹ, Lọndọnu. Awọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ rẹ pẹlu Lords Newton, Lamington, Stourton ati Mowbray.

Ni Ilu Lọndọn, o da egbe Hull Shakespeare Society silẹ, eyiti Sir Henry Irving jẹ Alakoso akọkọ. Ni eyi ti o fi anfani oṣelu rẹ han ati iwulo Ilu Gẹẹsi nla ni Ila-oorun, o da Anglo-Ottoman Society, London sile. Awọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ rẹ pẹlu Lords Newton, Lamington, Stourton ati Mowbray.

items.sourceText: Muhammadu Bellopronunciationⓘ (Arabic: محمد بلو) was the second Sultan of Sokoto[2] and reigned from 1817 until 1837. He was also an active writer of history, poetry, and Islamic studies. He was the son and primary aide to Usman dan Fodio, the founder of the Sokoto Caliphate and the first Sultan.[3] During his reign, he encouraged the spread of Islam throughout the region, increasing education for both men and women, and the establishment of Islamic courts. He died on October 25, 1837, and was succeeded by his brother Abu Bakr Atiku and then his son, Aliyu Babba.[4]

targets.targetText: Muhammadu Bello ( Arabic </link> ) jẹ Sultan keji ti ìlú Sokoto [1] ó sì jẹ́ ọba láti 1817 Títí di 1837. Ó tún jẹ onkọwe ti nṣiṣe lọwọ ti itan, ewi, ati awọn ẹkọ Islam . Oun ni ọmọ ati oluranlọwọ akọkọ si Usman dan Fodio, oludasile Sokoto Caliphate ati Sultan akọkọ. [2] Ni akoko ijọba rẹ, o ṣe iwuri fun itankale Islam ni gbogbo agbegbe, jijẹ ẹkọ fun awọn ọkunrin ati awọn obinrin, ati idasile awọn ile-ẹjọ Islam. O ku ni Oṣu Kẹwa Ọjọ 25, Ọdun 1837, arakunrin rẹ Abu Bakr Atiku si rọpo rẹ ati lẹhinna ọmọ rẹ, Aliyu Babba . [3]

Muhammadu Bello pronunciation ( Arabic </link> ) je Sultan keji ti Sokoto [1] o si joba lati 1817 titi di 1837. O tun jẹ onkọwe ti nṣiṣe lọwọ ti itan, ewi, ati awọn ẹkọ Islam . Oun ni ọmọ ati oluranlọwọ akọkọ si Usman dan Fodio, oludasile Sokoto Caliphate ati Sultan akọkọ. [2] Ni akoko ijọba rẹ, o ṣe iwuri fun itankale Islam ni gbogbo agbegbe, jijẹ ẹkọ fun awọn ọkunrin ati awọn obinrin, ati idasile awọn ile-ẹjọ Islam. O ku ni Oṣu Kẹwa Ọjọ 25, Ọdun 1837, arakunrin rẹ Abu Bakr Atiku si rọpo rẹ ati lẹhinna ọmọ rẹ, Aliyu Babba . [3]

items.sourceText: Bara is a town in Oyo State of southwestern Nigeria.[1] It is located just west of the Oko-Iressa-Aadu Road.[2] The majority of the people are members of the Yoruba ethnic group. Most of the people are employed in agriculture with locally produced yams, cassava, maize, and tobacco.

targets.targetText: Bara je ilu ni Ipinle Oyo ni guusu iwo oorun Naijiria . [1] O wa ni iwọ-oorun ti opopona Oko-Iressa-Aadu. [2] Pupọ julọ awọn eniyan jẹ ọmọ ẹya Yoruba . Pupọ ninu awọn eniyan naa ni iṣẹ-ogbin pẹlu iṣu iṣu ti agbegbe, gbaguda, agbado, ati taba .

Bara je ilu ni Ipinle Oyo ni guusu iwo oorun Naijiria.[1] O wa ni iwọ-oorun ti opopona Oko-Iressa-Aadu.[2] Pupọ julọ awọn eniyan jẹ ọmọ ẹya Yoruba. Pupọ ninu awọn eniyan naa ni iṣẹ-ogbin pẹlu iṣu iṣu ti agbegbe, gbaguda, agbado, ati taba.

items.sourceText: Nosa Omoregie, professionally known as Nosa, is a Nigerian recording artist, singer, songwriter and performer. He is currently signed to Warner Music Group African partner, Chocolate City.[1][2]

targets.targetText: Nosa Omoregie, ti a mọ ni iṣẹ-ṣiṣe bi Nosa, jẹ olorin gbigbasilẹ Naijiria, akọrin, akọrin ati oṣere. O ti wa ni Lọwọlọwọ wole si Warner Music Group African alabaṣepọ, Chocolate City . [1] [2]
Nosa Omoregie, tí a mọ̀ sí Nosa, jẹ olórin Naijiria, akọrin, àti òṣẹ̀ré. O ti wa ni Lọwọlọwọ wole si Warner Music Group African alabaṣepọ, Chocolate City . [1] [2]

items.sourceText: Shahida El-Baz (Arabic: شهيدة الباز; 2 November 1938 - 21 October 2021)[1] was an Egyptian feminist[2] who wrote many books on Arab women's issues.[3][4] El-Baz was the General Director of the Arab and African Research Center in Cairo, Egypt.[5][6] She was a member of the General Assembly establishing the Arab Society for Sociology,[6] and Council for the Development of Social Science Research in Africa (CODESRIA) Executive Committee between 2008 and 2011.[1]

targets.targetText: Shahida El-Baz (Larubawa: شهيدة الباز; 2 Oṣu kọkanla 1938 - 21 Oṣu Kẹwa Ọdun 2021)[1] jẹ obinrin ara Egipti[2] ti o kọ ọpọlọpọ awọn iwe lori awọn ọran obinrin Arab.[3][4] El-Baz jẹ Oludari Gbogbogbo ti Arab ati Ile-iṣẹ Iwadi Afirika ni Cairo, Egypt.[5][6] O jẹ ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti Apejọ Gbogbogbo ti n ṣe agbekalẹ Ẹgbẹ Arab fun Sociology,[6] ati Igbimọ fun Idagbasoke Iwadi Imọ-jinlẹ Awujọ ni Afirika (CODESRIA) Igbimọ Alase laarin 2008 ati 2011.[1]

Shahida El-Baz ( Arabic </link> ; 2 Oṣu kọkanla 1938 - 21 Oṣu Kẹwa Ọdun 2021) [1] jẹ obinrin ara Egipti [2] ti o kọ ọpọlọpọ awọn iwe lori awọn ọran obinrin Arab. [3] [4] El-Baz jẹ Oludari Gbogbogbo ti Arab ati Ile-iṣẹ Iwadi Afirika ni Cairo, Egypt. [5] [6] O jẹ ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti Apejọ Gbogbogbo ti o ṣeto Ẹgbẹ Arab fun Sociology, [6] ati Igbimọ fun Idagbasoke Iwadi Imọ-jinlẹ Awujọ ni Afirika (CODESRIA) Igbimọ Alase laarin 2008 ati 2011. [1]

items.sourceText: Mairo Ese was born on 27 May 1982 to Mr and Mrs Ese in Lagos State, Nigeria. He hails from Isoko South Local Government Area, Delta State.[5][6]

targets.targetText: A bí Mairo Ese ní 27 May 1982 sí Ọ̀gbẹ́ni àti Iyaafin Ese ní Ìpìnlẹ̀ Èko, Nigeria . Ó wá láti isoko South Local Government Area, Delta State . [1] [2]
A bi Mairo Ese ni 27 May 1982 si Ọgbẹni ati Iyaafin Ese ni Ipinle Eko, Nigeria . O wa lati isoko South Local Government Area, Delta State . [1] [2]

items.sourceText: Femi Fadugba (born 1987) is a British writer and physicist based in London. His first book, The Upper World, was published by Penguin Random House in 2021. It was turned into a film by Netflix, starring Daniel Kaluuya.

targets.targetText: Femi Fadugba (ti a bi ni 1987) jẹ onkọwe ara ilu Gẹẹsi ati onímọ-fisiksi ti o da ni Ilu Lọndọnu. Iwe akọkọ rẹ, The Oke World, ni a tẹjade nipasẹ Penguin Random House ni ọdun 2021. O ti wa ni tan-sinu fiimu kan nipasẹ Netflix, pẹlu Daniel Kaluuya .

Femi Fadugba (ti a bi ni 1987) jẹ onkọwe ilẹ̀ Gẹẹsi ati onímọ-fisiiki ti ó ń gbé ní ìlú Lọndọnu. Iwe akọkọ rẹ, The Oke World, ni a tẹjade nipasẹ Penguin Random House ni ọdun 2021. O ti wa ni tan-sinu fiimu kan nipasẹ Netflix, pẹlu Daniel Kaluuya .

items.sourceText: Abdulkarim Saliu is a Nigerian politician from Kogi State, who represented the Adavi/Okehi constituency in the House of Representatives at the National Assembly from 2007 to 2011. He served under the platform of the Alliance for Democracy. He was succeeded by Badamasuiy Abdulrahaman.[1]

targets.targetText: Abdulkarim Saliu je oloselu omo Naijiria lati ipinle Kogi, eni to soju agbegbe Adavi/Okehi ni ile igbimo asofin ni ile igbimo asofin agba lati 2007 si 2011. O ṣiṣẹ labẹ ipilẹ ti Alliance for Democracy . Badamasuiy Abdulrahaman ni o tele e. [1]

Abdulkarim Saliu je oloselu omo Nàìjíríà lati ipinle Kogi, eni to ṣojú àgbègbè Adavi/Okehi ni ile ìgbìmọ̀ asofin ni ile ìgbìmọ̀ asofin àgbà lati 2007 si 2011. O ṣiṣẹ labẹ ipilẹ ti Alliance for Democracy . Badamasuiy Abdulrahaman ni o tele e. [1]

items.sourceText: Ossai Nicholas Ossai is a Nigerian politician. He was a member representing Ndokwa East/Ndokwa West/Ukwuani Federal Constituency in the House of Representatives.[1][2]

targets.targetText: Ossai Nicholas Ossai je oloselu omo Naijiria . O jẹ ọmọ ẹgbẹ ti o nsoju Ndokwa East/Ndokwa West/Ukwuani ni ile ìgbìmò aṣòfin àgbà[1] [2]

items.sourceText: Yewande was born in Lagos State but hails from Ososa-Ijebu in Ogun State southwestern Nigeria.[3] She attended Bright star nursery and primary school, before proceeding for her secondary education at Bright Star Comprehensive High School. She obtained a Bachelor of Arts (B.A) degree in Mass communications from Babcock University. Yewande Adekoya is happily married with children.[4]

targets.targetText: Yewande ni a bi ni Ipinle Eko sugbon o wa lati ilu Ososa-Ijebu ni Ipinle Ogun ni guusu iwo oorun Nigeria . [1] O lọ si ile-iwe nọọsi irawọ Bright ati ile-iwe alakọbẹrẹ, ṣaaju ṣiwaju fun eto-ẹkọ giga rẹ ni Ile-iwe Giga ti Okeerẹ Bright Star. O gba oye Bachelor of Arts (BA) ni Mass Communication lati Ile-ẹkọ giga Babcock . Yewande Adekoya ti se igbeyawo o si ti bi omo. [2]

Yewande ni a bi ni Ipinle Eko sugbon o wa lati ilu Ososa-Ijebu ni Ipinle Ogun ni guusu iwo oorun Nigeria . O gba oye Bachelor of Arts (BA) ni awọn ibaraẹnisọrọ Mass lati Ile-ẹkọ giga Babcock . Ayara Yewande Adekoya ti gbeyawo pelu awon omo. [2]

items.sourceText: In 2013, Mercy Aigbe married a Nigerian hotelier, Lanre Gentry, and has two children (Juwon Gentry and Michelle Aigbe)[14] and three stepdaughters.[15][16][17] In 2017, she shared photos of herself after allegedly being assaulted by her husband. She consequently separated from her husband due to claims of domestic violence, and started a campaign against it.[18][19] Mercy Aigbe acquired a multi-million naira new mansion in 2018.[20]

targets.targetText: Ni ọdun 2013, Mercy Aigbe fẹ hotẹẹli hotẹẹli ile Naijiria kan, Lanre Gentry, o si ni ọmọ meji (Juwon Gentry ati Michelle Aigbe) [1] ati awọn ọmọbinrin mẹta. [2] [3] [4] Ni ọdun 2017, o pin awọn fọto ti ara rẹ lẹhin titẹnumọ pe ọkọ rẹ lu u. Nitori naa o yapa kuro lọdọ ọkọ rẹ nitori awọn ẹtọ ti iwa-ipa abele, o si bẹrẹ ipolongo si i. [5] [6] Mercy Aigbe ti ra ile nla tuntun ti ọpọlọpọ-miliọnu naira ni ọdun 2018. [7]

Ni ọdun 2013, Mercy Aigbe fẹ onisowo ile Naijiria kan, Lanre Gentry, o si ni ọmọ meji (Juwon Gentry ati Michelle Aigbe) [1] ati awọn ọmọbinrin mẹta. items.sourceText: She attended The Harlem School of the Arts, followed by the Fiorello H. LaGuardia High School. Hadera went on to receive an MFA in Text and Performance studies from RADA/King's College London.[7]

items.sourceText: Amenze Aighewi (born 21 November 1991) is a Nigerian footballer who played as a forward for the Nigeria women's national football team. She was part of the team at the 2011 FIFA Women's World Cup.[1] On club level she plays for Rivers Angels in Nigeria.[2]

targets.targetText: Amenze Aighewi (ti a bi ni ọjọ kọkanla oṣu kọkanla ọdun 1991) jẹ agbabọọlu ọmọ orilẹ-ede Naijiria kan ti o n gba apa iwaju fun ẹgbẹ agbabọọlu orilẹ-ede Naijiria . O jẹ okan ninu awon ti o gba boolu ni FIFA FIFA World Cup ni 2011 . [1] Lori ipele ẹgbẹ o nṣere fun Awọn angẹli Rivers ni Nigeria. [2]

Amenze Aighewi (ti a bi ni ọjọ kọkanla oṣu kọkanla ọdun 1991) jẹ agbabọọlu ọmọ orilẹ-ede Naijiria kan ti o ṣere siwaju fun ẹgbẹ agbabọọlu orilẹ-ede Naijiria . O jẹ apakan ti ẹgbẹ ni FIFA FIFA World Cup ni 2011 . [1] Lori ipele ẹgbẹ o nṣere fun Awọn angẹli Rivers ni Nigeria. [2]

items.sourceText: Sope was the Head of Research at the Nigerian Economic Summit Group, Lagos from 2014 till 2016. In 2016, she moved to South Africa and was appointed a professor of law at Stellenbosch University, South Africa in 2017, where she is the Head of the department of Mercantile law, and the Deputy Director of the African Procurement Law Unit.[4]

targets.targetText: Won yan Sope ni Oludari Iwadi ni Ẹgbẹ Apejọ Iṣowo ti Ilu Naijiria, Lagos lati ọdun 2014 si ọdun 2016. [1] Ni ọdun 2016, Sope gbe si South Africa ati pe wọn yan alamọdaju ofin ni Yunifasiti Stellenbosch, South Africa ni ọdun 2017, nibiti o ti jẹ Ori ti ẹka ti ofin Mercantile, ati Igbakeji Oludari Ẹka Iṣowo Ofin Afirika. [2]

Sope ni Oludari Iwadi ni Ẹgbẹ Apejọ Iṣowo ti Ilu Naijiria, Lagos lati ọdun 2014 si ọdun 2016. Ni ọdun 2016, o lọ si South Africa ati pe wọn yan alamọdaju ofin ni Yunifasiti Stellenbosch, South Africa ni ọdun 2017, nibiti o ti jẹ Ori ti ẹka ti ofin Mercantile, ati Igbakeji Oludari Ẹka Iṣowo Ofin Afirika. [1]

items.sourceText: Tunde Folawiyo was educated at the London School of Economics, where he obtained a B.Sc degree in Economics in 1980, and an LL.B in 1984. He obtained an LL.M degree from the University College London in June 1985.[1]

targets.targetText: Tunde Folawiyo lo si Ile -iwe ti Iṣowo ti London, nibi ti o ti gba oye B.Sc ni Iṣowo ni 1980, ati LL B ni ọdun 1984. O gba LL M degree lati Ile- ẹkọ giga Yunifasiti ti London ni Oṣu Karun ọjọ 1985. [1]

Tunde Folawiyo ti kọ ẹkọ ni Ile -iwe ti Iṣowo ti London, nibi ti o ti gba oye B.Sc ni Iṣowo ni 1980, ati LL kan. B ni ọdun 1984. O gba LL kan. M degree lati Ile- ẹkọ giga Yunifasiti ti London ni Oṣu Karun ọjọ 1985. [1]

items.sourceText: It was found by the descendants of Oduduwa five hundred years ago. The founders left Ile-ife, to settle at Otan-Ile before moving to Otan Koto (present day Otan Ayegabaju). Otan is a culturally rich town whose population is mostly made up of Ijesas and the Oyo tribal group.[citation needed]

targets.targetText: O ti rii nipasẹ awọn ọmọ Oduduwa ni ọdun marun sẹyin. Awọn oludasilẹ naa fi Ile-ife silẹ, lati joko si Otan-Ile ṣaaju ki wọn to lọ si Otan Koto (Otan Ayegabaju loni-in). Otan jẹ ilu ọlọrọ ti aṣa ti olugbe rẹ jẹ julọ ti Ijesas ati ẹgbẹ ẹya Oyo.

Awọn ọmọ Oduduwa ni won ri ni ọdun ogorun marun sẹyin. Awọn oludasilẹ naa fi Ile-ife silẹ, lati joko si Otan-Ile ṣaaju ki wọn to lọ si Otan Koto (Otan Ayegabaju loni-in). Otan jẹ ilu ọlọrọ ti aṣa ti awon olugbe rẹ jẹ julọ ti Ijesas ati ẹgbẹ ẹya Oyo.

items.sourceText: Simbine again broke the South African 100m record with a time of 9.89 seconds at the Gyulai István Memorial in Székesfehérvár on 18 July 2016.[7] He finished fifth in 9.94 seconds in the 100 m final of the 2016 Olympics in Rio de Janeiro on 14 August 2016.[8]

targets.targetText: Simbine tun bu igbasilẹ 100m South Africa pẹlu iṣẹju-aaya 9.89 ni Gyulai István Memorial ni Székesfehérvár ni ọjọ 18 Oṣu Keje ọdun 2016. [1] O gbe ipo karun ni iṣẹju-aaya 9.94 ni asekagba 100 m ti Olimpiiki 2016 ni Rio de Janeiro ni ọjọ 14 Oṣu Kẹjọ ọdun 2016. [2]

Simbine tun bu igbasilẹ 100m South Africa pẹlu akoko 9.89 iṣẹju-aaya ni Gyulai István Memorial ni Székesfehérvár ni ọjọ 18 Oṣu Keje ọdun 2016. [1] O pari karun ni iṣẹju-aaya 9.94 ni 100 m ipari ti Olimpiiki 2016 ni Rio de Janeiro ni ọjọ 14 Oṣu Kẹjọ ọdun 2016. [2]

items.sourceText: Halimatu Ibrahim Ayinde (born 16 May 1995) is a Nigerian professional footballer who plays as a midfielder for Eskilstuna United DFF and the Nigeria women's national team. She previously played for Western New York Flash in the United States, and Delta Queens in Nigeria.

targets.targetText: Halimatu Ibrahim Ayinde (ti a bi ni ọjọ kerindinlogun oṣu May odun 1995) jẹ agbabọọlu ọmọ orilẹede Naijiria ti o nṣere bii agbabọọlu fun Eskilstuna United DFF ati ẹgbẹ agbabọọlu obinrin Naijiria . O ṣere tẹlẹ fun Western New York Flash ni Amẹrika, ati Delta Queens ni Nigeria.

Halimatu Ibrahim Ayinde (ti a bi 16 May 1995) jẹ agbabọọlu agbabọọlu ọmọ orilẹede Naijiria ti o nṣere bii agbabọọlu fun Eskilstuna United DFF ati ẹgbẹ agbabọọlu obinrin Naijiria . O ṣere tẹlẹ fun Western New York Flash ni Amẹrika, ati Delta Queens ni Nigeria.

items.sourceText: Jean-Pierre Abossolo-Ze (born 18 December 1956) is a Cameroonian sprinter. He competed in the men's 4 × 400 metres relay at the 1984 Summer Olympics.[1]

targets.targetText: Jean-Pierre Abossolo-Ze (ti a bi 18 Oṣu kejila ọdun 1956) jẹ asare ọmọ ilu Kamẹru . O dije ninu isọdọtun awọn mita 4 × 400 awọn ọkunrin ni Awọn Olimpiiki Igba ooru 1984 . [1]
Jean-Pierre Abossolo-Ze (ti a bi ni ọjọ kejidinlogun Oṣu kejila ọdun 1956) jẹ asare orilẹ-ede Kamẹru . O dije ninu isọdọtun mita 4 × 400 awọn ọkunrin ni Olimpiiki Igba ooru 1984 . [1]

items.sourceText: As a part of the Cameroonian 4 × 100 metres relay team he finished fifth at the 2012 African Championships and sixth at the 2014 African Championships.[1]

targets.targetText: Gẹgẹbi apakan ti ẹgbẹ agbapada mita 4 × 100 ti Ilu Kamẹrika o pari karun ni Awọn idije Afirika 2012 ati kẹfa ni Awọn idije Afirika 2014 . [1]
Gẹgẹbi ara ti ẹgbẹ agbapada mita 4 × 100 ti orilẹ-ede Kamẹru, o pari ni ipo kaarun ninu idije Afirika 2012 ati ipo kẹfa ni idije Afirika 2014 . [1]

items.sourceText: From 1967 to 1974, Obasi was a World Meteorological Organisation/United Nations Development Programme expert and a senior lecturer at the University of Nairobi in Kenya. He also served as acting head of the Department of Meteorology in Kenya from 1972 to 1973, and as professor and chairman of the department from 1974 to 1976. Additionally, he was dean of the Faculty of Science at the University of Nairobi in Kenya from 1967 to 1976. Obasi also worked as an adviser in meteorology and assistant director for the Nigerian government from 1976 to 1978.[1][8]

targets.targetText: Lati ọdun 1967 si 1974, Obasi jẹ Ajo Agbaye ti Oju-ọjọ / Amọye Eto Idagbasoke United Nations ati olukọni agba ni University of Nairobi ni Kenya. O tun ṣiṣẹ bi adari adari Ẹka ti Oju-ọjọ ni Kenya lati ọdun 1972 si 1973, ati bi ọjọgbọn ati alaga ti ẹka lati 1974 si 1976. Ni afikun, o jẹ olori ti Oluko Imọ-jinlẹ ni Ile-ẹkọ giga ti Nairobi ni Kenya lati ọdun 1967 si 1976. Obasi tun sise bi oludamoran nipa oju ojo oju ojo ati oluranlọwọ oludari fun ijoba Naijiria lati 1976 si 1978. [1] [2]

Lati ọdun 1967 si 1974, Obasi jẹ Ajo Agbaye ti Oju-ọjọ / Amọye Eto Idagbasoke United Nations ati olukọni agba ni University of Nairobi ni Kenya. O tun ṣiṣẹ bi adari Ẹka ti Oju-ọjọ ni Kenya lati ọdun 1972 si 1973, ati bi ọjọgbọn ati alaga ti ẹka naa lati 1974 si 1976. Ni afikun, o jẹ olori ti oluko imọ ijinlẹ ni Ile-ẹkọ giga ti Nairobi ni Kenya lati ọdun 1967 si 1976. Obasi tun sise bi oludamoran nipa oju ojo ati oluranlọwọ oludari fun ijoba Naijiria lati 1976 si 1978. [1] [2]

items.sourceText: He was born in Karlovy Vary, Czechoslovakia [now Czech Republic] on 17 January 1954.[3] He is a Graduate Of the Charles University of Prague from the faculty of Mathematics and Physics. Mr Oberfalzer is blessed with five children.[4]

items.sourceText: In early 2008, the film, whose working title had been A Tale of Two Sisters, was renamed to The Uninvited.[4]

items.sourceText: Born in Lakeland, Florida, Waldon graduated from Boys High School in Brooklyn, New York in 1954 and went on to earn a B.S. from John Jay College in New York City in 1968 and a J.D. from New York Law School in New York City in 1973.

targets.targetText: Tí a bí sí Lakeland, Florida, Waldon parí ile-iwe giga Boys ní Brooklyn, New York ní ọdún 1954 ó tẹ̀síwájú láti gba BS láti Ile-ẹkọ giga John Jay ní Ìlú New York ní ọdún 1968 àti JD kan láti Ile-iwe Ofin New York ní Ìlú New York ní ọdún 1973 .

Ti a bi ni Lakeland, Florida, Waldon pari ile-iwe giga Boys ni Brooklyn, New York ni ọdun 1954 o tẹsiwaju lati jo'gun BS lati Ile-ẹkọ giga John Jay ni Ilu New York ni ọdun 1968 ati JD kan lati Ile-iwe Ofin New York ni Ilu New York ni ọdun 1973 .

items.sourceText: Amina Abubakar is a Kenyan associate Professor of Psychology and Public Health at Pwani University. She is a research fellow at the Kenya Medical Research Institute. Her research considers the developmental delay in children who have HIV, malnutrition and malaria. She is an honorary fellow at the University of Oxford.

targets.targetText: Amina Abubakar jẹ Ọjọgbọn ẹlẹgbẹ Kenya kan ti Ẹkọ nipa Imọ-jinlẹ ati Ilera Awujọ ni Ile-ẹkọ giga Pwani . O jẹ ẹlẹgbẹ iwadii ni Ile-ẹkọ Iwadi Iṣoogun ti Kenya . Iwadi rẹ ṣe akiyesi idaduro idagbasoke ninu awọn ọmọde ti o ni kokoro-arun HIV, aito ounjẹ ati iba . O jẹ ẹlẹgbẹ ọlá ni University of Oxford .

Amina Abubakar jẹ́ Ọ̀jọ̀gbọn Kenya kan ti Ẹ̀kọ nipa Imọ-jinlẹ ati Ilera Awujọ ni Ile-ẹkọ giga Pwani . Ó jẹ́ ẹlẹ́diwadii ni Ile-ẹkọ Iwadi Iṣoogun ti Kenya . Iwadi rẹ ṣe akiyesi idaduro idagbasoke ninu awọn ọmọde ti o ni kokoro-arun HIV, aito ounjẹ ati iba . O jẹ ẹlẹgbẹ ọlá ni University of Oxford .

items.sourceText: Chinwe Clara Nnabuife (born September 28, 1971)  is a Nigerian politician and lawmaker. She currently represents Orumba North/Orumba South under the Young Progressives Party at the Nigeria 10th National Assembly.[1][2]

items.sourceText: Maureen Okpoko is a Nigerian actress. In 2016, she was nominated for Africa Movie Academy Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role.

items.sourceText: In 1996, Akunyili became Zonal Secretary of the Petroleum Special Trust Fund (P.T.F), coordinating projects funded by profits from oil in Nigeria's South Eastern States. In 2001, President Olusegun Obasanjo appointed her the Drector-General of the National Agency for Food and Drug Administration and Control (NAFDAC).[1]

targets.targetText: Ni ọdun 1996, Akunyili di Akowe agbegbe ti Petroleum Special Trust Fund (PTF), ti n ṣakoso awọn iṣẹ akanṣe nipasẹ awọn èrè lati epo ni awọn ipinlẹ Guusu ila oorun Naijiria. Ni ọdun 2001, Aare Olusegun Obasanjo fi ṣe Oludari Gbogbogbo ti National Agency for Food and Drug Administration and Control (NAFDAC). [1]

Ni ọdun 1996, Akunyili di Akowe agbegbe ti Fund Trust Special Trust Fund (PTF), ti n ṣakoso awọn iṣẹ akanṣe nipasẹ awọn èrè lati epo ni awọn ipinlẹ Guusu ila oorun Naijiria. Ni ọdun 2001, Aare Olusegun Obasanjo fi i ṣe Oludari Gbogbogbo ti National Agency for Food and Drug Administration and Control (NAFDAC). [1]

items.sourceText: Akram Zuway (Arabic: أكرم زوي; born 24 December 1991), is a Libyan footballer who plays for Kazma as a striker.

targets.targetText: Akram Zuway ( Arabic ; ti a bi 24 Oṣu kejila ọdun 1991), jẹ agbabọọlu Libyan kan ti o ṣere fun Kazma bi agbabọọlu .
Akram Zuway ( Arabic ; ti a bi ni ọjọ kerinlelogun Oṣu kejila ọdun 1991), jẹ agbabọọlu Libyan kan ti o nngba bọọlu fun Kazma bi agbabọọlu .

items.sourceText: During the 2012–13 season, Niyungeko led Flambeau de l'Est to their first Burundi Premier League title, three years after formation.[1]

targets.targetText: Lakoko akoko 2012–13, Niyungeko dari egbe agbabọọlu Flambeau de l'Est si akọle Premier League Burundi akọkọ wọn, ọdun mẹta lẹhin idasile. [1]
Lakoko akoko 2012–13, Niyungeko dari Flambeau de l'Est si akọle Premier League Burundi akọkọ wọn, ọdun mẹta lẹhin idasile. [1]

items.sourceText: Mama Moluh (born 26 March 1958) is a Cameroonian sprinter. He competed in the men's 400 metres at the 1984 Summer Olympics.[1]

targets.targetText: Mama Moluh (ti a bi 26 Oṣu Kẹta ọdun 1958) jẹ asare ọmọ ilu Kamẹru . O dije ninu awọn mita 400 awọn ọkunrin ni Awọn Olimpiiki Igba ooru 1984 . [1]
Mama Moluh (ti a bi ni ọjọ kerindinlogbon Oṣu Kẹta ọdun 1958) jẹ asare orilẹ-ede Kamẹru . O dije ninu ìdíje mita 400 awọn ọkunrin ni Olimpiiki Igba ooru 1984 . [1]

items.sourceText: Njuh Venatius (born (1988-04-13)13 April 1988) is a Cameroonian male weightlifter, competing in the 69 kg category and representing Cameroon at international competitions. He competed at world championships, most recently at the 2010 World Weightlifting Championships.[1]

targets.targetText: Njuh Venatius (ti a bi (1988-04-13 ) ) je omo orile-ede Cameroon ti o gbe eru okunrin, ti o nfigagba ninu eya 69 kg ati ti o nsoju Cameroon ni awọn idije agbaye. O dije ni awọn ere-idije agbaye, laipẹ julọ ni Awọn aṣaju-idije iwuwo Agbaye 2010 . [1]

Njuh Venatius (ti a bi ni (1988-04-13 ) ) je omo orile-ede Cameroon ti o n gbe eru wiwo okunrin, ti o nfigagba ninu eya 69 kg ati ti o nsoju orilẹ-ede Cameroon ni awọn idije agbaye. O dije ni ere-idije agbaye, laipẹ o jẹ aṣaju-idije iwuwo Agbaye 2010 . [1]

items.sourceText: He represented Chad's national basketball team at the 2011 FIBA Africa Championship in Antananarivo, Madagascar, where he was his team's best rebounder and free throw shooter.[1]

targets.targetText: O ṣe aṣoju ẹgbẹ agbabọọlu orilẹ-ede Chad ni 2011 FIBA Africa Championship ni Antananarivo, Madagascar, nibiti o ti jẹ atungba ti o dara julọ ti ẹgbẹ rẹ ati eniti o mo bọọlu ofe ju. [1]
O ṣe aṣoju ẹgbẹ agbabọọlu orilẹ-ede Chad ni 2011 FIBA Africa Championship ni Antananarivo, Madagascar, nibiti o ti jẹ agbapada ti o dara julọ ti ẹgbẹ rẹ ati ayanbon ọfẹ ọfẹ. [1]

items.sourceText: During the administration of Navy Capt. Mike Akhigbe, the Office was transformed into a full-fledged Ministry of Home Affairs and Tourism, with Mr. Franklin Adejuwon as First Honourable Commissioner and Mr Musuliu Obanikoro as Second Honourable Commissioner.

targets.targetText: Nigba isakoso ti ọgagun Capt. Mike Akhigbe, Office naa ti yipada si Ile-iṣẹ ti Ile-iṣẹ Abele ati Irin-ajo, pẹlu Ọgbẹni Franklin Adejuwon gẹgẹbi Komisona Ọla akọkọ ati Ọgbẹni Musuliu Obanikoro gẹgẹbi Komisona Ọla Keji.

Nigba isakoso ti ọgagun Capt. Mike Akhigbe, Office naa ti yipada si Ile-iṣẹ ti Abele ati Irin-ajo, pẹlu Ọgbẹni Franklin Adejuwon gẹgẹbi Komisona Ọla akọkọ ati Ọgbẹni Musuliu Obanikoro gẹgẹbi Komisona Ọla Keji.

items.sourceText: The Lagos State Ministry of Special Duties is the state government ministry, charged with the responsibility to plan, devise and implement the state policies on Special Duties.[1][2]

targets.targetText: Ile -iṣẹ Ipinlẹ Eko ti Awọn iṣẹ pataki ni ile-iṣẹ ijọba ipinlẹ, ti o ni ojuse lati gbero, ṣe agbekalẹ ati imuse awọn eto imulo ipinlẹ lori Awọn iṣẹ akanṣe. [1] [2]
Ile -iṣẹ Ijoba ni Ipinlẹ Eko ti Awọn iṣẹ pataki ni o ni ojuse lati gbero, ṣe agbekalẹ ati imuse awọn eto imulo ipinlẹ lori Awọn iṣẹ akanṣe. [1] [2]

items.sourceText: Teye played for the Ghana Women's Premier League club Lady Strikers F.C..[1] In 2021, she was named "Player of the Month February".[2]

targets.targetText: Teye gbábọ́ọ̀lù fún ẹgbẹ́ agbábọ́ọ̀lù Premier League Women's Ghana Lady Strikers FC . Ní ọdún 2021, wọ́n fún ní orúkọ “Player of the month February”.
Teye ṣe bọọlu fun ẹgbẹ agbabọọlu Premier League Women's Ghana Lady Strikers FC . Ni ọdun 2021, o fun ni orukọ “Player of the month February”.

items.sourceText: SNAS has been involved in celebrating Sudan Week and organising the 3rd Community Lecture in collaboration with the Khartoum Institute for Scientific Research.[25]

targets.targetText: SNAS ti ni ipa ninu ayẹyẹ Ọsẹ Sudan ati siseto Ikẹkọ Agbegbe 3rd ni ifowosowopo pẹlu Ile-ẹkọ Khartoum fun Iwadi Imọ-jinlẹ . [1]
SNAS ti kopa ninu ayẹyẹ Ọsẹ Sudan ati siseto ikowe Agbegbe 3rd ni ifowosowopo pẹlu Ile-ẹkọ Khartoum fun Iwadi Imọ-jinlẹ.[20]

items.sourceText: Suad holds the role of treasurer at the Sudanese National Academy of Sciences, founded in August 2005 by a collective of Sudanese scientists.[2]

targets.targetText: Suad di ipa ti olutọju ni Ile-ẹkọ giga ti Orilẹ-ede Sudanese ti Awọn sáyẹnsì, ti a da ni Oṣu Kẹjọ ọdun 2005 nipasẹ apapọ awọn onimọ-jinlẹ ara ilu Sudan.￼
Suad ni ipa ti oluṣowo ni Ile-ẹkọ giga ti Orilẹ-ede Sudanese ti Awọn sáyẹnsì, ti a da ni Oṣu Kẹjọ ọdun 2005 nipasẹ apapọ awọn onimọ-jinlẹ Sudan . [1]

items.sourceText: The institution is a state owned polytechnic in Oyo state at South west region of Nigeria. It holds official recognition and accreditation from the National Board for Technical Education (NBTE) in Nigeria.[3].

targets.targetText: Ile-ẹkọ giga jẹ polytechnic ti ipinlẹ ni ipinlẹ Ọyọ ni ẹkun iwọ oorun guusu iwọ-oorun Naijiria . O ni idanimọ osise ati ifọwọsi lati ọdọ Igbimọ Orilẹ-ede fun Ẹkọ Imọ-ẹrọ (NBTE) ni Nigeria . [1] .
Ile-ẹkọ giga jẹ polytechnic ti ipinlẹ ni ipinlẹ Ọyọ ni ẹkun iwọ-oorun guusu iwọ-oorun Naijiria. O ni idanimọ osise ati ifọwọsi lati ọdọ Igbimọ Orilẹ-ede fun Ẹkọ Imọ-ẹrọ (NBTE) ni Nigeria..[3]

items.sourceText: Chineze Anyaene // ⓘ (born 28 December 1983) is a Nigerian filmmaker and film producer. She is best known for her 2010 critically acclaimed picture, Ijé: The Journey.

targets.targetText: Chineze Anyaene (ojoibi 28 December 1983) je onise fiimu ati olupilese fiimu. O jẹ olokiki julọ fun aworan ti o ni iyin ni 2010.
Chineze Anyaene // ⓘ</link> (ojoibi 28 December 1983) je onise fiimu ati olupilese fiimu. O jẹ olokiki julọ fun aworan ti o ni iyin ni 2010, Ijé: Irin-ajo naa .

items.sourceText: Lionheart was selected as the Nigerian entry for the Best International Feature Film at the 92nd Academy Awards.[8] It was the first time that Nigeria had submitted a film to the Oscars.[9] On 4 November 2019, the Academy disqualified the film as the majority of the dialogue is in English[10] and only about ten minutes of the film is in Igbo.[11]

targets.targetText: Lionheart ni a yan gẹgẹbi titẹsi orilẹ-ede Naijiria fun Fiimu Ẹya Kariaye Ti o dara julọ ni Awọn Awards 92nd Academy Awards . [1] O jẹ igba akọkọ ti Naijiria ti gbe fiimu kan silẹ si Oscars. [2] Ni ọjọ 4 Oṣu kọkanla ọdun 2019, Ile-ẹkọ giga kọ fiimu naa kuro nitori pe ọpọlọpọ ọrọ naa wa ni Gẹẹsi [3] ati pe bii iṣẹju mẹwa ti fiimu naa wa ni Igbo . [4]

Lionheart ni a yan gẹgẹbi ere orilẹ-ede Naijiria fun Fiimu Ẹya Kariaye Ti o dara julọ ni ami eye 92nd Academy Awards.[1]O jẹ igba akọkọ ti Naijiria ti gbe fiimu silẹ si Oscars.[2] Ni ọjọ keerin Oṣu kọkanla ọdun 2019, Ile-ẹkọ giga kọ fiimu naa kuro nitori pe ọpọlọpọ ọrọ naa wa ni Gẹẹsi[3] ati pe bii iṣẹju mẹwa ti fiimu naa wa ni Igbo.[4]

items.sourceText: Abdulraheem Medinat Motunrayo is a Nigerian public administrator and politician representing the Lanwa/Ejidongari constituency, Moro local government area in the Kwara State and the 10th Dupty House Leader of the Kwara State House of Assembly.[1][2]

targets.targetText: Abdulraheem Medinat Motunrayo je oloselu to n soju agbegbe Lanwa/Ejidongari, ijoba ibile Moro ni ipinle Kwara ati olori ile ìgbìmọ̀ kẹwàá Ile-igbimọ aṣofin Ipinle Kwara . [1] [2]

Abdulraheem Medinat Motunrayo je olori ilu Naijiria ati oloselu to n soju agbegbe Lanwa/Ejidongari, ijoba ibile Moro ni ipinle Kwara ati olori ile Dupty 10th ti Ile-igbimọ aṣofin Ipinle Kwara . [1] [2]

items.sourceText: Matthew Nwogu is a Nigerian politician who is currently serving as a member representing Aboh Mbaise/Ngor okpala Federal Constituency in the House of Representatives of Imo State.[1][2]

targets.targetText: Matthew Nwogu je oloselu omo orile-ede Naijiria to n sise bayii gege bi omo egbe to n soju agbegbe Aboh Mbaise/Ngor okpala Federal Constituency ni ile igbimo asofin ipinle Imo . [1] [2]
Matthew Nwogu je oloselu ọmọ orile-ede Nàìjíríà to n soju agbegbe Aboh Mbaise/Ngor okpala Federal Constituency ni ile igbimo asofin ipinle Imo . [1] [2]

items.sourceText: Martins Oke was born in 1958 and hails from Enugu State. He holds a bachelor’s degree in medicine. He served in the Federal House of Assembly from 2003 to 2007. He was re-elected in 2019, and again in 2023 for a third term as a federal legislator.[1][2]

targets.targetText: A bi Martins Oke ni ọdun 1958 o si wa lati Ipinle Enugu . O ni oye oye ni oogun. O ṣiṣẹ ni Ile-igbimọ Ile-igbimọ Federal lati 2003 si 2007. O tun dibo yan ni ọdun 2019, ati lẹẹkansi ni ọdun 2023 fun igba kẹta gẹgẹbi aṣofin ijọba apapọ. [1] [2]

A bi Martins Oke ni ọdun 1958 o si wa láti Ìpínlẹ̀ Enugu . O ni oye ni ìṣẹ́gun òyìnbó. O ṣiṣẹ ni Ile-igbimọ àgbà lati 2003 si 2007. O tun dibo yan ni ọdun 2019, ati lẹẹkansi ni ọdun 2023 fun igba kẹta gẹgẹbi aṣofin ijọba apapọ. [1] [2]

items.sourceText: In January 2014, she dated Nollywood actor Jim Iyke.[15] On 21 March 2014, Jim Iyke proposed to Buari.[16] She is a mother of twin girls but Jim Iyke is not the father.[17]

targets.targetText: Ni Oṣu Kini Oṣu Kini ọdun 2014, o ni ibaṣepọ Nollywood oṣere Jim Iyke . [1] Ni ojo kankanlelogun Oṣu Kẹta, Ọdun 2014, Jim Iyke dabaa fun Buari. [2] Arabinrin yi je iya ibeji sugbon Jim Iyke kii se baba won. [3]
Ni Oṣu Kini Oṣu Kini ọdun 2014, o ni ibaṣepọ Nollywood oṣere Jim Iyke . [1] Ni Oṣu Kẹta Ọjọ 21, Ọdun 2014, Jim Iyke dabaa fun Buari. [2] Arabinrin iya ni ibeji sugbon Jim Iyke kii se baba. [3]

items.sourceText: Chandamale also reached the final in the same category for a tenth-place finish at the 2006 Commonwealth Games in Melbourne, Australia, with a time of 17:10.46.

targets.targetText: Chandamale tun de ipari ni ẹka kanna fun ipari ibi kẹwa ni Awọn ere Agbaye 2006 ni Melbourne, Australia, pẹlu akoko 17:10.46.
Chandamale tun de ipele ipari ni ẹka kanna ni ipo kẹwa ni ere Agbaye 2006 ni Melbourne, Australia, ni akoko 17:10.46.

items.sourceText: Anifowoshe played for Göyazan Qazax during the 2004–05 and 2005–06 Azerbaijan season's and for Olimpik Baku during the 2006–07 season.

Anifowoshe ṣere fun Göyazan Qazax lakoko 2004–05 ati 2005–06 akoko Azerbaijan ati fun Olimpik Baku lakoko akoko 2006–07 .

items.sourceText: In 2014, he won the silver medal in the boys' 3000 metres event at the 2014 Summer Youth Olympics held in Nanjing, China.[2][3]

targets.targetText: Ni ọdun 2014, o gba ami-eye fadaka ni iṣẹlẹ awọn mita 3000 ti awọn ọmọkunrin ni Olimpiiki Igba ooru Ọdun 2014 ti o waye ni Nanjing, China. [1] [2]
Ni ọdun 2014, o gba ami-eye fadaka ni idije mita 3000 ti awọn ọmọkunrin ni Olimpiiki Igba ooru Ọdun 2014 ti o waye ni Nanjing, China. [1] [2]

items.sourceText: Since 2003, the school was renamed to Lagos State Senior Model College, Kankon. The junior section of the school was no longer under the administrative control of the school.

items.sourceText: She resigned in November 2021 in protest to the agreement to reinstate Abdalla Hamdok as Prime Minister after the 2021 Sudan coup d'état.[11]

targets.targetText: O fi ipo silẹ ni Oṣu kọkanla ọdun 2021 ni ilodi si adehun lati mu Abdalla Hamdok pada sipo gẹgẹbi Alakoso Agba lẹhin igbimọ ijọba Sudan 2021 . [1]
O fi ipo silẹ ni Oṣu kọkanla ọdun 2021 ni ilodi si adehun lati da Abdalla Hamdok pada sipo gẹgẹbi Prime Minister lẹhin igbimọ ijọba Sudan 2021.[11]

items.sourceText: Okeke obtained his  Master of Law (LL.M.) with honors (summa cum laude) from Kiev State University, Ukraine, and obtained his Doctorate in de Rechtsgeleerdheid (Ph.D.) from Free University of Amsterdam, The Netherlands.[1]

targets.targetText: Okeke gba Master of Law (LL.M.) pẹlu ọlá (summa cum laude) lati Kiev State University, Ukraine, o si gba oye oye rẹ ni de Rechtsgeleerdheid (Ph.D.) lati Ile-ẹkọ giga Ọfẹ ti Amsterdam, Fiorino.

Okeke gba Titunto si ti Ofin (LL.M.) pẹlu awọn ọlá (summa cum laude) lati Kiev State University, Ukraine, o si gba oye oye rẹ ni de Rechtsgeleerdheid (Ph.D.) lati Ile-ẹkọ giga ọfẹ ti Amsterdam, Fiorino . [1]

items.sourceText: Examples of her work is in the permanent collection of the Tate Gallery, the Arts Council and Birmingham Art Gallery.[1][2]

Awọn apẹẹrẹ ti iṣẹ rẹ wa ninu gbigba ayeraye ti Tate Gallery, Igbimọ Arts ati Birmingham Art Gallery.

items.sourceText: To use the library, a registration fee of #1,000 is required, which permits full access to the books on the shelves. However, the books available are outdated, mostly 1960–1970 publications.[6]

items.sourceText: Ghali Umar Na'Abba CFR (27 September 1958 – 27 December 2023) was a Nigerian politician who served as the 8th Speaker of the House of Representatives of Nigeria from 1999 to 2003.

targets.targetText: Ghali Umar Na'Abba CFR (27 Kẹsán 1958 – 27 December 2023) je olóṣèlú ọmọ orile-ede Naijiria ti o sise gege bi ààre ilé ìgbìmò aṣòfin lati ọdún 1999 si 2003.[1]
Ghali Umar Na'Abba CFR (27 Kẹsán 1958 – 27 December 2023) je oloselu omo orile-ede Naijiria ti o sise gege bi aare 8th ti Ile igbimo asoju-sofin Naijiria lati 1999 si 2003.

items.sourceText: In October 2024, six months after his suspension in May 2024, Iyamu was reinstated by the Edo State House of Assembly following an allegation that he had planted charms in the assembly complex.[2][3][4]

targets.targetText: Ni Oṣu Kẹwa ọdun 2024, oṣu mẹfa lẹhin idaduro rẹ ni May 2024, Iyamu ti da padà si Ile-igbimọ aṣòfin Ìpínlẹ̀ Edo lẹhin ẹsun kan pe o ti gbin awọn ẹwa si ile igbimọ naa. [1] [2] [3]
Ni Oṣu Kẹwa ọdun 2024, oṣu mẹfa lẹhin idaduro rẹ ni May 2024, Iyamu ti da pada si ile-igbimọ Ile-igbimọ Ipinle Edo lẹhin ẹsun kan pe o ti gbin awọn ẹwa si ile igbimọ naa. [1] [2] [3]

items.sourceText: On 14 August 2017, Omoni Oboli took to her instagram page to share a post announcing her new deal as the Brand ambassador of Olawale Ayilara's LandWey Investment Limited.[7]

targets.targetText: Ni Oṣu Kẹjọ Ọjọ 14 Oṣu Kẹjọ ọdun 2017, Omoni Oboli lọ si oju-iwe instagram rẹ lati pin ifiweranṣẹ kan ti o nkede adehun tuntun rẹ bi Ambassador Brand ti Olawale Ayilara ti LandWey Investment Limited. [1]
Ni Ọjọ kerinla Oṣu Kẹjọ ọdun 2017, Omoni Oboli lọ si oju-iwe instagram rẹ lati pin ifiweranṣẹ kan ti o nkede adehun tuntun rẹ bi Ambassador Brand ti Olawale Ayilara ti LandWey Investment Limited. [1]

items.sourceText: Da-Silva in 2012, debuted her career as a movie producer with a movie titled Mama Insurance which featured Ayo Mogaji, Lanre Hassan, Iyabo Ojo, Ronke Ojo, and Doris Simeon.[7][2]

targets.targetText: Da-Silva ni ọdun 2012, da iṣẹ rẹ bi olupilẹṣẹ fiimu pẹlu fiimu ti akole Mama Insurance eyiti o ṣe ifihan Ayo Mogaji, Lanre Hassan, Iyabo Ojo, Ronke Ojo, ati Doris Simeon . [1] [2]
Da-Silva ni ọdun 2012 ṣe akọkọ igberejade rẹ pẹlu fiimu ti akọle rẹ jẹ Mama Insurance, eyiti o ṣe ifihan Ayo Mogaji, Lanre Hassan, Iyabo Ojo, Ronke Ojo, ati Doris Simeon .[1][2]

items.sourceText: Ayobo is the last town in Lagos bordering Aiyetiro, Ogun State. Ayobo is a town with about 10 sub-towns under it. Megida, Isefun, Olorunisola, Bada, Sabo, Kande-Ijon, Orisumbare-Ijon, Jagundeyi, Alaja, etc.

targets.targetText: Ayobo ni ilu ti o kẹhin ni ilu Eko ni àlà Aiyetiro, ipinle Ogun. Ayobo jẹ ilu ti o ni awọn agbegbe mewa labẹ rẹ. Megida, Isefun, Olorunisola, Bada, Sabo, Kande-Ijon, Orisumbare-Ijon, Jagundeyi, Alaja, àti bebe lo.

Ayobo ni ilu ti o kẹhin ni ilu Eko ni bode Aiyetiro, ipinle Ogun. Ayobo jẹ ilu ti o ni awọn agbegbe agbegbe bi 10 labẹ rẹ. Megida, Isefun, Olorunisola, Bada, Sabo, Kande-Ijon, Orisumbare-Ijon, Jagundeyi, Alaja, etc.

items.sourceText: Hajia Sa’a Ibrahim was born to Malam Ibrahim and Yalwa Bello on 18 April 1960 in Magashi Quarters, Gwale Local Government Area in Kano State.

targets.targetText: Hajia Sa'a Ibrahim ni wọ́n bí sínú ìdílé Malam Ibrahim àti Yalwa Bello ní ọjọ́ kejìdínlógún oṣù kẹrin ọdún 1960 ní Magashi Quarters ní ìjọba ìbílẹ̀ Gwale ní ipinle Kano .
Hajia Sa'a Ibrahim ni won bi si Malam Ibrahim ati Yalwa Bello ni ojo kejidinlogun osu kerin odun 1960 ni Magashi Quarters ni ijoba ibile Gwale ni ipinle Kano .

items.sourceText: In December 2024, Ohajuruka was appointed by President Bola Tinubu as Executive Director for Finance on the Board of the South-East Development Commission (SEDC).[6][7]

targets.targetText: Ni Oṣu Kejila ọdun 2024, Aarẹ Bola Tinubu yan Ohajuruka gẹgẹ bi oludari eto iṣuna lori igbimọ igbimọ ti South-East Development Commission (SEDC). [1] [2]
Ni Oṣu Kejila ọdun 2024, Aarẹ Bola Tinubu yan Ohajuruka gẹgẹ bi olùdarí eto iṣuna lori ìgbìmò ti South-East Development Commission (SEDC). [1] [2]

items.sourceText: He finished twelfth in the high jump final at the 1968 Olympic Games. He also competed at the 1972 Olympic Games without reaching the final.[1]

targets.targetText: O pari kejila ni ipari fifo giga ni Awọn ere Olimpiiki 1968 . O tun dije ni Awọn ere Olimpiiki 1972 laisi ipari ipari. [1]
O pari ni ipo kejila ni ipari fifo giga ni ere Olimpiiki 1968 . O tun dije ninu ere Olimpiiki 1972 laisi dey ipari. [1]

items.sourceText: Anozie became paralyzed from polio when she was two years old.[1] She completed a university accounting program in 1998 but changed her career to sports when she could not find a job.[2]

targets.targetText: Anozie di rọ lati roparose nigbati o jẹ ọmọ ọdun meji. [1] O pari eto iṣiro ile-ẹkọ giga ni ọdun 1998 ṣugbọn o yipada iṣẹ rẹ si awọn ere idaraya nigbati ko le rii iṣẹ kan. [2]
Anozie di arọ lati ara aarun roparose nigbati o jẹ ọmọ ọdun meji. [1] O pari eto iṣiro ile-ẹkọ giga ni ọdun 1998 ṣugbọn o yipada iṣẹ rẹ si ere idaraya nigbati ko le rii iṣẹ kan. [2]

items.sourceText: The building, located at No. 53, Massey Street, Ita-Faaji, Lagos Island was a three story building with a penthouse and a primary school (Ohen Nursery and Primary School) on the second floor, prior to its collapse on the morning of the 13th. The Governor of Lagos State when the incident happened, Akinwunmi Ambode said the primary school was illegally occupying the building as the building is registered as a residential building.[8][9]

targets.targetText: Ile naa, ti o wa ni No. 53, Massey Street, Ita-Faaji, Lagos Island jẹ ile alaja mẹta ti o ni ile kekere kan ati ile-iwe alakọbẹrẹ (Ohen Nursery and Primary School) ni ipele keji, ṣaaju ki o to ṣubu ni owurọ owurọ. 13th. Gomina ipinle Eko nigba ti isele naa sele, Akinwunmi Ambode so pe ileewe alakobere n gbe ile naa lona ofin nitori pe ile naa ti wa ni oruko gege bi ile ibugbe. [1] [2]

Ile naa, ti o wa ni No. 53, Massey Street, Ita-Faaji, Lagos Island jẹ ile alaja mẹta ti o ni ile kekere kan ati ile-iwe alakọbẹrẹ (Ohen Nursery and Primary School) ni ipele keji, ṣaaju ki o to ṣubu ni owurọ ojo ketala. Gomina ipinle Eko nigba ti isele naa sele, Akinwunmi Ambode so pe ileewe alakobere n gbe ile naa lona ofin nitori pe ile naa ti wa ni oruko gege bi ile ibugbe. [1] [2]

items.sourceText: The estate hosts several hotels like Oakwood Park Hotel, Casa Hawa-Safe Court, Le Paris Continental Hotel and Pelican Intercontinental Hotel,[11] and a shopping complex.[2]

targets.targetText: Ohun-ini naa gbalejo ọpọlọpọ awọn ile itura bii Oakwood Park Hotel, Casa Hawa-Safe Court, Le Paris Continental Hotel ati Pelican Intercontinental Hotel, [1] ati eka ohun ile itaja. [2]

items.sourceText: Teye was admitted to the Ghana girls' U-17 team to plat at the [[2018 African U-17 Women's World Cup Qualifying Tournament and the 2018 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup .[5][6]

targets.targetText: Teye ti gba wọle si ẹgbẹ U-17 awọn ọmọbirin Ghana lati ṣe ere ni [[2018 African U-17 Women's World Cup Qualifying Figagbaga ati 2018 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup .
Wọ́n gba Teye wọlé sínú ẹgbẹ́ U-17 àwọn ọmọbìrin Ghana láti ṣe eré ní bi [[2018 African U-17 Women's World Cup Qualifying Tournament àti 2018 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup .

items.sourceText: He wrote several plays, producing The Jew's Revenge (1903) at the Royal Surrey Theatre in London, A Cleopatra Night (1907) at Dundee, and the Lily of Bermuda (1909), a musical comedy at the Theatre Royal, Manchester. The productions were praised by the British and American press.[citation needed]

targets.targetText: O kọ ọpọlọpọ awọn ere, ti o n ṣe Igbẹsan Juu (1903) ni Royal Surrey Theatre ni Ilu Lọndọn, Alẹ Cleopatra (1907) ni Dundee, ati Lily ti Bermuda (1909), awada orin kan ni Theatre Royal, Manchester. Awọn iṣe wonyi awon alatejade British ati Amẹrika gbori yin fun.

O kọ ọpọlọpọ awọn ere, ti o n ṣe Igbẹsan Juu (1903) ni Royal Surrey Theatre ni Ilu Lọndọnu, Alẹ Cleopatra (1907) ni Dundee, ati Lily ti Bermuda (1909), awada orin kan ni Theatre Royal, Manchester. Awọn iṣelọpọ ni iyìn nipasẹ awọn British ati awọn atẹjade Amẹrika.

items.sourceText: Mumtaz Ali was honoured with title of "Shams-ul-Ulama" by the Government of British India in 1934.[1] He died on 15 June 1935 in Lahore.[2]

targets.targetText: Mumtaz Ali ni wọ́n fi oyè "Shams-ul-Ulama" dalola nipasẹ Ijọba Gẹẹsi ti India ni ọdun 1934. [1] O ku ni ọjọ́ keedogun ọdún 1935 ni Lahore. [2]
Mumtaz Ali ni ola pẹlu akọle "Shams-ul-Ulama" nipasẹ Ijọba Gẹẹsi ti India ni ọdun 1934. [1] O ku ni 15 Okudu 1935 ni Lahore. [2]

items.sourceText: Fadwa Abd al-Rahman Ali Taha (Arabic: فدوى عبد الرحمن علي طه; born 23 October 1955 in Arbaji, Gezira State, Sudan) is a professor at the Department of History, University of Khartoum.[1]

targets.targetText: Fadwa Abd al-Rahman Ali Taha (Larubawa: فدوى عبد الرحمن علي طه; ti a bi 23 Oṣu Kẹwa Ọdun 1955 ni Arbaji, Ipinle Gezira, Sudan) jẹ olukọ ọjọgbọn ni Sakaani ti Itan, University of Khartoum.[1]
Fadwa Abd al-Rahman Ali Taha ( Arabic </link> ; bi 23 Oṣu Kẹwa Ọdun 1955 ni Arbaji, Ipinle Gezira, Sudan) jẹ olukọ ọjọgbọn ni Sakaani ti Itan, University of Khartoum . [1]

items.sourceText: Ibrahim Al Husseini Hamadtou (born 1 July 1973),[3] also known as Ibrahim Elhusseiny Hamadtou, is an Egyptian Para table tennis Champion, winning several honors over the years, including the silver medals in the African Para table tennis Championships in 2011 and 2013.[2]

targets.targetText: Ibrahim Al Husseini Hamadtou (ti a bi ni ojo 1 Osu Keje odun 1973), [1] ti a tun mọ si Ibrahim Elhusseiny Hamadtou, jẹ Aṣaju tẹnisi tabili Para ti ara ilu Egypt, ti o gba ọpọlọpọ amin ọla ni opoo ọdun, pẹlu ami-ẹri fadaka ninu idije tẹnisi tabili tabili Para ti Afirika ni ọdun 2011 ati Ọdun 2013.

Ibrahim Al Husseini Hamadtou (ti a bi 1 Keje 1973), [1] ti a tun mọ si Ibrahim Elhusseiny Hamadtou, jẹ Aṣaju tẹnisi tabili Para ti ara ilu Egypt, ti o bori ọpọlọpọ awọn ọla ni awọn ọdun, pẹlu awọn ami-ẹri fadaka ni Awọn idije tẹnisi tabili tabili Para ti Afirika ni ọdun 2011 ati Ọdun 2013.

items.sourceText: Iheanacho began his senior career at Manchester City during the 2015–16 season.[5][6][7] He moved to Leicester City in 2017 for a reported £25 million fee.

targets.targetText: Iheanacho bẹrẹ iṣẹ agba rẹ ni Ilu Manchester ni akoko 2015–16 . [1] [2] [3] O gbe lọ si Ilu Leicester ni ọdun 2017 fun idiyele £ 25 kan ti o royin.
Iheanacho bẹrẹ iṣẹ agba rẹ ni Ilu Manchester ni akoko 2015–16 . [1] [2] [3] O lọ si ẹgbẹ agbabọọlu Leicester ni ọdun 2017 fun idiyele £25milliion

items.sourceText: Théodore Nkwayed (born 6 March 1967) is a Cameroonian weightlifter. He competed in the men's heavyweight I event at the 1988 Summer Olympics.[1]

targets.targetText: Théodore Nkwayed (ojoibi 6 March 1967) je omo ilu Kamẹru . O dije ninu ìdíje gbigbe irinwuwo awọn ọkunrin ni Olimpiiki Igba ooru 1988 . [1]
Théodore Nkwayed (ojoibi 6 March 1967) je omo ilu Kamẹru . O dije ninu iṣẹlẹ iwuwo iwuwo awọn ọkunrin ni Awọn Olimpiiki Igba ooru 1988 . [1]

items.sourceText: In 2011, Eyekeno was elected as a member representing ibesikpo Asutan in the Akwa Ibom State House of Assembly, was appointed chairman house Committee on Finance and Appropriation, Akwa Ibom State House of Assembly.[1]

items.sourceText: Jeillo Angela Doris Edwards[3] was born in Freetown, Sierra Leone, one of six children, and she attended the Annie Walsh Memorial School.[2]

items.sourceText: In 2013, she won the Pan African Actress award at the annual Nigerian Entertainment Awards (NEA Awards) in New York City.[13]

targets.targetText: Ni ọdun 2013, o gba ami eye oṣere Pan African ni ọdọọdun Nigerian Entertainment Awards(NEA Awards) ni Ilu New York . [1]
Ni ọdun 2013, o gba ami eye oṣere Pan African ni ọdọọdun Awọn ohun idanilaraya ti Naijiria (NEA Awards) ni Ilu New York . [1]
